llm_translation: Rava said: A breach calls out to the thief. What is the difference between them? The difference between them is that one is guarding a vineyard of cucumbers.

hebrew_text: חוֹלִים וּמְשַׁמְּשֵׁיהֶם. תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: חוֹלֶה שֶׁאָמְרוּ, לֹא חוֹלֶה שֶׁיֵּשׁ בּוֹ סַכָּנָה, אֶלָּא אֲפִילּוּ חוֹלֶה שֶׁאֵין בּוֹ סַכָּנָה. אֲפִילּוּ חָשׁ בְּעֵינָיו, וַאֲפִילּוּ חָשׁ בְּרֹאשׁוֹ. אָמַר רַבָּן שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן גַּמְלִיאֵל: פַּעַם אַחַת חַשְׁתִּי בְּעֵינֵי בְּקֵיסָרִי, וְהִתִּיר רַבִּי יוֹסֵי בְּרִיבִּי לִישַׁן אֲנִי וּמְשַׁמְּשַׁי חוּץ לַסּוּכָּה.
human_translation: ill and their caretakers The Sages taught ill that they said an ill whose is critical, but even an ill whose is not critical, even feels in his eyes, and even feels in his head. Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel said: One time I felt in my eyes in Caesarea, and the esteemed Rabbi Yosei permitted me and my attendant to sleep outside the sukka .
llm_translation: Ill individuals and their attendants. The Rabbis taught: Regarding an ill person that they said, "He is not ill with danger," but even if he is ill without danger. Even if he feels unwell in his eyes, and even if he feels unwell in his head. Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel said: Once I felt unwell in the presence of the Caesar, and Rabbi Yosei, my friend, permitted me to sleep and attend to my needs outside the sukkah.

hebrew_text: רַב שְׁרָא לְרַב אַחָא בַּרְדְּלָא לְמִגְנֵא בְּכִילְּתָא בַּסּוּכָּה — מִשּׁוּם בָּקֵי. רָבָא שְׁרָא לֵיהּ לְרַבִּי אַחָא בַּר אַדָּא לְמִגְנֵא בַּר מִמְּטַלַּלְתָּא — מִשּׁוּם סִירְחָא דְגַרְגִּישְׁתָּא.
human_translation: Rav permitted Rav Aḥa Bardela to sleep beneath a canopy in the sukka due to flies [ baki ]. Rava permitted Rabbi Aḥa bar Adda to sleep outside the sukka due to the foul odor of the earth [ gargishta ]
llm_translation: Rav Shera said to Rav Acha bar Della to shield in the palm grove in the sukkah - due to the palm branches. Rava said to Rabbi Acha bar Adda to shield in the palm grove of the matlalta - due to the thick layer of reeds.

hebrew_text: רָבָא לְטַעְמֵיהּ, דְּאָמַר רָבָא: מִצְטַעֵר — פָּטוּר מִן הַסּוּכָּה. וְהָא אֲנַן תְּנַן: חוֹלִין וּמְשַׁמְּשֵׁיהֶם פְּטוּרִים מִן הַסּוּכָּה. חוֹלֶה אִין, מִצְטַעַר לָא! אָמְרִי: חוֹלֶה — הוּא וּמְשַׁמְּשָׁיו פְּטוּרִים, מִצְטַעֵר — הוּא פָּטוּר, מְשַׁמְּשָׁיו לָא.
human_translation: Rava to his reasoning, as Rava said: One who suffers is exempt from the sukka . But didn’t we learn ill and their caretakers are exempt from the sukka ? an ill yes, one who suffers, no, say: an ill he and his caretakers are exempt; one who suffers he is exempt his caretakers not.
llm_translation: Rava according to his reasoning, for Rava said: If one is in pain - exempt from the sukkah. But we learned: The sick and their attendants are exempt from the sukkah. If one is not sick, he is not in pain! It was said: If one is sick - he and his attendants are exempt, if he is in pain - he is exempt, but his attendants are not.

hebrew_text: אוֹכְלִים אֲכִילַת עֲרַאי חוּץ לַסּוּכָּה. וְכַמָּה אֲכִילַת עֲרַאי? אָמַר רַב יוֹסֵף: תַּרְתֵּי אוֹ תְּלָת בֵּיעֵי. אֲמַר לֵיהּ אַבָּיֵי: וְהָא זִימְנִין סַגִּיאִין סַגִּי לֵיהּ לְאִינִישׁ בְּהָכִי, וְהָוֵה לֵיהּ סְעוּדַת קֶבַע! אֶלָּא אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: כִּדְטָעֵים בַּר בֵּי רַב וְעָיֵיל לְכַלָּה.
human_translation: One may eat casual meal outside the sukka . And how much is a casual meal? Rav Yosef said: two or three egg Abaye said to him: But often, doesn’t a person suffice with that and its is a formal meal? Rather, Abaye said: like that a student of the academy of Rav tastes and then enters the lecture.
llm_translation: Eating a temporary meal outside of the sukkah. And how much is a temporary meal? Rav Yosef said: Two or three eggs. Abaye said to him: But sometimes a person is satisfied with this amount, and it becomes a fixed meal for him! Rather, Abaye said: Like the guests of the house of Rav who would go to a wedding feast.

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: אוֹכְלִין אֲכִילַת עֲרַאי חוּץ לַסּוּכָּה, וְאֵין יְשֵׁנִים שֵׁינַת עֲרַאי חוּץ לַסּוּכָּה. מַאי טַעְמָא? אָמַר רַב אָשֵׁי: גְּזֵרָה שֶׁמָּא יֵרָדֵם.
human_translation: The Sages taught One eat a casual meal outside the sukka , but one not a brief nap outside the sukka . What is the reason Rav Ashi said: a decree lest he fall sleep.
llm_translation: The sages taught: One may eat a temporary meal outside the sukkah, but one may not sleep a temporary sleep outside the sukkah. What is the reason? Rav Ashi said: It is a decree lest one fall into a deep sleep.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ אַבָּיֵי, אֶלָּא הָא דְּתַנְיָא: יָשֵׁן אָדָם שֵׁינַת עֲרַאי בִּתְפִילִּין, אֲבָל לֹא שֵׁינַת קֶבַע, לֵיחוּשׁ שֶׁמָּא יֵרָדֵם! אָמַר רַב יוֹסֵף בְּרֵיהּ דְּרַב עִילַּאי: בְּמוֹסֵר שְׁנָתוֹ לַאֲחֵרִים.
human_translation: Abaye said to him: But that which is taught A person take a brief nap phylacteries but substantial sleep not Let us be concerned lest he fall sleep. Rav Yosef, son of Rav Illai, said: where one assigns his sleep to others.
llm_translation: He said to him Abaye, rather this that it teaches: A person may sleep a temporary sleep with tefillin, but not a permanent sleep, for fear he may fall asleep! Rav Yosef, son of Rav Illai, said: By relinquishing his sleep to others.

hebrew_text: מַתְקֵיף לֵיהּ רַב מְשַׁרְשְׁיָא: עָרְבָיךְ עָרְבָא צְרִיךְ! אֶלָּא אָמַר רַבָּה בַּר בַּר חָנָה אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: בְּמַנִּיחַ רֹאשׁוֹ בֵּין בִּרְכָּיו עָסְקִינַן. רָבָא אָמַר: אֵין קֶבַע לַשֵּׁינָה.
human_translation: Rav Mesharshiyya strongly objects to Your guarantor, requires a guarantor Rather, Rabba bar bar Ḥana said Rabbi Yoḥanan said: We are dealing with where he places his head between his knees, Rava said: there is no substantial to sleep,
llm_translation: Rav Mesharshya objects to him: "Your evening is evening, it requires a pledge!" Rather, Rabba bar bar Ḥana said in the name of Rabbi Yoḥanan: We are dealing with one who places his head between his knees. Rava said: There is no permanence for the tooth.

hebrew_text: תָּנֵי חֲדָא: יָשֵׁן אָדָם בִּתְפִילִּין שֵׁינַת עֲרַאי אֲבָל לֹא שֵׁינַת קֶבַע, וְתַנְיָא אִידַּךְ: בֵּין קֶבַע בֵּין עֲרַאי. וְתַנְיָא אִידַּךְ: לֹא קֶבַע וְלֹא עֲרַאי. לָא קַשְׁיָא: הָא — דְּנָקֵיט לְהוּ בִּידֵיהּ. הָא — דְּמַנְּחִי בְּרֵישֵׁיהּ. הָא — דְּפָרֵיס סוּדָרָא עִלָּוֵיהּ.
human_translation: it is taught one A person take a brief nap with phylacteries, but substantial sleep not And it was taught another Both substantial and brief And it was taught another Neither substantial nor brief not difficult: This where one holds in his hands. That where are placed on his head. That where he spreads a cloth over
llm_translation: One taught: A person may sleep in tefillin for a temporary sleep, but not for a permanent sleep. And it was taught in another source: Whether for a permanent sleep or a temporary sleep. And it was taught in another source: Not for a permanent sleep and not for a temporary sleep. There is no difficulty: this one - who takes them off with his hands. That one - who places them on his head. That one - who spreads a cloth over them.

hebrew_text: וְכַמָּה שֵׁינַת עֲרַאי? תָּנֵי רָמֵי בַּר יְחֶזְקֵאל: כְּדֵי הִילּוּךְ מֵאָה אַמָּה. תַּנְיָא נָמֵי הָכִי: הַיָּשֵׁן בִּתְפִילִּין וְרוֹאֶה קֶרִי — אוֹחֵז בָּרְצוּעָה
human_translation: And how much is a brief nap? Rami bar Yeḥezkel taught: equivalent walking one hundred cubits. That is also taught One who sleeps with phylacteries and experiences a seminal emission grips the strap
llm_translation: The Talmudic text translates as follows: "And how much is the measurement of an 'Ar'ai? It was taught: Ramei son of Yehezkel said: The distance of one hundred cubits. It was taught similarly: One who falls asleep wearing Tefillin and experiences a seminal emission - he grasps the strap."

hebrew_text: וְאֵינוֹ אוֹחֵז בַּקְּצִיצָה, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי יַעֲקֹב. וַחֲכָמִים אוֹמְרִים: יָשֵׁן אָדָם בִּתְפִילִּין שֵׁינַת עֲרַאי, אֲבָל לֹא שֵׁינַת קֶבַע. וְכַמָּה שֵׁינַת עֲרַאי — כְּדֵי הִילּוּךְ מֵאָה אַמָּה.
human_translation: and does not grip the box the statement of Rabbi Ya’akov. And the Rabbis say: A person take a brief nap with his phylacteries, but substantial sleep not And how long is a brief nap? equivalent walking one hundred cubits.
llm_translation: "And one who does not hold onto the tzitzit, the words of Rabbi Yaakov. And the sages say: A person may sleep with tefillin for a temporary sleep, but not for a permanent sleep. And how long is a temporary sleep? The distance of one hundred cubits."

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב: אָסוּר לָאָדָם לִישַׁן בַּיּוֹם יוֹתֵר מִשֵּׁינַת הַסּוּס. וְכַמָּה שֵׁינַת הַסּוּס — שִׁיתִּין נִשְׁמֵי.
human_translation: Rav said: It is prohibited for a person to sleep during the day longer than the sleep of a horse. And how long is the sleep of a horse? sixty breaths
llm_translation: Rav said: It is forbidden for a person to sleep during the day more than the sleep of a horse. And how much is the sleep of a horse? Sixty breaths.

hebrew_text: אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: שִׁנְתֵּיהּ דְּמָר כִּדְרַב, וּדְרַב כִּדְרַבִּי, וּדְרַבִּי כִּדְדָוִד, וּדְדָוִד כִּדְסוּסְיָא, וּדְסוּסְיָא שִׁיתִּין נִשְׁמֵי.
human_translation: Abaye said: The sleep of Master, like that of Rav, and that of Rav like of Rabbi And that of Rabbi like that of David, and that of David like that of a horse. And that of a horse is sixty breaths.
llm_translation: Abaye said: The teeth of Mar are like those of Rav, and those of Rav are like those of Rabbi, and those of Rabbi are like those of David, and those of David are like those of Susya, and those of Susya are sixty souls.

hebrew_text: אַבָּיֵי הֲוָה נָיֵים כְּדִמְעַיֵּיל מִפּוּמְבְּדִיתָא לְבֵי כוּבֵּי. קָרֵי עֲלֵיהּ רַב יוֹסֵף: ״עַד מָתַי עָצֵל תִּשְׁכָּב מָתַי תָּקוּם מִשְּׁנָתֶךָ״.
human_translation: Abaye would sleep for equivalent enter from Pumbedita to Bei Kuvei. Rav Yosef read pertaining to “How long will you sleep, sluggard? When will you arise from your sleep?”
llm_translation: Abbaye was sleeping when he woke up from his nap and went to the house of study. Rav Yosef called out to him: "How long will you lie there, O sluggard? When will you arise from your sleep?"

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: הַנִּכְנָס לִישַׁן בַּיּוֹם, רָצָה — חוֹלֵץ, רָצָה — מַנִּיחַ. בַּלַּיְלָה — חוֹלֵץ וְאֵינוֹ מַנִּיחַ, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי נָתָן. רַבִּי יוֹסֵי אוֹמֵר: הַיְּלָדִים, לְעוֹלָם חוֹלְצִין וְאֵינָן מַנִּיחִין, מִפְּנֵי שֶׁרְגִילִין בְּטוּמְאָה.
human_translation: The Sages taught one who enters to sleep during the day, if he wishes, he remove if he wishes, he leave at night removes and not leave the statement of Rabbi Natan. Rabbi Yosei says: The young always remove and not leave because they are accustomed to impurity,
llm_translation: The Sages taught: One who enters to sleep during the day, if he wishes - he may remove his tefillin, if he wishes - he may leave them on. At night - he must remove them and may not leave them on, the words of Rabbi Nathan. Rabbi Yosei says: Children, always remove their tefillin and do not leave them on, because they are accustomed to impurity.

hebrew_text: לֵימָא קָסָבַר רַבִּי יוֹסֵי בַּעַל קֶרִי אָסוּר לְהַנִּיחַ תְּפִילִּין? אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: בִּילָדִים וּנְשׁוֹתֵיהֶן עִמָּהֶן עָסְקִינַן, שֶׁמָּא יָבוֹאוּ לִידֵי הֶרְגֵּל דָּבָר.
human_translation: Let us say that Rabbi Yosei holds it is prohibited one who experienced a seminal emission to don phylacteries. Abaye said: we are dealing with young wives are with them, lest they come to engage in matters accustomed,
llm_translation: Let's say Rabbi Yosei holds that one who experiences a seminal emission is forbidden to wear tefillin? Abaye said: We are dealing with young boys and their wives, lest they come to a matter of habit.

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: שָׁכַח וְשִׁמֵּשׁ מִטָּתוֹ בִּתְפִילִּין — אֵינוֹ אוֹחֵז לֹא בָּרְצוּעָה וְלֹא בַּקְּצִיצָה עַד שֶׁיִּטּוֹל יָדָיו וְיִטְּלֵם, מִפְּנֵי שֶׁהַיָּדַיִם עַסְקָנִיּוֹת הֵן.
human_translation: The Sages taught one forgot and engaged in relations with his phylacteries he grip neither the strap nor the box until he washes his hands, and remove because the hands are active
llm_translation: The sages taught: If one forgot and used his bed for Tefillin - he does not touch either the strap or the box until he washes his hands and then touches them, because the hands are busy.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ מַעֲשֶׂה וְהֵבִיאוּ לוֹ לְרַבָּן יוֹחָנָן בֶּן זַכַּאי לִטְעוֹם אֶת הַתַּבְשִׁיל, וּלְרַבָּן גַּמְלִיאֵל שְׁנֵי כּוֹתָבוֹת וּדְלִי שֶׁל מַיִם. וְאָמְרוּ: הַעֲלוּם לַסּוּכָּה.
human_translation: An incident they brought a cooked dish to Rabban Yoḥanan ben Zakkai to taste, and to Rabban Gamliel two dates and a bucket of water. And they said: Take them up to the sukka
llm_translation: The Mishnah: A story, they brought to Rabban Yochanan ben Zakkai to taste the dish, and to Rabban Gamliel two scrolls and a jug of water. And they said: Bring them into the sukkah.

hebrew_text: וּכְשֶׁנָּתְנוּ לוֹ לְרַבִּי צָדוֹק אוֹכֶל פָּחוֹת מִכְּבֵיצָה, נְטָלוֹ בַּמַּפָּה, וַאֲכָלוֹ חוּץ לַסּוּכָּה, וְלֹא בֵּירַךְ אַחֲרָיו.
human_translation: And when they gave Rabbi Tzadok less than an egg-bulk of food, he took in a cloth And he ate it outside the sukka and did not recite a blessing after it.
llm_translation: And when they gave to Rabbi Tzadok, he ate less than an egg, took it in a cloth, and ate it outside the sukkah, and did not bless afterward.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ מַעֲשֶׂה לִסְתּוֹר?! חַסּוֹרֵי מְחַסְּרָא וְהָכִי קָתָנֵי: אִם בָּא לְהַחְמִיר עַל עַצְמוֹ — מַחְמִיר, וְלֵית בֵּיהּ מִשּׁוּם יוּהֲרָא. וּמַעֲשֶׂה נָמֵי וְהֵבִיאוּ לוֹ לְרַבָּן יוֹחָנָן בֶּן זַכַּאי לִטְעוֹם אֶת הַתַּבְשִׁיל, וּלְרַבָּן גַּמְלִיאֵל שְׁתֵּי כוֹתָבוֹת וּדְלִי שֶׁל מַיִם,
human_translation: an incident to contradict incomplete, and it teaches the following: If one seeks to impose a stringency upon himself he be stringent, and there is no presumptuousness And also an incident They brought a cooked dish to Rabban Yoḥanan ben Zakkai to taste, and to Rabban Gamliel two dates and a bucket of water,
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Is it possible to hide a camel?! Deficient in deficiency, yet it teaches: If one wishes to be stringent upon oneself — let him be stringent, and there is no element of haughtiness in this. And there was a similar incident, they brought it to Rabban Yochanan ben Zakkai to taste the dish, and to Rabban Gamliel two scrolls and a jug of water.

hebrew_text: וְאָמְרוּ: הַעֲלוּם לַסּוּכָּה.
human_translation: and they said: Take them up to the sukka .
llm_translation: And they said: "Bring the hidden one to the booth."

hebrew_text: וּכְשֶׁנָּתְנוּ לוֹ לְרַבִּי צָדוֹק אוֹכֶל פָּחוֹת מִכְּבֵיצָה, נְטָלוֹ בְּמַפָּה וַאֲכָלוֹ חוּץ לַסּוּכָּה וְלֹא בֵּירַךְ אַחֲרָיו. הָא כְּבֵיצָה, בָּעֵי סוּכָּה. לֵימָא תֶּיהְוֵי תְּיוּבְתֵּיהּ דְּרַב יוֹסֵף וְאַבָּיֵי! דִּילְמָא פָּחוֹת מִכְּבֵיצָה נְטִילָה וּבְרָכָה לָא בָּעֵי, הָא כְּבֵיצָה בָּעֵי נְטִילָה וּבְרָכָה.
human_translation: And when they gave Rabbi Tzadok less than an egg-bulk of food, he took in a cloth and he ate it outside the sukka and did not recite a blessing after it. an egg-bulk he required sukka . Let us say that this is a conclusive refutation of Rav Yosef and Abaye, perhaps less than an egg-bulk does not require washing and a blessing however, an egg-bulk requires washing and blessing.
llm_translation: When they gave to Rabbi Tzadok less than a k'beitza to eat, he took it in a cloth and ate it outside the sukkah without reciting a blessing afterward. The Gemara asks: If it is less than a k'beitza, does it require a sukkah? Let it be the preference of Rav Yosef and Abaye! Perhaps when it is less than a k'beitza, it does not require a blessing, but when it is a k'beitza, it does require a blessing.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר אוֹמֵר: אַרְבַּע עֶשְׂרֵה סְעוּדוֹת חַיָּיב אָדָם לֶאֱכוֹל בַּסּוּכָּה, אַחַת בְּיוֹם וְאַחַת בַּלַּיְלָה. וַחֲכָמִים אוֹמְרִים: אֵין לַדָּבָר קִצְבָה, חוּץ מִלֵּילֵי יוֹם טוֹב רִאשׁוֹן שֶׁל חַג בִּלְבַד.
human_translation: Rabbi Eliezer says: A person is obligated to eat fourteen meals in the sukka one during the day and one at night And the Rabbis say: There is no quota except for the evening of the first Festival of Sukkot ,
llm_translation: The Mishnah: Rabbi Eliezer says: A person is obligated to eat fourteen meals in the sukkah, one during the day and one at night. And the Sages say: There is no fixed measure for this matter, except for the nights of the first day of the festival alone.

hebrew_text: וְעוֹד אָמַר רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר: מִי שֶׁלֹּא אָכַל [לֵילֵי] יוֹם טוֹב הָרִאשׁוֹן — יַשְׁלִים לֵילֵי יוֹם טוֹב הָאַחֲרוֹן שֶׁל חַג. וַחֲכָמִים אוֹמְרִים: אֵין לַדָּבָר תַּשְׁלוּמִין, וְעַל זֶה נֶאֱמַר: ״מְעֻוָּת לֹא יוּכַל לִתְקוֹן וְחֶסְרוֹן לֹא יוּכַל לְהִמָּנוֹת״.
human_translation: And furthermore, Rabbi Eliezer said: One who did not eat evening of the first day compensate evening of the last day of the Festival, And the Rabbis say: There is no compensation for matter, and with regard to it is stated: “That which is crooked cannot be made straight; and that which is wanting cannot be numbered”
llm_translation: And furthermore, Rabbi Eliezer said: One who did not eat on the first day of the festival must complete it on the last day of the festival. And the sages say: There are no make-up offerings for this matter, and regarding this it is said: "That which is crooked cannot be straightened, and that which is lacking cannot be counted."

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ מַאי טַעְמֵיהּ דְּרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר? ״תֵּשְׁבוּ״ כְּעֵין תָּדוּרוּ. מָה דִּירָה — אַחַת בַּיּוֹם וְאַחַת בַּלַּיְלָה, אַף סוּכָּה — אַחַת בְּיוֹם וְאַחַת בַּלַּיְלָה.
human_translation: What is the rationale of Rabbi Eliezer, shall you reside” as you dwell just as dwelling one during the day and one at night, so too, in a sukka one during the day and one at night.
llm_translation: Gemara: What is the reason for Rabbi Eliezer's opinion? "You shall dwell" - similar to your permanent residence. Just as a dwelling - one during the day and one at night, so too a sukkah - one during the day and one at night.

hebrew_text: וְרַבָּנַן? כְּדִירָה. מָה דִּירָה — אִי בָּעֵי אָכֵיל אִי בָּעֵי לָא אָכֵיל, אַף סוּכָּה נָמֵי — אִי בָּעֵי אָכֵיל אִי בָּעֵי לָא אָכֵיל.
human_translation: And the Rabbis like a dwelling. Just as dwelling, if one desires he eats, and if one does not desire he does not eat, so too, sukka , if one desires he eats, and if one does not desire he does not eat.
llm_translation: The sages? Like a dirah. What is a dirah? If one wants to eat, or if one does not want to eat, so too with a sukkah — if one wants to eat, or if one does not want to eat.

hebrew_text: אִי הָכִי אֲפִילּוּ לֵילֵי יוֹם טוֹב רִאשׁוֹן נָמֵי!
human_translation: If so, even the first Festival evening as well
llm_translation: "If so, even the nights of the first day of a festival are considered!"

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן מִשּׁוּם רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן יְהוֹצָדָק: נֶאֱמַר כָּאן ״חֲמִשָּׁה עָשָׂר״, וְנֶאֱמַר ״חֲמִשָּׁה עָשָׂר״ בְּחַג הַמַּצּוֹת. מָה לְהַלָּן — לַיְלָה הָרִאשׁוֹן חוֹבָה, מִכָּאן וְאֵילָךְ רְשׁוּת, אַף כָּאן — לַיְלָה הָרִאשׁוֹן חוֹבָה, מִכָּאן וְאֵילָךְ רְשׁוּת.
human_translation: Rabbi Yoḥanan said in the name of Rabbi Shimon ben Yehotzadak: It is stated here, fifteenth And it is stated: fifteenth with regard to Passover. Just as there, the first night an obligation and from that point onward it is optional, so too here, the first night is an obligation and from that point onward it is optional.
llm_translation: Said Rabbi Yochanan in the name of Rabbi Shimon ben Yehotzadak: It is stated here "fifteen," and it is stated "fifteen" on the Festival of Matzot. Just as there — the first night is obligatory, from here onward is optional, so too here — the first night is obligatory, from here onward is optional.

hebrew_text: וְהָתָם מְנָלַן? אָמַר קְרָא: ״בָּעֶרֶב תֹּאכְלוּ מַצּוֹת״, הַכָּתוּב קְבָעוֹ חוֹבָה.
human_translation: And there, from where do we the verse says: “In the evening you shall eat matzot ” The verse established it an obligation.
llm_translation: And there, how do we derive it? The verse says: "In the evening, you shall eat unleavened bread," the Scripture has established it as an obligation.

hebrew_text: וְעוֹד אָמַר רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר: וְהָא אָמַר רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר אַרְבַּע עֶשְׂרֵה סְעוּדוֹת חַיָּיב אָדָם לֶאֱכוֹל בַּסּוּכָּה, אַחַת בַּיּוֹם וְאַחַת בַּלַּיְלָה! אָמַר בֵּירָא אָמַר רַבִּי אַמֵּי: חָזַר בּוֹ רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר.
human_translation: And furthermore, Rabbi Eliezer said But didn’t Rabbi Eliezer say a person is obligated to eat fourteen meals in the sukka , one during the day and one at night? Beira said Rabbi Ami said: Rabbi Eliezer retracted
llm_translation: And furthermore said Rabbi Eliezer: And this is what Rabbi Eliezer said: Fourteen meals a person is obligated to eat in the sukkah, one during the day and one at night! Beira said in the name of Rabbi Ammi: Rabbi Eliezer retracted.

hebrew_text: מַשְׁלִים בְּמַאי? אִילֵימָא בְּרִיפְתָּא, סְעוּדָה דְיוֹמֵיהּ קָא אָכֵיל. אֶלָּא, מַאי יַשְׁלִים — יַשְׁלִים בְּמִינֵי תַרְגִּימָא. תַּנְיָא נָמֵי הָכִי: אִם הִשְׁלִים בְּמִינֵי תַרְגִּימָא — יָצָא.
human_translation: With what he compensate If we say with bread, he is eating the meal of that Day Rather, what is He compensate? he compensate by types of delicacies [ targima ]. That is taught as well: If he compensated by types of delicacies, he fulfilled his obligation.
llm_translation: Interpreting with what? Perhaps with bread, he is eating his daytime meal. Rather, with what does he interpret? He interprets with different types of translations. It was also taught similarly: If he interpreted with different types of translations - he has fulfilled his obligation.

hebrew_text: שָׁאַל אַפּוֹטְרוֹפּוֹס שֶׁל אַגְרִיפַּס הַמֶּלֶךְ אֶת רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר: כְּגוֹן אֲנִי, שֶׁאֵינִי רָגִיל לֶאֱכוֹל אֶלָּא סְעוּדָה אַחַת בַּיּוֹם, מַהוּ שֶׁאוֹכַל סְעוּדָה אַחַת וְאֶפָּטֵר? אָמַר לוֹ: בְּכׇל יוֹם וְיוֹם אַתָּה מַמְשִׁיךְ כַּמָּה פַּרְפְּרָאוֹת לִכְבוֹד עַצְמְךָ, וְעַכְשָׁיו אִי אַתָּה מַמְשִׁיךְ פַּרְפֶּרֶת אַחַת לִכְבוֹד קוֹנֶךָ?
human_translation: The steward [ apotropos ] of King Agrippas asked Rabbi Eliezer: For like me, who is accustomed to eat only one meal a day, what is that I eat one meal exempt said to him: Each day you continue and taste various kinds of appetizers in deference to your own and now you do not continue one appetizer in deference to your Maker?
llm_translation: He asked Apotropos, the steward of King Agrippas, Rabbi Eliezer: For example, I, who am not accustomed to eat except one meal a day, what if I eat one meal and conclude? He said to him: Every day you prolong how many butterflies for your own honor, and now you will not prolong one butterfly for the honor of your Creator?

hebrew_text: וְעוֹד שְׁאָלוֹ: כְּגוֹן אֲנִי שֶׁיֵּשׁ לִי שְׁתֵּי נָשִׁים, אַחַת בִּטְבֶרְיָא וְאַחַת בְּצִיפּוֹרִי, וְיֵשׁ לִי שְׁתֵּי סוּכּוֹת אַחַת בִּטְבֶרְיָא וְאַחַת בְּצִיפּוֹרִי, מַהוּ שֶׁאֵצֵא מִסּוּכָּה לְסוּכָּה וְאֶפָּטֵר? אָמַר לוֹ: לֹא! שֶׁאֲנִי אוֹמֵר: כׇּל הַיּוֹצֵא מִסּוּכָּה לְסוּכָּה בִּטֵּל מִצְוָתָהּ שֶׁל רִאשׁוֹנָה.
human_translation: And further asked For like me, who has two wives, one in Tiberias and one in Tzippori, and has two sukkot , one in Tiberias and one in Tzippori, what I depart from sukka to sukka and exempt said to him: No, as I say anyone who departs from sukka to sukka has negated the mitzva of the first.
llm_translation: And they further asked: For example, I have two wives, one in Tiberias and one in Tzippori, and I have two sukkot, one in Tiberias and one in Tzippori. What is the law if I go from one sukkah to another and exempt myself? He said to him: No! For I say: Anyone who goes from one sukkah to another nullifies the obligation of the first.

hebrew_text: תַּנְיָא רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר אוֹמֵר:
human_translation: It is taught Rabbi Eliezer says:
llm_translation: It is taught in a Baraita: Rabbi Eliezer says:

hebrew_text: אֵין יוֹצְאִין מִסּוּכָּה לְסוּכָּה, וְאֵין עוֹשִׂין סוּכָּה בְּחוּלּוֹ שֶׁל מוֹעֵד. וַחֲכָמִים אוֹמְרִים: יוֹצְאִין מִסּוּכָּה לְסוּכָּה, וְעוֹשִׂין סוּכָּה בְּחוּלּוֹ שֶׁל מוֹעֵד. וְשָׁוִין, שֶׁאִם נָפְלָה, שֶׁחוֹזֵר וּבוֹנָהּ בְּחוּלּוֹ שֶׁל מוֹעֵד.
human_translation: One not depart from sukka to sukka ; And one not establish a sukka during the intermediate days of the Festival And the Rabbis say: One depart from sukka to sukka , and one establish a sukka on the intermediate days of the Festival. And they agree that if collapsed, he rebuild it during the intermediate days of the Festival.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: One does not go out from sukkah to sukkah, and one does not make a sukkah on a festival eve. And the sages say: One goes out from sukkah to sukkah, and one makes a sukkah on a festival eve. And they are equal, for if it fell, one may go back and rebuild it on a festival eve.

hebrew_text: מַאי טַעְמָא דְּרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר? אָמַר קְרָא: ״חַג הַסּוּכּוֹת תַּעֲשֶׂה לְךָ שִׁבְעַת יָמִים״, עֲשֵׂה סוּכָּה הָרְאוּיָה לְשִׁבְעָה. וְרַבָּנַן? הָכִי קָאָמַר רַחֲמָנָא: עֲשֵׂה סוּכָּה בֶּחָג.
human_translation: What is the rationale of Rabbi Eliezer the verse says: “You shall prepare for yourself the festival of Sukkot for seven days” Establish a sukka that is suitable for seven And the Rabbis this Merciful One is saying: establish a sukka during the Festival.
llm_translation: What is the reason for Rabbi Eliezer? The verse says: "You shall make the Feast of Booths for yourself seven days," make a sukkah suitable for seven. And the Rabbis? This is what the Merciful One says: Make a sukkah on the festival.

hebrew_text: וְשָׁוִין שֶׁאִם נָפְלָה, שֶׁחוֹזֵר וּבוֹנֶה אוֹתָהּ בְּחוּלּוֹ שֶׁל מוֹעֵד. פְּשִׁיטָא? מַהוּ דְּתֵימָא הַאי אַחֲרִיתִי הִיא וְאֵינָהּ לְשִׁבְעָה, קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן.
human_translation: And they agree that if collapsed, he may rebuild it during the intermediate days of the Festival. obvious; Lest you say this is a different one and is not seven teaches us
llm_translation: And equal that if fell, that he returns and builds it in the secular of the festival. Obviously? What might you say, that it is final and not for seven, it implies to us.

hebrew_text: תַּנְיָא רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר אוֹמֵר: כְּשֵׁם שֶׁאֵין אָדָם יוֹצֵא יְדֵי חוֹבָתוֹ בַּיּוֹם טוֹב הָרִאשׁוֹן שֶׁל חַג בְּלוּלָבוֹ שֶׁל חֲבֵירוֹ, דִּכְתִיב: ״וּלְקַחְתֶּם לָכֶם בַּיּוֹם הָרִאשׁוֹן פְּרִי עֵץ הָדָר כַּפּוֹת תְּמָרִים״ — מִשֶּׁלָּכֶם, כָּךְ אֵין אָדָם יוֹצֵא יְדֵי חוֹבָתוֹ בְּסוּכָּתוֹ שֶׁל חֲבֵירוֹ, דִּכְתִיב: ״חַג הַסּוּכּוֹת תַּעֲשֶׂה לְךָ שִׁבְעַת יָמִים״ — מִשֶּׁלְּךָ.
human_translation: It is taught Rabbi Eliezer says: Just as a person does not fulfill his obligation on the first day of the Festival with the lulav of another, as it is written: “And you shall take for yourselves on the first day the fruit of a beautiful tree, branches of a date palm” from your own so too, a person does not fulfill his obligation with the sukka of another, as it is written: “You shall prepare for yourself the festival of Sukkot for seven days” from your own.
llm_translation: It was taught: Rabbi Eliezer says: Just as a person does not fulfill his obligation on the first day of the festival with the lulav of his fellow, as it is written: "And you shall take for yourselves on the first day the fruit of a beautiful tree, palm branches" — from yours, so too, a person does not fulfill his obligation in his fellow's sukkah, as it is written: "You shall make the festival of Sukkot for yourself seven days" — from yours.

hebrew_text: וַחֲכָמִים אוֹמְרִים: אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁאָמְרוּ אֵין אָדָם יוֹצֵא יְדֵי חוֹבָתוֹ בְּיוֹם טוֹב הָרִאשׁוֹן בְּלוּלָבוֹ שֶׁל חֲבֵירוֹ, אֲבָל יוֹצֵא יְדֵי חוֹבָתוֹ בְּסוּכָּתוֹ שֶׁל חֲבֵירוֹ, דִּכְתִיב: ״כׇּל הָאֶזְרָח בְּיִשְׂרָאֵל יֵשְׁבוּ בַּסּוּכּוֹת״, מְלַמֵּד שֶׁכׇּל יִשְׂרָאֵל רְאוּיִם לֵישֵׁב בְּסוּכָּה אַחַת.
human_translation: And the Rabbis say: Although they said a person does not fulfill his obligation on the first day of the Festival with the lulav of another, he fulfills his obligation with the sukka of another, as it is written: “All the homeborn in Israel shall reside in sukkot ” teaches that all of the Jewish people are fit to reside in one sukka .
llm_translation: The sages say: Even though they said, "A person does not fulfill his obligation on the first day of Sukkot with the lulav of his fellow," he does fulfill his obligation on the first day of Sukkot with the sukkah of his fellow, as it is written: "All citizens of Israel shall dwell in sukkot," teaching that all of Israel are fit to dwell in one sukkah.

hebrew_text: וְרַבָּנַן, הַאי ״לְךָ״, מַאי דָּרְשִׁי בֵּיהּ? מִיבְּעֵי לֵיהּ לְמַעוֹטֵי גְּזוּלָה, אֲבָל שְׁאוּלָה כְּתִיב: ״כׇּל הָאֶזְרָח״.
human_translation: And the Rabbis, what do they derive from this “for yourself”? They require to exclude a stolen However, a borrowed it is written: “All the homeborn,”
llm_translation: The sages, this "to you," what did they interpret in it? They needed it to exclude robbery, but regarding a loan it is written: "Every citizen."

hebrew_text: וְרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר, הַאי ״כׇּל הָאֶזְרָח״ מַאי עָבֵיד לֵיהּ? מִיבְּעֵי לֵיהּ לְגֵר שֶׁנִּתְגַּיֵּיר בֵּינְתַיִם וְקָטָן שֶׁנִּתְגַּדֵּל בֵּינְתַיִם. וְרַבָּנַן? כֵּיוָן שֶׁאָמְרוּ: עוֹשִׂין סוּכָּה בְּחוּלּוֹ שֶׁל מוֹעֵד, לָא אִצְטְרִיךְ קְרָא.
human_translation: And Rabbi Eliezer, what does he do with this “All the homeborn”? He requires to a convert who converted in the interim, and a minor who reached majority in the interim, And the Rabbis, Once said one establish a sukka during the intermediate days of the Festival, verse not necessary
llm_translation: Rabbi Eliezer, this "every citizen," what does he do with it? He requires it for a convert who converted in the interim and a minor who grew up in the interim. And the Rabbis? Since they said: One may make a sukkah on Chol HaMoed, there is no need for a verse.

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: מַעֲשֶׂה בְּרַבִּי אִלְעַאי שֶׁהָלַךְ לְהַקְבִּיל פְּנֵי רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר רַבּוֹ בְּלוֹד בָּרֶגֶל. אָמַר לוֹ: אִלְעַאי! אֵינְךָ מִשּׁוֹבְתֵי הָרֶגֶל. שֶׁהָיָה רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר אוֹמֵר: מְשַׁבֵּחַ אֲנִי אֶת הָעַצְלָנִין, שֶׁאֵין יוֹצְאִין מִבָּתֵּיהֶן בָּרֶגֶל, דִּכְתִיב: ״וְשָׂמַחְתָּ אַתָּה וּבֵיתֶךָ״.
human_translation: The Sages taught: an incident involving Rabbi Elai, who went to greet his teacher Rabbi Eliezer in Lod on the Festival. He said to him: Elai, you are not among stay on the Festival as Rabbi Eliezer would say: I praise the lazy, who, do not leave their houses on the Festival, as it is written: “You shall rejoice, you and your household”
llm_translation: The Rabbis taught: There was an incident involving Rabbi Elai who went to greet his teacher Rabbi Eliezer, his master, in Lod on foot. He said to him: Elai! You are not from the inhabitants of Lod. For Rabbi Eliezer used to say: I praise the lazy, who do not leave their homes on foot, as it is written: "And you shall rejoice, you and your household."

hebrew_text: אִינִי?! וְהָאָמַר רַבִּי יִצְחָק: מִנַּיִין שֶׁחַיָּיב לְהַקְבִּיל פְּנֵי רַבּוֹ בָּרֶגֶל, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״מַדּוּעַ אַתְּ הוֹלֶכֶת אֵלָיו הַיּוֹם לֹא חֹדֶשׁ וְלֹא שַׁבָּת״, מִכְּלָל דִּבְחֹדֶשׁ וְשַׁבָּת מִיחַיַּיב אִינִישׁ לְאַקְבּוֹלֵי אַפֵּי רַבֵּיהּ! לָא קַשְׁיָא: הָא — דְּאָזֵיל וְאָתֵי בְּיוֹמֵיהּ, הָא — דְּאָזֵיל וְלָא אָתֵי בְּיוֹמֵיהּ.
human_translation: Is that so? Didn’t Rabbi Yitzḥak say: From where that is obligated to greet his teacher on the Festival? as it is stated “Why are you going to him today? It is neither the New Moon nor Shabbat” by inference that on the New Moon and Shabbat a person is obligated to greet his teacher. not difficult: This where he goes and returns on day and this where he goes and does not return on day
llm_translation: I?! And didn't Rabbi Yitzchak say: From where do we derive that one must greet his teacher by foot, as it is stated: "Why are you going to him today? It is neither a new moon nor a Sabbath." From the fact that new moon and Sabbath are mentioned, one might think that one is obligated to greet his teacher even if he is coming from a far distance! It is not difficult: this one — who goes and comes on his days, this one — who goes and does not come on his days.

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: מַעֲשֶׂה בְּרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר שֶׁשָּׁבַת בַּגָּלִיל הָעֶלְיוֹן בְּסוּכָּתוֹ שֶׁל יוֹחָנָן בְּרַבִּי אִלְעַאי בְּקֵיסָרִי, וְאָמְרִי לַהּ בְּקֵיסָרְיוֹן, וְהִגִּיעַ חַמָּה לַסּוּכָּה. אָמַר לוֹ: מַהוּ שֶׁאֶפְרוֹשׂ עָלֶיהָ סָדִין? אָמַר לוֹ: אֵין לְךָ כׇּל שֵׁבֶט וְשֵׁבֶט מִיִּשְׂרָאֵל שֶׁלֹּא הֶעֱמִיד מִמֶּנּוּ שׁוֹפֵט.
human_translation: The Sages taught: an incident Rabbi Eliezer, who stayed in the Upper Galilee in the sukka of Yoḥanan, son of Rabbi Elai, in Caesarea; and some say that in Caesarion. And sun reached of the sukka , said to him: What is I spread a sheet over said to him: There is no tribe of Israel from which a judge did not emerge.
llm_translation: The sages taught: There was an incident involving Rabbi Eliezer who spent the Sabbath in the Upper Galilee in the sukkah of Yochanan son of Ilai in Caesarea, and some say in his own sukkah in Caesarea. And the sun reached the sukkah. He said to him: What is the reason that you did not spread a sheet over it? He said to him: Is there any tribe or court of Israel that did not appoint a judge from it?

hebrew_text: הִגִּיעַ חַמָּה לַחֲצִי הַסּוּכָּה, אָמַר לוֹ: מַהוּ שֶׁאֶפְרוֹשׂ עָלֶיהָ סָדִין? אָמַר לוֹ: אֵין לְךָ כׇּל שֵׁבֶט וְשֵׁבֶט מִיִּשְׂרָאֵל שֶׁלֹּא יָצְאוּ מִמֶּנּוּ נְבִיאִים. שֵׁבֶט יְהוּדָה וּבִנְיָמִין הֶעֱמִידוּ מְלָכִים עַל פִּי נְבִיאִים. הִגִּיעַ חַמָּה לְמַרְגְּלוֹתָיו שֶׁל רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר, נָטַל יוֹחָנָן סָדִין וּפֵירַשׂ עָלֶיהָ, הִפְשִׁיל רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר טַלִּיתוֹ לַאֲחוֹרָיו וְיָצָא. לֹא מִפְּנֵי שֶׁהִפְלִיגוֹ בִּדְבָרִים, אֶלָּא מִפְּנֵי שֶׁלֹּא אָמַר דָּבָר שֶׁלֹּא שָׁמַע מִפִּי רַבּוֹ לְעוֹלָם.
human_translation: sun reached midpoint of the sukka . said to him: What is I spread a sheet over it? said to him: There is no tribe of Israel from which prophets did not emerge. the tribes of Judah and Benjamin they established kings according to prophets, sun reached the feet of Rabbi Eliezer. Yoḥanan took a sheet and spread it over Rabbi Eliezer slung his cloak behind him and emerged not because he was to diverting his with words, but because never said a matter that he did not hear from his teacher.
llm_translation: The sun reached the midpoint of the sukkah, he said to him: What is the explanation of spreading a sheet over it? He said to him: You do not have a tribe of Israel from which prophets did not emerge. The tribe of Judah and Benjamin established kings according to the words of the prophets. The sun reached the feet of Rabbi Eliezer's sandals, Yochanan took a sheet and spread it over them, Rabbi Eliezer turned his cloak behind him and left. Not because they disagreed in words, but because he never said anything he did not hear from his teacher.

hebrew_text: הֵיכִי עָבֵיד הָכִי? וְהָאָמַר רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר: אֵין יוֹצְאִין מִסּוּכָּה לְסוּכָּה! רֶגֶל אַחֵר הֲוַאי.
human_translation: How did do so? Didn’t Rabbi Eliezer say: One may not depart from sukka to sukka ? was a different Festival
llm_translation: "How does he do this? But didn't Rabbi Eliezer say: One may not go out from one booth to another! It is considered a different domain."

hebrew_text: וְהָאָמַר רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר: מְשַׁבֵּחַ אֲנִי אֶת הָעַצְלָנִין שֶׁאֵין יוֹצְאִין מִבָּתֵּיהֶן בָּרֶגֶל! שַׁבָּת הֲוַאי.
human_translation: But didn’t Rabbi Eliezer say: I praise the lazy, who do not leave their houses on the Festival? It was Shabbat,
llm_translation: And he said, Rabbi Eliezer: I praise the lazy ones, for they do not go out from their homes by foot! Shabbat is coming.

hebrew_text: וְתִיפְשׁוֹט לֵיהּ מִדִּידֵיהּ דִּתְנַן: פְּקַק הַחַלּוֹן, רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר אוֹמֵר: בִּזְמַן שֶׁקָּשׁוּר וְתָלוּי — פּוֹקְקִין בּוֹ, וְאִם לָאו — אֵין פּוֹקְקִין בּוֹ. וַחֲכָמִים אוֹמְרִים: בֵּין כָּךְ וּבֵין כָּךְ פּוֹקְקִין.
human_translation: resolve from his own as we learned a window shutter Rabbi Eliezer says: When it is tied and hanging one may shutter with it, and if not, one may not shutter with it. And the Rabbis say: Both this and that one may shutter with it.
llm_translation: And it shall be removed from its place, as we learned in a Mishnah: If the window is blocked, Rabbi Eliezer says: When it is tied and hanging - we may unblock it, but if not - we may not unblock it. And the Sages say: In either case we may unblock it.

hebrew_text: הָתָם הוּא דִּמְבַטֵּל, אֲבָל הָכָא דְּלָא מְבַטֵּל — לָא.
human_translation: There, where he negates However, here, where he does not negate no,
llm_translation: There, he who nullifies, but here, where not nullifying — no.

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: מַעֲשֶׂה בְּרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר שֶׁשָּׁבַת בַּגָּלִיל הָעֶלְיוֹן, וּשְׁאָלוּהוּ שְׁלֹשִׁים הֲלָכוֹת בְּהִלְכוֹת סוּכָּה, שְׁתֵּים עֶשְׂרֵה אָמַר לָהֶם: שָׁמַעְתִּי, שְׁמוֹנֶה עֶשְׂרֵה אָמַר לָהֶם: לֹא שָׁמַעְתִּי. רַבִּי יוֹסֵי בְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר, חִילּוּף הַדְּבָרִים: שְׁמוֹנֶה עֶשְׂרֵה אָמַר לָהֶם: שָׁמַעְתִּי, שְׁתֵּים עֶשְׂרֵה אָמַר לָהֶם: לֹא שָׁמַעְתִּי.
human_translation: The Sages taught: an incident involving Rabbi Eliezer, who stayed in the Upper Galilee, and asked him thirty halakhot in the halakhot of sukka . twelve, he said to them: I heard eighteen, he said to them: I did not hear Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, says: the reverse of these matters. eighteen he said to them: I heard twelve he said to them: I did not hear
llm_translation: The Rabbis taught: There was an incident involving Rabbi Eliezer who was staying in the Upper Galilee, and they asked him thirty laws regarding the laws of the sukkah. He responded to twelve of them: "I have heard," and to eighteen of them he responded: "I have not heard." Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, says, a reversal of the matter: to eighteen of them he responded: "I have heard," and to twelve of them he responded: "I have not heard."

hebrew_text: אָמְרוּ לוֹ: כׇּל דְּבָרֶיךָ אֵינָן אֶלָּא מִפִּי הַשְּׁמוּעָה! אָמַר לָהֶם: הִזְקַקְתּוּנִי לוֹמַר דָּבָר שֶׁלֹּא שָׁמַעְתִּי מִפִּי רַבּוֹתַי. מִיָּמַי לֹא קְדָמַנִי אָדָם בְּבֵית הַמִּדְרָשׁ, וְלֹא יָשַׁנְתִּי בְּבֵית הַמִּדְרָשׁ לֹא שֵׁינַת קֶבַע וְלֹא שֵׁינַת עֲרַאי, וְלֹא הִנַּחְתִּי אָדָם בְּבֵית הַמִּדְרָשׁ וְיָצָאתִי, וְלֹא שַׂחְתִּי שִׂיחַת חוּלִּין, וְלֹא אָמַרְתִּי דָּבָר שֶׁלֹּא שָׁמַעְתִּי מִפִּי רַבִּי מֵעוֹלָם.
human_translation: They said to him: Are all the matters you only from what heard? He said to them: you forced me to say a matter that I did not hear from my teachers, In my days, no person ever preceded me into the study hall, and I never slept in the study hall, neither substantial sleep nor a brief nap; and I never left anyone in the study hall and exited, and I never engaged in idle conversation; and I never said anything that I did not hear from my teacher.
llm_translation: They said to him: "All your words are nothing but from hearsay!" He said to them: "You have compelled me to say something that I have not heard from my teachers. Never has a person preceded me in the study hall, and I have never slept in the study hall, neither a permanent sleep nor a temporary one, and I have never left a person in the study hall and departed, and I have never engaged in idle chatter, and I have never said something that I have not heard from my teacher ever."

hebrew_text: אָמְרוּ עָלָיו עַל רַבָּן יוֹחָנָן בֶּן זַכַּאי: מִיָּמָיו לֹא שָׂח שִׂיחַת חוּלִּין, וְלֹא הָלַךְ אַרְבַּע אַמּוֹת בְּלָא תּוֹרָה וּבְלֹא תְּפִילִּין, וְלֹא קְדָמוֹ אָדָם בְּבֵית הַמִּדְרָשׁ, וְלֹא יָשַׁן בְּבֵית הַמִּדְרָשׁ לֹא שֵׁינַת קֶבַע וְלֹא שֵׁינַת עֲרַאי, וְלֹא הִרְהֵר בִּמְבוֹאוֹת הַמְטוּנָּפוֹת, וְלֹא הִנִּיחַ אָדָם בְּבֵית הַמִּדְרָשׁ וְיָצָא, וְלֹא מְצָאוֹ אָדָם יוֹשֵׁב וְדוֹמֵם אֶלָּא יוֹשֵׁב וְשׁוֹנֶה, וְלֹא פָּתַח אָדָם דֶּלֶת לְתַלְמִידָיו, אֶלָּא הוּא בְּעַצְמוֹ, וְלֹא אָמַר דָּבָר שֶׁלֹּא שָׁמַע מִפִּי רַבּוֹ מֵעוֹלָם, וְלֹא אָמַר: הִגִּיעַ עֵת לַעֲמוֹד מִבֵּית הַמִּדְרָשׁ, חוּץ מֵעַרְבֵי פְסָחִים, וְעַרְבֵי יוֹם הַכִּפּוּרִים. וְכֵן הָיָה רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר תַּלְמִידוֹ נוֹהֵג אַחֲרָיו.
human_translation: said about Rabban Yoḥanan ben Zakkai, In his days he never engaged in idle conversation; and he never walked four cubits without Torah and without phylacteries; and no person ever preceded him into the study hall; and he never slept in the study hall, neither substantial sleep nor a brief nap; and he never contemplated in alleyways filthy and he never left anyone in the study hall and exited; and no person ever found him sitting and silent, rather, he sitting and studying; and only he opened the door for his students, and he never said anything that he did not hear from his teacher; and he never said the time has arrived to arise the study hall except on Passover eves, Yom Kippur eves, And Rabbi Eliezer, his student, accustomed after his
llm_translation: They said about Rabban Yochanan ben Zakkai: From his days he did not engage in idle chatter, and he did not walk four cubits without Torah and without Tefillin, and no one preceded him in the Beit Midrash, and he did not sleep in the Beit Midrash, neither a deep sleep nor a light sleep, and he did not ponder in the entrances of brothels, and he did not leave a person in the Beit Midrash and depart, and he did not find a person sitting and silent, but sitting and learning, and he did not open the door for his students, but he himself, and he did not say anything that he did not hear from his teacher, ever, and he did not say: "It is time to leave the Beit Midrash," except on the eve of Passover and the eve of Yom Kippur. And so too Rabbi Eliezer, his student, followed after him.

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: שְׁמוֹנִים תַּלְמִידִים הָיוּ לוֹ לְהִלֵּל הַזָּקֵן. שְׁלֹשִׁים מֵהֶן רְאוּיִם שֶׁתִּשְׁרֶה עֲלֵיהֶן שְׁכִינָה כְּמֹשֶׁה רַבֵּינוּ, וּשְׁלֹשִׁים מֵהֶן רְאוּיִם שֶׁתַּעֲמוֹד לָהֶם חַמָּה כִּיהוֹשֻׁעַ בִּן נוּן. עֶשְׂרִים בֵּינוֹנִים. גָּדוֹל שֶׁבְּכוּלָּן — יוֹנָתָן בֶּן עוּזִּיאֵל, קָטָן שֶׁבְּכוּלָּן — רַבָּן יוֹחָנָן בֶּן זַכַּאי.
human_translation: The Sages taught: Hillel the Elder had eighty students. Thirty of them worthy that the Divine Presence rest upon them as Moses our teacher, and thirty of them worthy that the sun stand still for them as Joshua bin Nun, and twenty intermediate The greatest of all Yonatan ben Uzziel, and the youngest of them Rabban Yoḥanan ben Zakkai.
llm_translation: The Rabbis taught: Hillel the Elder had eighty disciples. Thirty of them were worthy that the Divine Presence should rest upon them like it did upon Moses our teacher, and thirty of them were worthy that the sun should stand still for them like it did for Joshua son of Nun. Twenty of them were in between. The greatest of them all was Yonatan ben Uzziel, and the least of them all was Rabban Yochanan ben Zakkai.

hebrew_text: אָמְרוּ עָלָיו עַל רַבָּן יוֹחָנָן בֶּן זַכַּאי שֶׁלֹּא הִנִּיחַ מִקְרָא וּמִשְׁנָה, גְּמָרָא הֲלָכוֹת וְאַגָּדוֹת; דִּקְדּוּקֵי תוֹרָה וְדִקְִדּוּקֵי סוֹפְרִים; קַלִּים וַחֲמוּרִים וּגְזֵרוֹת שָׁווֹת; תְּקוּפוֹת וְגִימַטְרִיָּאוֹת; שִׂיחַת מַלְאֲכֵי הַשָּׁרֵת וְשִׂיחַת שֵׁדִים וְשִׂיחַת דְּקָלִים; מִשְׁלוֹת כּוֹבְסִין, מִשְׁלוֹת שׁוּעָלִים; דָּבָר גָּדוֹל וְדָבָר קָטָן.
human_translation: said about Rabban Yoḥanan ben Zakkai he did not neglect Bible; Mishna; Gemara; halakhot and aggadot ; minutiae of the Torah and minutiae of the scribes; a fortiori inferences and verbal analogies; seasons; numerology [ gimmatreyaot ]. the conversation of ministering angels; the conversation of demons, and the conversation of palm trees; parables of launderers, parables of foxes; a great matter and a small matter.
llm_translation: They said about Rabban Yohanan ben Zakkai that he did not leave out study of Scripture and Mishnah, Gemara, Halakhot, and Aggadot; the nuances of Torah and the nuances of the Scribes; lenient rulings and stringent rulings and equal decrees; seasons and numerology; conversation of ministering angels and conversation of demons and conversation of palm trees; parables of launderers, parables of foxes; a great matter and a small matter.

hebrew_text: דָּבָר גָּדוֹל — מַעֲשֵׂה מֶרְכָּבָה. דָּבָר קָטָן — הֲוָיוֹת דְּאַבָּיֵי וְרָבָא. לְקַיֵּים מַה שֶּׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״לְהַנְחִיל אוֹהֲבַי יֵשׁ וְאוֹצְרוֹתֵיהֶם אֲמַלֵּא״. וְכִי מֵאַחַר שֶׁקָּטָן שֶׁבְּכוּלָּן כָּךְ, גָּדוֹל שֶׁבְּכוּלָּן עַל אַחַת כַּמָּה וְכַמָּה. אָמְרוּ עָלָיו עַל יוֹנָתָן בֶּן עוּזִּיאֵל, בְּשָׁעָה שֶׁיּוֹשֵׁב וְעוֹסֵק בַּתּוֹרָה — כׇּל עוֹף שֶׁפּוֹרֵחַ עָלָיו מִיָּד נִשְׂרָף.
human_translation: A great matter Design of the Chariot, A small matter the disputes of Abaye and Rava. to fulfill that which is stated: “That I may cause those that love me to inherit substance and that I may fill their treasuries” And if the youngest of them was so the greatest of them all the more so said of Yonatan ben Uzziel, that when he sat and was engaged in Torah any bird that flew over him was immediately incinerated.
llm_translation: A great matter — the work of the chariot. A small matter — the discussions of Abbaye and Rava. To fulfill what is said: "I will give to my lovers, and their treasures I will fill." And since the small among them are so, how much more so the great among them, all the more so. They said about Yonatan ben Uzziel, when he sits and engages in Torah study — any bird that flies over him immediately burns.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ מִי שֶׁהָיָה רֹאשׁוֹ וְרוּבּוֹ בַּסּוּכָּה וְשׁוּלְחָנוֹ בְּתוֹךְ הַבַּיִת — בֵּית שַׁמַּאי פּוֹסְלִין וּבֵית הִלֵּל מַכְשִׁירִין. אָמְרוּ לָהֶם בֵּית הִלֵּל לְבֵית שַׁמַּאי: לֹא כָּךְ הָיָה מַעֲשֶׂה שֶׁהָלְכוּ זִקְנֵי בֵּית שַׁמַּאי וְזִקְנֵי בֵּית הִלֵּל לְבַקֵּר אֶת רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן בֶּן הַחוֹרָנִית, וּמְצָאוּהוּ שֶׁהָיָה יוֹשֵׁב רֹאשׁוֹ וְרוּבּוֹ בַּסּוּכָּה וְשׁוּלְחָנוֹ בְּתוֹךְ הַבַּיִת, וְלֹא אָמְרוּ לוֹ דָּבָר. אָמְרוּ לָהֶם בֵּית שַׁמַּאי: מִשָּׁם רְאָיָה?! אַף הֵם אָמְרוּ לוֹ: אִם כֵּן הָיִיתָ נוֹהֵג, לֹא קִיַּימְתָּ מִצְוַת סוּכָּה מִיָּמֶיךָ.
human_translation: one whose head and most of his were in the sukka and his table was in the house, Beit Shammai deem it unfit, and Beit Hillel deem it fit. Beit Hillel said to Beit Shammai: wasn’t there an incident where the Elders of Beit Shammai and the Elders of Beit Hillel went to visit Rabbi Yoḥanan ben HaḤoranit and they found him that he was sitting with his head and most of his in the sukka and his table in the house, and they said nothing to him? Beit Shammai said to them: proof from there? they said to him: If you were accustomed this you have never fulfilled the mitzva of sukka in your life.
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: One whose head and most of his body were inside the sukkah, while his table was inside the house— Beit Shammai deem it invalid, and Beit Hillel deem it valid. Beit Hillel said to Beit Shammai: This was not the practice when the elders of Beit Shammai and the elders of Beit Hillel went to visit Rabbi Yochanan ben HaChoranit. They found him sitting with his head and most of his body inside the sukkah, while his table was inside the house, and they did not say anything to him. Beit Shammai said to them: Is this a proof?! They also said to him: If this is how you conduct yourself, you have not fulfilled the mitzvah of sukkah in your lifetime.

hebrew_text: נָשִׁים וַעֲבָדִים וּקְטַנִּים פְּטוּרִין מִן הַסּוּכָּה. קָטָן שֶׁאֵינוֹ צָרִיךְ לְאִמּוֹ — חַיָּיב בְּסוּכָּה. מַעֲשֶׂה וְיָלְדָה כַּלָּתוֹ שֶׁל שַׁמַּאי הַזָּקֵן, וּפִיחֵת אֶת הַמַּעֲזִיבָה וְסִיכֵּךְ עַל גַּבֵּי הַמִּטָּה בִּשְׁבִיל קָטָן.
human_translation: Women, slaves, and minors are exempt from the sukka . A minor who does not need his mother is obligated an incident where the daughter-in-law of Shammai the Elder gave birth removed the plaster and roofed over the bed for the minor.
llm_translation: Women, slaves, and minors are exempt from the obligation of dwelling in the sukkah. A minor who does not need his mother - is obligated in the sukkah. It once happened that the daughter-in-law of Shammai the Elder gave birth, and she blew out the lamp and covered the cradle with a sheet for the sake of the minor.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ מְנָא הָנֵי מִילֵּי? דְּתָנוּ רַבָּנַן: ״אֶזְרָח״ — זֶה אֶזְרָח, ״הָאֶזְרָח״ — לְהוֹצִיא אֶת הַנָּשִׁים, ״כׇּל״ — לְרַבּוֹת אֶת הַקְּטַנִּים.
human_translation: From where are these matters as the Sages taught Homeborn, that homeborn “The homeborn,” to the exclusion of the women. “All to include the minors
llm_translation: Gemara: What do these words mean? The Rabbis taught: "Ezrach" - this refers to a citizen, "Ha'ezrach" - to exclude women, "Kol" - to include minors.

hebrew_text: אָמַר מָר: ״הָאֶזְרָח״ — לְהוֹצִיא אֶת הַנָּשִׁים. לְמֵימְרָא דְּ״אֶזְרָח״, בֵּין נָשִׁים בֵּין גַּבְרֵי מַשְׁמַע? וְהָתַנְיָא: ״הָאֶזְרָח״ — לְרַבּוֹת אֶת הַנָּשִׁים הָאֶזְרָחִיּוֹת, שֶׁחַיָּיבוֹת בְּעִינּוּי. אַלְמָא ״אֶזְרָח״ — גַּבְרֵי מַשְׁמַע! אָמַר רַבָּה: הִלְכְתָא נִינְהוּ וְאַסְמְכִינְהוּ רַבָּנַן אַקְּרָאֵי.
human_translation: The Master said: “The homeborn” to the exclusion of women. Is that to say that homeborn indicates both men and women? Isn’t it taught “the homeborn” to include homeborn women, who are obligated in affliction apparently, indicates men. Rabba said: They are halakha and the Sages supported them with verses
llm_translation: Master said: "The citizen" — to exclude women. Does it mean to say that by "citizen," it includes both women and men? But it was taught: "The citizen" — to include citizen women, who are obligated in the mitzvah. It is evident that "citizen" refers to men! Rabbah said: This is a tradition, and the Rabbis support it with a verse.

hebrew_text: הֵי קְרָא וְהֵי הִלְכְתָא? וְתוּ: קְרָא לְמָה לִי, הִלְכְתָא לְמָה לִי? הָא סוּכָּה מִצְוַת עֲשֵׂה שֶׁהַזְּמַן גְּרָמָא, וְכׇל מִצְוַת עֲשֵׂה שֶׁהַזְּמַן גְּרָמָא נָשִׁים פְּטוּרוֹת.
human_translation: Which is the verse and which is a halakha And furthermore, why do I the verse and why do I the halakha ? Isn’t sukka a positive, time-bound mitzva, and women are exempt from all positive, time-bound mitzvot?
llm_translation: Be a verse and be a halakha? And come and learn: Why do I need a verse, why do I need a halakha? For a sukkah is a positive commandment dependent on time, and all positive commandments dependent on time, women are exempt.

hebrew_text: יוֹם הַכִּפּוּרִים, מִדְּרַב יְהוּדָה אָמַר רַב נָפְקָא. דְּאָמַר רַב יְהוּדָה אָמַר רַב, וְכֵן תָּנָא דְּבֵי רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל אָמַר קְרָא: ״אִישׁ אוֹ אִשָּׁה״,
human_translation: Yom Kippur, derived from which Rav Yehuda Rav said, as Rav Yehuda said Rav said, and it was likewise taught in the school of Rabbi Yishmael: The verse says: a man or woman
llm_translation: Day of Atonement, from Rav Yehudah said Rav Nafka. For Rav Yehudah said Rav, and so too it was taught in the school of Rabbi Yishmael, as the verse states: "A man or a woman,"

hebrew_text: הִשְׁוָה הַכָּתוּב אִשָּׁה לְאִישׁ לְכׇל עוֹנָשִׁין שֶׁבַּתּוֹרָה. אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: לְעוֹלָם סוּכָּה הִלְכְתָא, וְאִיצְטְרִיךְ. סָלְקָא דַּעְתָּךְ אָמֵינָא ״תֵּשְׁבוּ״ — כְּעֵין תָּדוּרוּ, מָה דִּירָה — אִישׁ וְאִשְׁתּוֹ, אַף סוּכָּה — אִישׁ וְאִשְׁתּוֹ, קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן.
human_translation: The verse equated a woman to a man to all punishments in the Torah. Abaye said: Actually, sukka is a halakha was necessary it might enter your mind to say: “Shall you reside” as you dwell; just as dwelling man and his wife, so too, sukka a man and his wife. it teaches us
llm_translation: Comparison the written woman to man to all punishments in the Torah. Said Abbaye: Always Sukkah halakha, and necessary. As your mind I say "you shall dwell" — like his dwelling, just as a house — a man and his wife, so too Sukkah — a man and his wife, it teaches us.

hebrew_text: רָבָא אָמַר: אִיצְטְרִיךְ, סָלְקָא דַּעְתָּךְ אָמֵינָא יָלֵיף ״חֲמִשָּׁה עָשָׂר״ ״חֲמִשָּׁה עָשָׂר״ מֵחַג הַמַּצּוֹת. מָה לְהַלָּן — נָשִׁים חַיָּיבוֹת, אַף כָּאן — נָשִׁים חַיָּיבוֹת. קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן.
human_translation: Rava said was necessary it might enter your mind to say: Derive fifteenth from fifteenth festival of matzot ” Just as there, women are obligated so too here, women are obligated. teaches us
llm_translation: Rava said: It is necessary, as your mind may think, that "fifteen" "fifteen" from the Festival of Matzot. Just as there - women are obligated, so too here - women are obligated. It is heard for us.

hebrew_text: וְהַשְׁתָּא דְּאָמְרַתְּ סוּכָּה הִלְכְתָא, קָרָא לְמָה לִי? לְרַבּוֹת אֶת הַגֵּרִים. סָלְקָא דַּעְתָּךְ אָמֵינָא: ״הָאֶזְרָח בְּיִשְׂרָאֵל״ אָמַר רַחֲמָנָא — וְלֹא אֶת הַגֵּרִים, קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן.
human_translation: And now that you said halakha why do I verse to include converts, it might enter your mind to say the Merciful One says: “The homeborn in Israel,” and not the converts. teaches us
llm_translation: The matter that you said, "Sukkah is a halakha," why did he call it? To include the converts. Is it your opinion that I would say: "The native-born in Israel," the Merciful One said - and not the converts, this is what he is teaching us.

hebrew_text: יוֹם הַכִּפּוּרִים מִדְּרַב יְהוּדָה אָמַר רַב נָפְקָא. לֹא נִצְרְכָא אֶלָּא לְתוֹסֶפֶת עִינּוּי. סָלְקָא דַּעְתָּךְ אָמֵינָא: הוֹאִיל וּמִיעֵט רַחֲמָנָא לְתוֹסֶפֶת עִינּוּי מֵעוֹנֶשׁ וּמֵאַזְהָרָה, לֹא נִתְחַיְּיבוּ נָשִׁים כְּלָל, קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן.
human_translation: Yom Kippur is derived from that Rav Yehuda Rav said. was needed only to extension of affliction it might enter your mind to say: Since the Merciful One excludes the extension of affliction from punishment and prohibition, women should not be obligated at all. teaches us
llm_translation: Day of Atonement from Rav Yehudah said Rav Nafkha. Not needed except for additional affliction. Your mind may say: Since the Merciful One has somewhat diminished the additional affliction from punishment and warning, women are not obligated at all, this is what we hear.

hebrew_text: אָמַר מָר: ״כׇּל״ לְרַבּוֹת אֶת הַקְּטַנִּים. וְהָתְנַן: נָשִׁים וַעֲבָדִים וּקְטַנִּים פְּטוּרִין מִן הַסּוּכָּה! לָא קַשְׁיָא כָּאן — בְּקָטָן שֶׁהִגִּיעַ לְחִינּוּךְ, כָּאן — בְּקָטָן שֶׁלֹּא הִגִּיעַ לְחִינּוּךְ. קָטָן שֶׁהִגִּיעַ לְחִינּוּךְ מִדְּרַבָּנַן הוּא! מִדְּרַבָּנַן, וּקְרָא — אַסְמַכְתָּא בְּעָלְמָא הוּא.
human_translation: The Master said “All to include the minors Didn’t we learn Women and slaves and minors are exempt from the sukka ? not difficult. Here, a minor who reached training, Here, a minor did not reach training. a minor who reached training is by rabbinic law, by rabbinic law and the verse a mere support
llm_translation: Master said: "All" to include the young. And we learned: Women, slaves, and minors are exempt from the Sukkah! It is not difficult here - regarding a minor who has reached the age of education, here - regarding a minor who has not reached the age of education. A minor who has reached the age of education is from Rabbinic law! From Rabbinic law, and a verse - it is merely a support in general.

hebrew_text: קָטָן שֶׁאֵינוֹ צָרִיךְ לְאִמּוֹ כּוּ׳. הֵיכִי דָּמֵי קָטָן שֶׁאֵינוֹ צָרִיךְ לְאִמּוֹ? אָמְרִי דְּבֵי רַבִּי יַנַּאי: כֹּל שֶׁנִּפְנֶה וְאֵין אִמּוֹ מְקַנַּחְתּוֹ. רַבִּי (שִׁמְעוֹן) אוֹמֵר: כׇּל שֶׁנֵּעוֹר מִשְּׁנָתוֹ וְאֵינוֹ קוֹרֵא ״אִמָּא, [אִמָּא]!״ גְּדוֹלִים נָמֵי קָרוּ? אֶלָּא: (אֵימָא) כָּל שֶׁנֵּעוֹר וְאֵינוֹ קוֹרֵא: ״אִמָּא, אִמָּא!״.
human_translation: A minor who does not need his mother is obligated What are the circumstances a minor who does not need his mother? In the school of Rabbi Yannai they said: any who defecates and his mother does not wipe him. Rabbi Shimon says: any who awakens from his sleep and does not call: Mother, mother. Older also call Rather, say any who awakens and does not call: Mother, mother,
llm_translation: A minor who does not need his mother, how so? The school of Rabbi Yannai said: anyone who turns away and his mother does not rebuke him. Rabbi (Shimon) says: anyone who sleeps late and does not call out "Ima, Ima!" Are adults also included? Rather, (say): "Eima" anyone who sleeps late and does not call out "Ima, Ima!"

hebrew_text: מַעֲשֶׂה וְיָלְדָה כַּלָּתוֹ כּוּ׳. מַעֲשֶׂה לִסְתּוֹר? חַסּוֹרֵי מְחַסְּרָא וְהָכִי קָתָנֵי: וְשַׁמַּאי מַחְמִיר, וּמַעֲשֶׂה נָמֵי וְיָלְדָה כַּלָּתוֹ שֶׁל שַׁמַּאי הַזָּקֵן, וּפִחֵת אֶת הַמַּעֲזִיבָה וְסִיכֵּךְ עַל הַמִּטָּה בִּשְׁבִיל הַקָּטָן.
human_translation: an incident where the daughter-in-law of gave birth an incident to contradict incomplete, and it teaches the following: And Shammai is stringent and there was also an incident and the daughter-in-law of Shammai the Elder gave birth removed the plaster and roofed over the bed for the minor.
llm_translation: The incident occurred, and his daughter-in-law gave birth. Incident to conceal? Lacking, lacking, and thus it teaches: "Shammai was stringent, and the incident also occurred, and his daughter-in-law gave birth to the son of Shammai the Elder, and he diminished the cradle and placed it on the bed for the infant."

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ כׇּל שִׁבְעַת הַיָּמִים אָדָם עוֹשֶׂה סוּכָּתוֹ קֶבַע, וּבֵיתוֹ עֲרַאי. יָרְדוּ גְּשָׁמִים, מֵאֵימָתַי מוּתָּר לְפַנּוֹת — מִשֶּׁתִּסְרַח הַמִּקְפָּה. מָשְׁלוּ מָשָׁל לְמָה הַדָּבָר דּוֹמֶה — לְעֶבֶד שֶׁבָּא לִמְזוֹג כּוֹס לְרַבּוֹ, וְשָׁפַךְ לוֹ קִיתוֹן עַל פָּנָיו.
human_translation: All seven days a person renders his sukka permanent and his house temporary rain fell, from when is it permitted to vacate from that the congealed dish will spoil. told a parable: To what is this matter comparable? to a servant who comes to pour wine for his master, and he pours a jug [ kiton ] of water in his face
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: Throughout the seven days, a person makes his sukkah a permanent dwelling, while his house is considered temporary. When the rains come, from when is one permitted to turn the sukkah aside? From when the thatch sags. They gave a parable: To what is this matter similar? To a servant who came to pour a cup for his master, and spilled the pitcher on his face.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: כׇּל שִׁבְעַת הַיָּמִים אָדָם עוֹשֶׂה סוּכָּתוֹ קֶבַע וּבֵיתוֹ עֲרַאי, כֵּיצַד? הָיוּ לוֹ כֵּלִים נָאִים מַעֲלָן לַסּוּכָּה, מַצָּעוֹת נָאוֹת — מַעֲלָן לַסּוּכָּה, אוֹכֵל וְשׁוֹתֶה וּמְטַיֵּיל בַּסּוּכָּה. מְנָא הָנֵי מִילֵּי? דְּתָנוּ רַבָּנַן: ״תֵּשְׁבוּ״ — כְּעֵין תָּדוּרוּ, מִכָּאן אָמְרוּ: כׇּל שִׁבְעַת הַיָּמִים עוֹשֶׂה אָדָם סוּכָּתוֹ קֶבַע וּבֵיתוֹ עֲרַאי. כֵּיצַד? הָיוּ לוֹ כֵּלִים נָאִים — מַעֲלָן לַסּוּכָּה, מַצָּעוֹת נָאוֹת — מַעֲלָן לַסּוּכָּה, אוֹכֵל וְשׁוֹתֶה וּמְטַיֵּיל בַּסּוּכָּה וּמְשַׁנֵּן בַּסּוּכָּה.
human_translation: The Sages taught: All seven days a person renders his sukka permanent and his house temporary How so? If he has beautiful vessels, he takes them up to the sukka , If he has beautiful bedding, he takes it up to the sukka . He eats and drinks and relaxes in the sukka . From where are these matters as the Sages taught: shall you reside” ( as you dwell From here they said: All seven days, a person renders his sukka permanent and his house temporary How so? If he has beautiful vessels, he takes them up to the sukka ; beautiful bedding, he takes it up to the sukka ; he eats and drinks and relaxes in the sukka and studies in the sukka .
llm_translation: The Sages taught: Throughout the seven days, a person makes his sukkah a permanent dwelling and his house temporary. How so? If he had nice vessels, he brings them up to the sukkah; nice cushions - he brings them up to the sukkah; he eats, drinks, and spends time in the sukkah. How do we know these matters? For the Sages taught: "You shall dwell" - in a manner of your regular dwelling. From here they said: Throughout the seven days, a person makes his sukkah a permanent dwelling and his house temporary. How so? If he had nice vessels - he brings them up to the sukkah; nice cushions - he brings them up to the sukkah; he eats, drinks, spends time in the sukkah, and sleeps in the sukkah.

hebrew_text: אִינִי?! וְהָאָמַר רָבָא: מִקְרָא וּמִתְנֵא בִּמְטַלַּלְתָּא, וְתַנּוֹיֵי בַּר מִמְּטַלַּלְתָּא! לָא קַשְׁיָא: הָא — בְּמִגְרַס, הָא — בְּעַיּוֹנֵי.
human_translation: Is that so? Didn’t Rava say: Studying Bible and studying Mishna in the sukka ; analyzing outside the sukka . not difficult. This with regard to extensive study, That with regard to intensive study;
llm_translation: I?! And didn't Rava say: Scripture and Mishnah in Metallalta, and the students of Bar Metallalta! It is not difficult: this — in Megras, that — in Ayyonei.

hebrew_text: כִּי הָא (דְּרַבָּה) בַּר חָמָא כִּי הֲווֹ קָיְימִי מִקַּמֵּיהּ דְּרַב חִסְדָּא מַרְהֲטִי בִּגְמָרָא בַּהֲדֵי הֲדָדֵי, וַהֲדַר מְעַיְּינִי בִּסְבָרָא.
human_translation: As that bar Ḥama, when they would stand before Rav Ḥisda, they quickly the tradition together and then analyze the rationale
llm_translation: The text reads as follows: "For when Rabba bar Ḥama and Rab Ḥisda were sitting together, Rabba bar Ḥama was engaged in studying the Gemara in the presence of Rab Ḥisda, and then he would inquire into the reasoning."

hebrew_text: אָמַר רָבָא: מָאנֵי מִשְׁתְּיָא — בִּמְטַלַּלְתָּא, מָאנֵי מֵיכְלָא — בַּר מִמְּטַלַּלְתָּא. חַצְבָּא וְשָׁחֵיל — בַּר מִמְּטַלַּלְתָּא, וּשְׁרָגָא — בִּמְטַלַּלְתָּא. וְאָמְרִי לַהּ: בַּר מִמְּטַלַּלְתָּא. וְלָא פְּלִיגִי: הָא — בְּסוּכָּה גְּדוֹלָה, הָא — בְּסוּכָּה קְטַנָּה.
human_translation: Rava said: Drinking vessels in the sukka . Eating vessels out of the sukka An earthenware jug and a wicker basket [ shaḥil ] outside the sukka . And a lamp inside the sukka , and some say outside the sukka . And they do not disagree. this to a large sukka , that to a small sukka ,
llm_translation: Rava said: "When it comes to drinking - in a covered area, when it comes to eating - in the open area. A pitcher and a bowl - in the open area, and a lamp - in a covered area." And some say: "In the open area." And they do not disagree: this - in a large sukkah, that - in a small sukkah.

hebrew_text: יָרְדוּ גְּשָׁמִים. תָּנָא: מִשֶּׁתִּסְרַח הַמִּקְפָּה שֶׁל גְּרִיסִין.
human_translation: rain fell, It was taught from when a congealed dish of pounded grain, will spoil.
llm_translation: The rain fell. It was taught: Once the roof of the presses leaks.

hebrew_text: אַבָּיֵי הֲוָה קָא יָתֵיב קַמֵּיהּ דְּרַב יוֹסֵף בִּמְטַלַּלְתָּא, נְשַׁב זִיקָא וְקָא מַיְיתֵי צִיבְוָתָא. אֲמַר לְהוּ רַב יוֹסֵף: פַּנּוּ לִי מָאנַי מֵהָכָא. אֲמַר לֵיהּ אַבָּיֵי, וְהָא תְּנַן: מִשֶּׁתִּסְרַח הַמִּקְפָּה! אֲמַר לֵיהּ: לְדִידִי, כֵּיוָן דַּאֲנִינָא דַּעְתַּאי — כְּמִי שֶׁתִּסְרַח הַמִּקְפָּה דָּמֵי לִי.
human_translation: Abaye was sitting before Rav Yosef in the sukka . The wind blew and brought splinters Rav Yosef said to him: Vacate my vessels from here, Abaye said to him: Didn’t we learn until the congealed dish will spoil? He said to him: For me, since I am delicate, is as if the congealed dish will spoil.
llm_translation: Abaye was sitting in front of Rav Yosef in the courtyard, a fly came and disturbed him. Rav Yosef said to them: Turn it away from me. Abaye said to him, but didn't we learn: "When the skull is itching!" He said to him: According to my opinion, since my mind is disturbed, it is as if the skull is itching for me.

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: הָיָה אוֹכֵל בַּסּוּכָּה וְיָרְדוּ גְּשָׁמִים וְיָרַד — אֵין מַטְרִיחִין אוֹתוֹ לַעֲלוֹת עַד שֶׁיִּגְמוֹר סְעוּדָּתוֹ. הָיָה יָשֵׁן תַּחַת הַסּוּכָּה וְיָרְדוּ גְּשָׁמִים וְיָרַד — אֵין מַטְרִיחִין אוֹתוֹ לַעֲלוֹת עַד שֶׁיֵּאוֹר.
human_translation: The Sages taught: one was eating in the sukka , and rain fell, he descended one does not burden him to ascend until he finishes his meal. one was sleeping under the sukka , and rain fell, and he descended one does not burden him to ascend until it becomes light.
llm_translation: The Sages taught: If one was eating in the sukkah and rain fell, and he descended — they do not trouble him to ascend until he finishes his meal. If one was sleeping beneath the sukkah and rain fell, and he descended — they do not trouble him to ascend until it clears up.

hebrew_text: אִיבַּעְיָא לְהוּ: עַד שֶׁיֵּעוֹר אוֹ עַד שֶׁיֵּאוֹר? תָּא שְׁמַע: עַד שֶׁיֵּאוֹר וְיַעֲלֶה עַמּוּד הַשַּׁחַר. תַּרְתֵּי?! אֶלָּא אֵימָא: עַד שֶׁיֵּעוֹר וְיַעֲלֶה עַמּוּד הַשַּׁחַר.
human_translation: A dilemma was raised before Until one awakens [ sheyeor ], Until it becomes light [ sheyeor ], Come hear until it becomes light [ sheyeor ], and dawn two Rather, say Until he awakens [ sheyeor ], and the dawn
llm_translation: The question was asked: Until it becomes light or until it is light? Come and hear: Until it is light and the morning star rises. Two?! Rather say: Until it becomes light and the morning star rises.

hebrew_text: מָשָׁל לְמָה הַדָּבָר דּוֹמֶה. אִיבַּעְיָא לְהוּ: מִי שָׁפַךְ לְמִי? תָּא שְׁמַע דְּתַנְיָא: שָׁפַךְ לוֹ רַבּוֹ קִיתוֹן עַל פָּנָיו, וְאָמַר לוֹ: אִי אֶפְשִׁי בְּשִׁמּוּשֶׁךָ.
human_translation: told a parable: To what is this matter comparable? A dilemma was raised before Who poured in whose Come hear as it is taught His master poured a jug on his face and said to him: I do not want your service.
llm_translation: A parable: To what is this matter similar? They asked: Who poured to whom? Come and hear, as it was taught: He poured a pitcher of water on his master's face, and said to him: If you wish, use your servant.

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: בִּזְמַן שֶׁהַחַמָּה לוֹקָה — סִימָן רַע לְכׇל הָעוֹלָם כּוּלּוֹ. מָשָׁל לְמָה הַדָּבָר דּוֹמֶה? לְמֶלֶךְ בָּשָׂר וָדָם שֶׁעָשָׂה סְעוּדָּה לַעֲבָדָיו וְהִנִּיחַ פָּנָס לִפְנֵיהֶם, כָּעַס עֲלֵיהֶם וְאָמַר לְעַבְדּוֹ: טוֹל פָּנָס מִפְּנֵיהֶם וְהוֹשִׁיבֵם בַּחוֹשֶׁךְ.
human_translation: The Sages taught: When the sun is eclipsed it is a bad omen for the entire world. a parable. To what is this matter comparable? to a king of flesh and blood who prepared a feast for his servants and placed a lantern [ panas ] before them He became angry at them and said to his servant: Take the lantern from before them and seat them in darkness.
llm_translation: The Rabbis taught: When the sun is afflicted - it is a bad omen for the entire world. What is this matter comparable to? To a human king who made a feast for his servants and placed a lantern before them, he became angry with them and said to his servant: Take the lantern away from before them and seat them in darkness.

hebrew_text: תַּנְיָא רַבִּי מֵאִיר אוֹמֵר: כׇּל זְמַן שֶׁמְּאוֹרוֹת לוֹקִין — סִימָן רַע לְשׂוֹנְאֵיהֶם שֶׁל יִשְׂרָאֵל, מִפְּנֵי שֶׁמְּלוּמָּדִין בְּמַכּוֹתֵיהֶן. מָשָׁל לְסוֹפֵר שֶׁבָּא לְבֵית הַסֵּפֶר וּרְצוּעָה בְּיָדוֹ, מִי דּוֹאֵג — מִי שֶׁרָגִיל לִלְקוֹת בְּכׇל יוֹם וָיוֹם הוּא דּוֹאֵג.
human_translation: It is taught Rabbi Meir says: When the lights, are eclipsed, it is a bad omen for the enemies of the Jewish people, because they are experienced in their beatings. a parable: to a teacher who comes to the school with a strap in his hand. Who worries? who is accustomed to be beaten each and every day is worries.
llm_translation: It was taught: Rabbi Meir says: As long as their candles are lit, it is a bad sign for the slanderers of Israel, because they are accustomed to their beatings. It is like a scribe who comes to the house of study with his quill in his hand; who worries? He who is accustomed to write every day, he worries.

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: בִּזְמַן שֶׁהַחַמָּה לוֹקָה — סִימָן רַע לַגּוֹיִם. לְבָנָה לוֹקָה — סִימָן רַע לְשׂוֹנְאֵיהֶם שֶׁל יִשְׂרָאֵל. מִפְּנֵי שֶׁיִּשְׂרָאֵל מוֹנִין לַלְּבָנָה, וְגוֹיִם לַחַמָּה. לוֹקָה בַּמִּזְרָח — סִימָן רַע לְיוֹשְׁבֵי מִזְרָח. בַּמַּעֲרָב — סִימָן רַע לְיוֹשְׁבֵי מַעֲרָב. בְּאֶמְצַע הָרָקִיעַ — סִימָן רַע לְכׇל הָעוֹלָם כּוּלּוֹ.
human_translation: The Sages taught When the sun is eclipsed, it is a bad omen for the nations. the moon is eclipsed, it is a bad omen for the enemies of the Jewish people. due to that the Jewish people calculate on the moon, and the nations on the sun. eclipsed in the east, it is a bad omen for the residents the east. in the west, it is a bad omen for the residents the west. in the middle of the sky, it is a bad omen for the entire world.
llm_translation: The Rabbis taught: When the sun is afflicted - it is a bad omen for the nations. When the moon is afflicted - it is a bad omen for the enemies of Israel. Because Israel counts by the moon, and the nations by the sun. Afflicted in the east - a bad omen for the inhabitants of the east. In the west - a bad omen for the inhabitants of the west. In the middle of the sky - a bad omen for the entire world.

hebrew_text: פָּנָיו דּוֹמִין לְדָם — חֶרֶב בָּא לָעוֹלָם. לְשַׂק — חִיצֵּי רָעָב בָּאִין לָעוֹלָם. לָזוֹ וְלָזוֹ — חֶרֶב וְחִיצֵּי רָעָב בָּאִין לָעוֹלָם. לָקָה בִּכְנִיסָתוֹ — פּוּרְעָנוּת שׁוֹהָה לָבֹא. בִּיצִיאָתוֹ — מְמַהֶרֶת לָבֹא. וְיֵשׁ אוֹמְרִים חִילּוּף הַדְּבָרִים.
human_translation: the visage is like blood, sword, is coming to the world. is like sackcloth arrows of hunger are coming to the world, to this, and to that, sword and arrows of hunger are coming to the world. eclipsed upon its entry, calamity is tarrying to come. upon its departure calamity is hastening to come. And some say the matters are reversed:
llm_translation: His face is like blood - a sword comes to the world. For sackcloth - arrows of famine come to the world. For this and for that - sword and arrows of famine come to the world. If he is struck upon entering - the decree is delayed in coming. Upon his exit - it hastens to come. And some say, the order of the words.

hebrew_text: וְאֵין לְךָ כׇּל אוּמָּה וְאוּמָּהּ שֶׁלּוֹקָה, שֶׁאֵין אֱלֹהֶיהָ לוֹקֶה עִמָּהּ, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וּבְכׇל אֱלֹהֵי מִצְרַיִם אֶעֱשֶׂה שְׁפָטִים״. וּבִזְמַן שֶׁיִּשְׂרָאֵל עוֹשִׂין רְצוֹנוֹ שֶׁל מָקוֹם אֵין מִתְיָרְאִין מִכׇּל אֵלּוּ, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״כֹּה אָמַר ה׳ אֶל דֶּרֶךְ הַגּוֹיִם אַל תִּלְמָדוּ וּמֵאוֹתוֹת הַשָּׁמַיִם אַל תֵּחָתּוּ כִּי יֵחַתּוּ הַגּוֹיִם מֵהֵמָּה״ — גּוֹיִם יֵחַתּוּ, וְאֵין יִשְׂרָאֵל יֵחַתּוּ.
human_translation: There is no nation that is afflicted whose god is not afflicted with it, as it is stated: “And against all the gods of Egypt I will mete out judgment; I am God” When the Jewish people perform God’s will, they not fear any of these as it is stated: “Thus says the Lord: Learn not the way of the nations, and be not dismayed at the signs of Heaven; for the nations are dismayed at them” The nations will be dismayed, but the Jewish people will not be dismayed,
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And you have no nation and its deity is not punished with it, as it is stated: "And against all the gods of Egypt I will execute judgments." And when Israel does the will of the Omnipresent, they are not afraid of any of these, as it is stated: "Thus said the Lord: Do not learn the way of the nations, and do not be dismayed at the signs of the heavens, for the nations are dismayed by them" - the nations will be dismayed, but Israel will not be dismayed.

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: בִּשְׁבִיל אַרְבָּעָה דְּבָרִים חַמָּה לוֹקָה: עַל אָב בֵּית דִּין שֶׁמֵּת וְאֵינוֹ נִסְפָּד כַּהֲלָכָה, וְעַל נַעֲרָה הַמְאוֹרָסָה שֶׁצָּעֲקָה בָּעִיר וְאֵין מוֹשִׁיעַ לָהּ, וְעַל מִשְׁכַּב זְכוּר, וְעַל שְׁנֵי אַחִין שֶׁנִּשְׁפַּךְ דָּמָן כְּאֶחָד.
human_translation: The Sages taught on account of four matters the sun is eclipsed: On a president of the court who dies and is not eulogized appropriately, on a betrothed young woman who screamed in the city and there was no one to rescue her; on homosexuality; and on two brothers whose blood was spilled as one.
llm_translation: The Rabbis taught: For four matters the sun is smitten: upon the father of the court who dies and is not eulogized according to the law, and upon a betrothed maiden who cries out in the city and there is no one to save her, and upon a male who lies with another male, and upon two brothers whose blood is spilled together as one.

hebrew_text: וּבִשְׁבִיל אַרְבָּעָה דְּבָרִים מְאוֹרוֹת לוֹקִין: עַל כּוֹתְבֵי פְלַסְתֵּר, וְעַל מְעִידֵי עֵדוּת שֶׁקֶר, וְעַל מְגַדְּלֵי בְּהֵמָה דַּקָּה בְּאֶרֶץ יִשְׂרָאֵל, וְעַל קוֹצְצֵי אִילָנוֹת טוֹבוֹת.
human_translation: And on account of four matters the lights eclipsed: On forgers of a fraudulent document [ pelaster ] on testifiers of false testimony; on raisers of small domesticated animals in Eretz Yisrael and on choppers of good, trees.
llm_translation: And because of four matters, they flog him: for those who write false documents, and for false witnesses, and for those who raise a lean animal in the land of Israel, and for those who cut down good trees.

hebrew_text: וּבִשְׁבִיל אַרְבָּעָה דְּבָרִים נִכְסֵי בַּעֲלֵי בָתִּים נִמְסָרִין לַמַּלְכוּת: עַל מַשְׁהֵי שְׁטָרוֹת פְּרוּעִים, וְעַל מַלְוֵי בְּרִבִּית,
human_translation: And on account of four matters the property of homeowners is delivered to the monarchy On keepers of paid notes, and on lenders with interest;
llm_translation: And because of four matters the properties of householders are delivered to the kingdom: for unpaid promissory notes, and for loans with interest.

hebrew_text: וְעַל שֶׁהָיָה סִפֵּק בְּיָדָם לִמְחוֹת וְלֹא מִיחוּ, וְעַל שֶׁפּוֹסְקִים צְדָקָה בָּרַבִּים וְאֵינָן נוֹתְנִין.
human_translation: and on those who had the ability to reprimand and did not reprimand and on those who issued charity in public and do not give
llm_translation: And on that which there was doubt in their hands to erase and they did not erase, and on that which they distribute charity in public and do not give.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב: בִּשְׁבִיל אַרְבָּעָה דְּבָרִים נִכְסֵי בַּעֲלֵי בָּתִּים יוֹצְאִין לְטִמְיוֹן: עַל כּוֹבְשֵׁי שְׂכַר שָׂכִיר, וְעַל עוֹשְׁקֵי שְׂכַר שָׂכִיר, וְעַל שֶׁפּוֹרְקִין עוֹל מֵעַל צַוְּארֵיהֶן וְנוֹתְנִין עַל חַבְרֵיהֶן, וְעַל גַּסּוּת הָרוּחַ. וְגַסּוּת הָרוּחַ — כְּנֶגֶד כּוּלָּן. אֲבָל בַּעֲנָוִים כְּתִיב: ״וַעֲנָוִים יִירְשׁוּ אָרֶץ וְהִתְעַנְּגוּ עַל רֹב שָׁלוֹם״.
human_translation: Rav said: On account of four matters the property of homeowners is confiscated by the state treasury [ timyon ]: On those who delay the salary of hired laborers on those who withhold the salary of hired laborers and on those who throw off the yoke from their necks and place on their friends; and on the arrogance And the arrogance is equal to them all. However, with regard to the humble it is written: “The humble will inherit the land and delight themselves in the abundance of peace”
llm_translation: Rav said: Because of four things, the property owners leave for concealment: On the oppressors of hired workers, and on those who withhold the wages of hired workers, and on those who remove the yoke from their necks and place it on their colleagues, and on those who are arrogant. And arrogance is against them all. But concerning the humble, it is written: "But the humble shall inherit the land and delight in abundant peace."

hebrew_text: הֲדַרַן עֲלָךְ הַיָּשֵׁן
llm_translation: We will return to you, old one.

hebrew_text: לוּלָב הַגָּזוּל וְהַיָּבֵשׁ — פָּסוּל. שֶׁל אֲשֵׁירָה וְשֶׁל עִיר הַנִּדַּחַת — פָּסוּל. נִקְטַם רֹאשׁוֹ, נִפְרְצוּ עָלָיו — פָּסוּל. נִפְרְדוּ עָלָיו — כָּשֵׁר. רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: יַאַגְדֶנּוּ מִלְמַעְלָה. צִינֵי הַר הַבַּרְזֶל — כְּשֵׁירוֹת. לוּלָב שֶׁיֵּשׁ בּוֹ שְׁלֹשָׁה טְפָחִים כְּדֵי לְנַעְנֵעַ בּוֹ — כָּשֵׁר.
human_translation: A lulav that was stolen or that is dry unfit of a tree worshipped as idolatry [ asheira ] and from a city incited unfit. If the top was severed or if the leaves were severed unfit. If its leaves, were spread fit. Rabbi Yehuda says: one should bind from the top, palms of the Iron Mountain fit A lulav that has three handbreadths sufficient to wave with it, is fit
llm_translation: Talmudic text: A stolen or dried out Lulav — invalid. One from an Asherah tree or from a city that has been excommunicated — invalid. If its top is cut off, or if it is split — invalid. If its leaves are separated — valid. Rabbi Yehuda says: Bind it from above. The side branches of Har HaBarzel — valid. A Lulav that has three handbreadths in order to shake with it — valid.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ קָא פָסֵיק וְתָנֵי, לָא שְׁנָא בְּיוֹם טוֹב רִאשׁוֹן, וְלָא שְׁנָא בְּיוֹם טוֹב שֵׁנִי.
human_translation: The mishna teaches no difference on the first day of the festival and no difference on the second day of the festival
llm_translation: The Gemara interrupted and taught: It is no different on the first day of Yom Tov, and it is no different on the second day of Yom Tov.

hebrew_text: בִּשְׁלָמָא יָבֵשׁ — ״הָדָר״ בָּעֵינַן, וְלֵיכָּא. אֶלָּא גָּזוּל, בִּשְׁלָמָא יוֹם טוֹב רִאשׁוֹן, דִּכְתִיב: ״לָכֶם״ — מִשֶּׁלָּכֶם. אֶלָּא בְּיוֹם טוֹב שֵׁנִי אַמַּאי לָא?
human_translation: Granted, a dry we require beauty. And there is not However, a stolen granted, the first day of the Festival as it is written: for yourselves from your own However, on the second day of the Festival, why not
llm_translation: In peace dried — "adorn" we require, and not. Rather, robbery, in peace first day of the festival, as it is written: "for you" — from what is yours. But on the second day of the festival, why not?

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן מִשּׁוּם רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן יוֹחַי:
human_translation: Rabbi Yoḥanan said in the name of Rabbi Shimon ben Yoḥai:
llm_translation: Said Rabbi Yochanan in the name of Rabbi Shimon ben Yochai:

hebrew_text: מִשּׁוּם דְּהָוֵה לֵיהּ מִצְוָה הַבָּאָה בַּעֲבֵירָה, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וַהֲבֵאתֶם גָּזוּל וְאֶת הַפִּסֵּחַ וְאֶת הַחוֹלֶה״. גָּזוּל דּוּמְיָא דְּפִסֵּחַ, מָה פִּסֵּחַ לֵית לֵיהּ תַּקַּנְתָּא — אַף גָּזוּל לֵית לֵיהּ תַּקַּנְתָּא, לָא שְׁנָא לִפְנֵי יֵאוּשׁ וְלָא שְׁנָא לְאַחַר יֵאוּשׁ.
human_translation: because it is a mitzva that comes by means of a transgression, as it is stated: “And you have brought that which was stolen and the lame, and the sick; a stolen equivalent to a lame Just as a lame has no remedy so too, a stolen has no remedy. no difference before despair no difference after despair.
llm_translation: Due to the fact that a commandment that comes through transgression, as it is stated: "And you shall bring a stolen animal and the Passover offering and the ill person." Stolen property is similar to the Passover offering: just as the Passover offering does not have a remedy, so too stolen property does not have a remedy. It is not different whether the stolen property is before despair or after despair.

hebrew_text: בִּשְׁלָמָא לִפְנֵי יֵאוּשׁ — ״אָדָם כִּי יַקְרִיב מִכֶּם״ אָמַר רַחֲמָנָא, וְלָאו דִּידֵיהּ הוּא. אֶלָּא לְאַחַר יֵאוּשׁ — הָא קַנְיֵיהּ בְּיֵאוּשׁ! אֶלָּא לָאו, מִשּׁוּם דְּהָוֵה לֵיהּ מִצְוָה הַבָּאָה בַּעֲבֵירָה.
human_translation: Granted, before despair The Merciful One says: “When a person sacrifices from yours and this is not his. However, after despair didn’t acquire with despair? Rather, is it not because is a mitzva that comes by means of a transgression?
llm_translation: Talmudic text: With peace before despair - "When a man among you brings an offering" the Merciful One said, and not his own. But after despair - he acquires it with despair! Rather, no, because it becomes a commandment that comes through transgression.

hebrew_text: וְאָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן מִשּׁוּם רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן יוֹחַי: מַאי דִּכְתִיב: ״כִּי אֲנִי ה׳ אוֹהֵב מִשְׁפָּט שׂוֹנֵא גָזֵל בְּעוֹלָה״ — מָשָׁל לְמֶלֶךְ בָּשָׂר וָדָם שֶׁהָיָה עוֹבֵר עַל בֵּית הַמֶּכֶס, אָמַר לַעֲבָדָיו: תְּנוּ מֶכֶס לַמּוֹכְסִים. אָמְרוּ לוֹ: וַהֲלֹא כׇּל הַמֶּכֶס כּוּלּוֹ שֶׁלְּךָ הוּא? אָמַר לָהֶם: מִמֶּנִּי יִלְמְדוּ כׇּל עוֹבְרֵי דְּרָכִים וְלֹא יַבְרִיחוּ עַצְמָן מִן הַמֶּכֶס. אַף הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא אָמַר: ״אֲנִי ה׳ שׂוֹנֵא גָזֵל בְּעוֹלָה״, מִמֶּנִּי יִלְמְדוּ בָּנַי וְיַבְרִיחוּ עַצְמָן מִן הַגָּזֵל.
human_translation: And Rabbi Yoḥanan said in the name of Rabbi Shimon ben Yoḥai: What is that which is written: “For I the Lord love justice, I hate robbery in a burnt-offering” a parable of a flesh-and-blood king who was passing by a customs house. He said to his servants: Pay the levy to the taxmen. They said to him: Doesn’t all the tax in its entirety belong to you? He said to them: From my all travelers will learn and will not evade the tax. So too, the Holy One, Blessed be He, said: “I the Lord... hate robbery in a burnt-offering.” From My My children will learn and distance themselves from robbery,
