llm_translation: And Rabbi Yochanan said in the name of Rabbi Shimon ben Yochai: What is the meaning of what is written: "For I, the Lord, love justice, I hate robbery with burnt offering"? — A parable to a king of flesh and blood who passed by the customs house, he said to his servants: Give the customs duty to the tax collectors. They said to him: But isn't all the customs duty yours? He said to them: Let those who pass by learn from me all the paths and not evade the customs duty. So too, the Holy One, blessed be He, said: "I, the Lord, hate robbery with burnt offering," let my children learn from Me and not steal.

hebrew_text: אִתְּמַר נָמֵי, אָמַר רַבִּי אַמֵּי: יָבֵשׁ פָּסוּל מִפְּנֵי שֶׁאֵין הָדָר, גָּזוּל פָּסוּל מִשּׁוּם דְּהָוֵה לֵיהּ מִצְוָה הַבָּאָה בַּעֲבֵירָה.
human_translation: It was also stated: Rabbi Ami said: A dry lulav is unfit because it not beauty, and a stolen is unfit because it is a mitzva that comes by means of a transgression.
llm_translation: It was stated: It was said by Rabbi Ammi: A dried-up Etrog is invalid because it lacks beauty, a stolen Etrog is invalid because it involves a mitzvah that comes through sin.

hebrew_text: וּפְלִיגָא דְּרַבִּי יִצְחָק. דְּאָמַר רַבִּי יִצְחָק בַּר נַחְמָנִי אָמַר שְׁמוּאֵל: לֹא שָׁנוּ, אֶלָּא בְּיוֹם טוֹב רִאשׁוֹן, אֲבָל בְּיוֹם טוֹב שֵׁנִי, מִתּוֹךְ שֶׁיּוֹצֵא בְּשָׁאוּל — יוֹצֵא נָמֵי בְּגָזוּל.
human_translation: And disagrees with Rabbi Yitzḥak, as Rabbi Yitzhak bar Naḥmani said Shmuel said: taught only with regard to the first day of the festival However, on the second day of the Festival, Since one fulfills his obligation with a borrowed one fulfills with a stolen one as well.
llm_translation: Disagreement of Rabbi Yitzchak. For Rabbi Yitzchak son of Nachmani said in the name of Shmuel: They did not differentiate, except on the first day of the festival, but on the second day of the festival, since it is derived from Saul — it is derived from robbery.

hebrew_text: מֵתִיב רַב נַחְמָן בַּר יִצְחָק: לוּלָב הַגָּזוּל וְהַיָּבֵשׁ — פָּסוּל, הָא שָׁאוּל — כָּשֵׁר. אֵימַת? אִילֵּימָא בְּיוֹם טוֹב רִאשׁוֹן, הָא כְּתִיב: ״לָכֶם״ — מִשֶּׁלָּכֶם, וְהַאי לָאו דִּידֵיהּ הוּא. אֶלָּא לָאו, בְּיוֹם טוֹב שֵׁנִי, וְקָתָנֵי גָּזוּל — פָּסוּל!
human_translation: Rabbi Naḥman bar Yitzḥak raises an objection A lulav that was stolen or that is dry unfit. that a borrowed is fit When If you say the first day of the Festival, isn’t it written: for yourselves from your own and this is not his? Rather, is it not the second day of the Festival, and teaches that a stolen is unfit
llm_translation: The Gemara raises an objection: Rav Nachman bar Yitzchak raised an objection: If the stolen or dried out lulav - invalid, but the borrowed one - valid. When? If you will say on the first day of the festival, but it is written: "for you" - from yours, and this one is not his. Rather, it is not valid on the second day of the festival, and it teaches: the stolen one - invalid!

hebrew_text: (רָבָא אָמַר:) לְעוֹלָם בְּיוֹם טוֹב רִאשׁוֹן, וְלָא מִיבַּעְיָא קָאָמַר: לָא מִיבַּעְיָא שָׁאוּל דְּלָאו דִּידֵיהּ הוּא, אֲבָל גָּזוּל, אֵימָא: סְתַם גְּזֵילָה יֵאוּשׁ בְּעָלִים הוּא, וּכְדִידֵיהּ דָּמֵי, קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן.
human_translation: Rava said: Actually, the first day of the Festival, is stating It was not necessary. It was not necessary a borrowed lulav , as it is not his. However, a stolen say: standard robbery despair of the owners, and is like teaches us
llm_translation: Rava said: Always on the first day of a festival, and not that he said: Not that Saul is not his own, but robbery, say: Stolen property is presumed to be owned by the possessor, and its value is like his, this is what he teaches us.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לְהוּ רַב הוּנָא לְהָנְהוּ אֲוַונְכָּרֵי: כִּי זָבְנִיתוּ אָסָא מִגּוֹיִם — לָא תִּגְזְזוּ אַתּוּן, אֶלָּא לִגְזְזוּהּ אִינְהוּ וְיָהֲבוּ לְכוּ. מַאי טַעְמָא — סְתָם גּוֹיִם גַּזְלָנֵי אַרְעָתָא נִינְהוּ
human_translation: Rav Huna said to the merchants [ avankarei ] When you purchase myrtle from gentiles, don’t you cut Rather, let the gentiles cut them and give them to you. What is the reason typical gentiles are land robbers,
llm_translation: Rav Huna said to the Avonkarei: "When Asa purchased the city from the nations, you shall not cut down its trees, but they shall be cut down and given to you. What is the reason? They are considered as ordinary non-Jews who steal land."

hebrew_text: וְקַרְקַע אֵינָהּ נִגְזֶלֶת. הִלְכָּךְ לִגְזְזוּהּ אִינְהוּ, כִּי הֵיכִי דְּלִיהְווֹ יֵאוּשׁ בְּעָלִים בִּידַיְיהוּ דִּידְהוּ וְשִׁינּוּי הָרְשׁוּת בִּידַיְיכוּ.
human_translation: and land not stolen. Therefore, let the gentiles cut so that the despair of the owners will be are still in the hands and the change of possession into your hands.
llm_translation: And the ground is not stolen. Therefore, to steal it is not possible, for if they the thieves will be despaired of keeping it in the hands of its owners, then the transfer of ownership will be in your hands.

hebrew_text: סוֹף סוֹף כִּי גָזְזוּ אֲוַונְכָּרֵי, לֶיהֱוֵי יֵאוּשׁ בְּעָלִים בִּידַיְיהוּ וְשִׁינּוּי הָרְשׁוּת בִּידַן! לָא צְרִיכָא, בְּהוֹשַׁעְנָא דַּאֲוַונְכָּרֵי גּוּפַיְיהוּ.
human_translation: Ultimately, when the merchants cut let it be despair in their hands, and the change of possession into the hands No, necessary with regard to of the merchants themselves,
llm_translation: At the end, when the Avankarei cut, let the owners despair in their hands, and the transfer of ownership in our hands! It is not necessary, with the help of the Avankarei themselves.

hebrew_text: וְלִיקְנְיוּהּ בְּשִׁינּוּי מַעֲשֶׂה! קָא סָבַר לוּלָב אֵין צָרִיךְ אֶגֶד.
human_translation: And let them acquire with change by action Rav Huna holds: A lulav does not require binding.
llm_translation: And they should acquire it with the exchange of an action! He thought that the lulav does not require a binding.

hebrew_text: וְאִם תִּמְצֵי לוֹמַר לוּלָב צָרִיךְ אֶגֶד, שִׁינּוּי הַחוֹזֵר לִבְרִיָּיתוֹ הוּא, וְשִׁינּוּי הַחוֹזֵר לִבְרִיָּיתוֹ — לָא שְׁמֵיהּ שִׁינּוּי.
human_translation: And if you want to say a lulav requires binding, it is a change which reverts to its original state. And A change which reverts to its original state is not considered a change.
llm_translation: "And if you might say, 'The lulav requires a binding,' it is a change that returns to its original state, and a change that returns to its original state - its name is not a change."

hebrew_text: וְלִיקְנְיוּהּ בְּשִׁינּוּי הַשֵּׁם, דְּמֵעִיקָּרָא הֲוָה לֵיהּ אַסָּא וְהַשְׁתָּא
human_translation: And let acquire with a change of name as initially it was a myrtle branch, and now
llm_translation: And they bought it with a change of name, for originally his name was Asa and now it is.

hebrew_text: הוֹשַׁעְנָא! מֵעִיקָּרָא, נָמֵי לְאַסָּא ״הוֹשַׁעְנָא״ קָרוּ לֵיהּ.
human_translation: hoshana , also they initially refer to a myrtle branch as a hoshana
llm_translation: Save us! Initially, indeed to Asa, "Save us" they called out to him.

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: סוּכָּה גְּזוּלָה, וְהַמְסַכֵּךְ בִּרְשׁוּת הָרַבִּים — רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר פּוֹסֵל, וַחֲכָמִים מַכְשִׁירִין.
human_translation: The Sages taught: a stolen sukka and one who roofs in the public domain, Rabbi Eliezer deems unfit and the Rabbis deem fit.
llm_translation: The Sages taught: A stolen sukkah, and one who covers it in a public domain — Rabbi Eliezer disqualifies it, and the Sages deem it fit.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב נַחְמָן: מַחְלוֹקֶת בְּשֶׁתּוֹקֵף אֶת חֲבֵירוֹ וְהוֹצִיאוֹ מִסּוּכָּתוֹ. וְרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר לְטַעְמֵיהּ דְּאָמַר: אֵין אָדָם יוֹצֵא יְדֵי חוֹבָתוֹ בְּסוּכָּתוֹ שֶׁל חֲבֵירוֹ. אִי קַרְקַע נִגְזֶלֶת — סוּכָּה גְּזוּלָה הִיא. וְאִי נָמֵי קַרְקַע אֵינָהּ נִגְזֶלֶת — סוּכָּה שְׁאוּלָה הִיא.
human_translation: Rav Naḥman said: dispute is where one assaults another and evicts him from his sukka , And Rabbi Eliezer conforms to his reasoning, as he said: A person does not fulfill his obligation with the sukka of another. If land be stolen is a stolen sukka . And if indeed land cannot be stolen, it is a borrowed sukka .
llm_translation: Rav Nachman said: A dispute regarding one who lifts up his fellow and removes him from his booth. And Rabbi Eliezer according to his reasoning said: A person does not fulfill his obligation in his fellow's booth. If the ground is stolen - it is a stolen booth. And if the ground is not stolen - it is a borrowed booth.

hebrew_text: וְרַבָּנַן לְטַעְמַיְיהוּ, דְּאָמְרִי: אָדָם יוֹצֵא יְדֵי חוֹבָתוֹ בְּסוּכָּתוֹ שֶׁל חֲבֵירוֹ, וְקַרְקַע אֵינָהּ נִגְזֶלֶת, וְסוּכָּה שְׁאוּלָה הִיא.
human_translation: And the Rabbis conform to their reasoning, as they said: A person fulfills his obligation with the sukka of another. And land cannot be stolen and is a borrowed
llm_translation: The Sages according to their reasoning, for they say: A person fulfills his obligation in his friend's sukkah, and the ground is not considered stolen, and the sukkah is valid.

hebrew_text: אֲבָל גָּזַל עֵצִים וְסִיכֵּךְ בָּהֶן — דִּבְרֵי הַכֹּל אֵין לוֹ אֶלָּא דְּמֵי עֵצִים.
human_translation: However, one stole wood and roofed with it, everyone agrees, has only the monetary value of the wood.
llm_translation: But one who steals wood and constructs with it - the words of everyone is that he only has the value of the wood.

hebrew_text: מִמַּאי?
human_translation: From where
llm_translation: From what?

hebrew_text: מִדְּקָתָנֵי: דּוּמְיָא דִּרְשׁוּת הָרַבִּים. מָה רְשׁוּת הָרַבִּים — קַרְקַע לָאו דִּידֵיהּ הוּא, סוּכָּה נָמֵי — לָאו קַרְקַע דִּידֵיהּ הוּא.
human_translation: From the fact that teaches similar to the public domain. Just as the public domain the land is not his, sukka too, the land is not his,
llm_translation: From the Mishnah: Similar to a public domain. What is a public domain? — The ground is not its own, and a sukkah also is not its own ground.

hebrew_text: הָהִיא סָבְתָּא דַּאֲתַאי לְקַמֵּיהּ דְּרַב נַחְמָן, אֲמַרָה לֵיהּ: רֵישׁ גָּלוּתָא וְכוּלְּהוּ רַבָּנַן דְּבֵי רֵישׁ גָּלוּתָא בְּסוּכָּה גְּזוּלָה הֲווֹ יָתְבִי. צָוְוחָה וְלָא אַשְׁגַּח בָּהּ רַב נַחְמָן. אֲמַרָה לֵיהּ: אִיתְּתָא דַּהֲוָה לֵיהּ לַאֲבוּהָא תְּלָת מְאָה וְתַמְנֵי סְרֵי עַבְדֵי צָוְוחָא קַמַּיְיכוּ וְלָא אַשְׁגְּחִיתוּ בַּהּ?! אֲמַר לְהוּ רַב נַחְמָן: פָּעִיתָא הִיא דָּא, וְאֵין לָהּ אֶלָּא דְּמֵי עֵצִים בִּלְבַד.
human_translation: a certain old woman who came before Rav Naḥman. She said to him: The Exilarch and all the Sages in his house have been sitting in a stolen sukka . She screamed, but Rav Naḥman did not pay attention to her. She said to him: A woman whose father, had three hundred and eighteen slaves screams before you, and you do not pay attention to her? Rav Naḥman said to This is a screamer, and she has only the monetary value of the wood.
llm_translation: That elderly woman who came before Rav Nachman, she said to him: "The head of the exile and all the sages of the house of the head of the exile were sitting in a stolen sukkah." She shouted, and Rav Nachman did not pay attention to her. She said to him: "A woman who had three hundred and eighty-two slaves shouted in front of you, and you did not pay attention to her?!" Rav Nachman said to them: "This is a case of a lost object, and it only has the value of the wood."

hebrew_text: אָמַר רָבִינָא: הַאי כְּשׁוּרָא דִמְטַלַּלְתָּא דִּגְזוּלָה, עָבְדִי לַיהּ רַבָּנַן תַּקַּנְתָּא, מִשּׁוּם תַּקָּנַת מָרִישׁ.
human_translation: Ravina said: the stolen beam of a sukka , the Sages instituted an ordinance due to the ordinance of a beam.
llm_translation: Ravina said: This Kesura of a stolen beam, the Rabbis made a decree concerning it, in the name of the decree of the Master.

hebrew_text: פְּשִׁיטָא, מַאי שְׁנָא מֵעֵצִים? מַהוּ דְּתֵימָא עֵצִים שְׁכִיחִי, אֲבָל הַאי לָא שְׁכִיחָא — אֵימָא לָא, קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן.
human_translation: obvious. what is different from wood Lest you say: Wood is common, but, this is not common, say no teaches us
llm_translation: The Talmudic text translates as follows: Talmudic text: "Peshita, what is the difference between wood? Perhaps you might say that common wood is different, but this one is not common — say no, for it is implied to us."

hebrew_text: הָנֵי מִילֵּי בְּגוֹ שִׁבְעָה, אֲבָל לְבָתַר שִׁבְעָה — הָדַר בְּעֵינֵיהּ. וְאִי חִבְּרוֹ בְּטִינָא, וַאֲפִילּוּ לְאַחַר שִׁבְעָה נָמֵי יָהֵיב לֵיהּ דְּמֵי.
human_translation: This applies within seven However, after seven returns intact. And if attached it with mortar even after seven gives the monetary value
llm_translation: These matters in the case of seven, but after seven - he reconsiders. And if he combined it with straw, even after seven, he must pay its value.

hebrew_text: תָּנָא: יָבֵשׁ — פָּסוּל, רַבִּי יְהוּדָה מַכְשִׁיר. אָמַר רָבָא: מַחֲלוֹקֶת בְּלוּלָב, דְּרַבָּנַן סָבְרִי: מַקְּשִׁינַן לוּלָב לְאֶתְרוֹג, מָה אֶתְרוֹג בָּעֵי ״הָדָר״ — אַף לוּלָב בָּעֵי ״הָדָר״. וְרַבִּי יְהוּדָה סָבַר: לָא מַקְּשִׁינַן לוּלָב לְאֶתְרוֹג. אֲבָל בְּאֶתְרוֹג — דִּבְרֵי הַכֹּל הָדָר בָּעֵינַן.
human_translation: A dry lulav is unfit. Rabbi Yehuda deems fit. Rava said: The dispute is with regard to a lulav , as the Rabbis hold: We liken the lulav to the etrog , Just as the etrog requires beauty, so too, the lulav requires beauty. And Rabbi Yehuda holds: We do not liken the lulav to the etrog . However, with regard to an etrog , everyone agrees that we require beauty [ hadar ]
llm_translation: Mishnah: Dry - invalid, Rabbi Yehuda permits. Rava said: The dispute is regarding the binding of the lulav, the Rabbis hold: We bind the lulav with the etrog, just as the etrog requires "hadar" - so too the lulav requires "hadar." And Rabbi Yehuda holds: We do not bind the lulav with the etrog. But regarding the etrog - everyone agrees that "hadar" is required.

hebrew_text: וּבְלוּלָב לָא בָּעֵי רַבִּי יְהוּדָה ״הָדָר״? וְהָתְנַן, רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: יַאַגְדֶנּוּ מִלְמַעְלָה. מַאי טַעְמָא — לָאו מִשּׁוּם דְּבָעֵי ״הָדָר״?
human_translation: And with regard to a lulav , does Rabbi Yehuda not require beauty? But didn’t we learn in the mishna Rabbi Yehuda says: one should bind from the top. What is the reason not because he requires beauty
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Does Rabbi Yehuda not require a lulav "hadar"? And we learned in a Mishnah, Rabbi Yehuda says: "One should bind it from above." What is the reason - is it not because he requires "hadar"?

hebrew_text: לָא, כִּדְקָתָנֵי טַעְמָא: רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר מִשּׁוּם רַבִּי טַרְפוֹן: ״כַּפּוֹת תְּמָרִים״ — כְּפוֹת, וְאִם הָיָה פָּרוּד יִכְפְּתֶנּוּ.
human_translation: No, as the reason is taught: Rabbi Yehuda says in the name of Rabbi Tarfon “Branches [ kappot ] of a date palm.” bound [ kafut ], if were spread, one should bind it.
llm_translation: Not as it is taught in the Mishnah: Rabbi Yehudah says in the name of Rabbi Tarfon: "Palm branches" - branches, and if it was separated, it should be tied.

hebrew_text: וְלָא בָּעֵי ״הָדָר״? וְהָתְנַן: אֵין אוֹגְדִין אֶת הַלּוּלָב אֶלָּא בְּמִינוֹ, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי יְהוּדָה. מַאי טַעְמָא, לָאו מִשּׁוּם דְּבָעֵי ״הָדָר״?
human_translation: And does not require beauty But didn’t we learn in a mishna: One binds the lulav only with its own species, the statement of Rabbi Yehuda? What is the reason not due to he requires beauty
llm_translation: And does it not require "honor"? And we learned: One may not bind the lulav except with its own kind, the words of Rabbi Yehuda. What is the reason, is it not because it requires "honor"?

hebrew_text: לָא, דְּהָא אָמַר רָבָא: אֲפִילּוּ בְּסִיב, וַאֲפִילּוּ בְּעִיקָּרָא דְּדִיקְלָא. [וְאֶלָּא] מַאי טַעְמָא דְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה הָתָם? דְּקָא סָבַר לוּלָב צָרִיךְ אֶגֶד, וְאִי מַיְיתֵי מִינָא אַחֲרִינָא — הָוֵה לְהוּ חֲמִשָּׁה מִינִין.
human_translation: No, as Rava said: even with fiber and even with the root of the date palm, Rather, what is the rationale of Rabbi Yehuda there, because he holds a lulav requires binding, and if one brought another species they are five species
llm_translation: Not so, for Rava said: Even if it is in the middle, and even if it is at the very top of the palm tree. Rather, what is the reason for Rabbi Yehuda there? Because he holds that the lulav needs a binding, and if one brings another species with it, there will be five species.

hebrew_text: וּבְאֶתְרוֹג מִי בָּעֵי רַבִּי יְהוּדָה הָדָר? וְהָתַנְיָא: אַרְבַּעַת מִינִין שֶׁבַּלּוּלָב, כְּשֵׁם שֶׁאֵין פּוֹחֲתִין מֵהֶן כָּךְ אֵין מוֹסִיפִין עֲלֵיהֶן. לֹא מָצָא אֶתְרוֹג — לֹא יָבִיא לֹא פָּרִישׁ וְלֹא רִמּוֹן וְלֹא דָּבָר אַחֵר. כְּמוּשִׁין — כְּשֵׁרִין, יְבֵשִׁין — פְּסוּלִין. רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: אַף יְבֵשִׁין.
human_translation: And with regard to an etrog , does Rabbi Yehuda require beauty? But isn’t it taught the four species of the lulav , just as one may not diminish from their so too, one may not add to their If one did not find an etrog , he should not bring a quince, a pomegranate, or any other item dried, are fit. dry, are unfit. Rabbi Yehuda says: Even dry etrogim are fit.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And in Etrog, who requires Rabbi Yehuda's honor? And it was taught: Four species of the lulav, just as they are not less than them, so do not add to them. If one did not find an etrog — he should not bring neither a persimmon nor a pomegranate nor any other thing. If they are moist — they are valid, if they are dry — they are invalid. Rabbi Yehuda says: Even if they are dry.

hebrew_text: וְאָמַר רַבִּי יְהוּדָה: מַעֲשֶׂה
human_translation: And Rabbi Yehuda said: an incident
llm_translation: And Rabbi Yehuda said: The incident...

hebrew_text: בִּבְנֵי כְרַכִּין, שֶׁהָיוּ מוֹרִישִׁין אֶת לוּלְבֵיהֶן לִבְנֵי בְנֵיהֶן! אָמְרוּ (לָהֶם): מִשָּׁם רְאָיָה? אֵין שְׁעַת הַדְּחָק רְאָיָה.
human_translation: involving city dwellers who would bequeath their lulavim to their grandchildren, said to him: proof from there in exigent circumstances are not proof.
llm_translation: Among the people of Karkin, who would bequeath their lulavs to their grandchildren! They said to them: Is there a proof from there? The time of distress is not a proof.

hebrew_text: קָתָנֵי מִיהַת, רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: אַף יְבֵשִׁין כְּשֵׁרִין, מַאי לָאו, אַאֶתְרוֹג! לָא, אַלּוּלָב.
human_translation: In any event, teaches Rabbi Yehuda says: Even dry are fit What, is it not to an etrog No, that lulav
llm_translation: It was taught in one place: Rabbi Yehuda says: Even dried out etrogs are valid. What is the reason? Because it is written, "a fruit of a beautiful tree" (Leviticus 23:40) - this includes the etrog.

hebrew_text: אָמַר מָר: כְּשֵׁם שֶׁאֵין פּוֹחֲתִין מֵהֶן, כָּךְ אֵין מוֹסִיפִין עֲלֵיהֶן. פְּשִׁיטָא? מַהוּ דְּתֵימָא: הוֹאִיל וְאָמַר רַבִּי יְהוּדָה לוּלָב צָרִיךְ אֶגֶד, וְאִי מַיְיתֵי מִינָא אַחֲרִינָא, הַאי לְחוֹדֵיהּ קָאֵי וְהַאי לְחוֹדֵיהּ קָאֵי, קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן.
human_translation: Master stated Just as one may not diminish from their so too, one may not add to their obvious. Lest you say: Since Rabbi Yehuda said a lulav requires a binding, and if you bring another species, this stands alone and that stands alone, teaches us
llm_translation: Master said: Just as they do not diminish from them, so too they do not add onto them. It is obvious? What might you say: Since Rabbi Yehuda said that the lulav needs a binding, and if one brings another species, this one stands for itself and that one stands for itself, it is clear to us.

hebrew_text: אָמַר מָר: לֹא מָצָא אֶתְרוֹג — לֹא יָבִיא לֹא רִמּוֹן וְלֹא פָּרִישׁ וְלֹא דָּבָר אַחֵר. פְּשִׁיטָא! מַהוּ דְּתֵימָא: לַיְיתֵי, כִּי הֵיכִי שֶׁלֹּא תִּשָּׁכַח תּוֹרַת אֶתְרוֹג, קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן, זִימְנִין דְּנָפֵיק חוּרְבָּא מִינֵּיהּ, דְּאָתֵי לְמִסְרַךְ.
human_translation: Master stated If one cannot find an etrog , he may not bring a pomegranate, a quince, or anything else obvious. Lest you say: He should bring so that the category of etrog will not be forgotten, teaches us damage will result from Some may come to be drawn
llm_translation: Master said: "If one did not find an etrog, he should not bring neither a pomegranate, nor a quince, nor any other fruit." It is obvious! What might you have thought? That he should bring them, so that the law of the etrog will not be forgotten? We learn that sometimes a sword comes out of its sheath, that it comes to destroy.

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע: אֶתְרוֹג הַיָּשָׁן — פָּסוּל, וְרַבִּי יְהוּדָה מַכְשִׁיר. תְּיוּבְתָּא דְרָבָא, תְּיוּבְתָּא.
human_translation: Come hear An old etrog is unfit. Rabbi Yehuda deems it fit. a conclusive refutation a conclusive refutation
llm_translation: "Come and hear: An old etrog - invalid, and Rabbi Yehuda permits it. The dispute of Rava, the dispute."

hebrew_text: וְלָא בָּעֵי הָדָר? וְהָא אֲנַן תְּנַן: הַיָּרוֹק כְּכַרָּתֵי — רַבִּי מֵאִיר מַכְשִׁיר וְרַבִּי יְהוּדָה פּוֹסֵל. לָאו מִשּׁוּם דְּבָעֵי הָדָר? לָא, מִשּׁוּם דְּלָא גְּמַר פֵּירָא.
human_translation: And does not require beauty But didn’t we learn that is leek green, Rabbi Meir deems it fit and Rabbi Yehuda deems it unfit? not due to that requires beauty No, due to that the fruit did not ripen,
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "And does it not require adornment? But we learned: 'If the vegetable is like a leek' — Rabbi Meir deems it valid, and Rabbi Yehuda deems it invalid. Is it not because it requires adornment? No, it is because it has not reached its full growth."

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע: שִׁיעוּר אֶתְרוֹג קָטָן, רַבִּי מֵאִיר אוֹמֵר: כֶּאֱגוֹז, רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: כְּבֵיצָה. לָאו מִשּׁוּם דְּבָעֵי הָדָר? לָא, מִשּׁוּם דְּלָא גְּמַר פֵּירָא.
human_translation: Come hear: the measure of a small etrog ? Rabbi Meir says: a walnut-bulk. Rabbi Yehuda says: an egg-bulk. not due to that requires beauty No, due to that the fruit did not ripen.
llm_translation: Come and hear: the measurement of a small etrog. Rabbi Meir says: like a nut, Rabbi Yehuda says: like an egg. Is it not because it requires beauty? No, it is because it has not reached its full growth.

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע: וּבְגָדוֹל כְּדֵי שֶׁיֶּאֱחוֹז שְׁנַיִם בְּיָדוֹ אַחַת, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי יְהוּדָה. רַבִּי יוֹסֵי אוֹמֵר: אֲפִילּוּ אֶחָד בִּשְׁתֵּי יָדָיו. מַאי טַעְמָא, לָאו מִשּׁוּם דְּבָעֵי הָדָר? לָא, כֵּיוָן דְּאָמַר רַבָּה: לוּלָב בְּיָמִין וְאֶתְרוֹג בִּשְׂמֹאל, זִימְנִין דְּמִחַלְּפִי לֵיהּ וְאָתֵי לְאַפּוּכִינְהוּ וְאָתֵי לְאִיפְּסוֹלֵי.
human_translation: Come hear And in a large so that one could hold two in his one hand; the statement of Rabbi Yehuda. Rabbi Yosei says: even one in his two hands. What is the rationale not due to that requires beauty No, as Rabba said: the lulav in the right and the etrog in the left. Sometimes, they will exchange them for him, and he will come to switch them come to render unfit,
llm_translation: Come and hear: And with a large lulav that is big enough to hold two items in one hand, these are the words of Rabbi Yehuda. Rabbi Yosei says: Even if one holds one item in both hands. What is the reason? Is it not because he wants to beautify the mitzvah? No, since Rabba said: If one holds the lulav in the right hand and the etrog in the left hand, sometimes he will switch them, and he will come to juggle them and will come to invalidate the mitzvah.

hebrew_text: וְאֶלָּא לְרַבִּי יְהוּדָה, הָא כְּתִיב ״הָדָר״?
human_translation: However, to Rabbi Yehuda, isn’t it written: a beautiful [ hadar ]
llm_translation: And rather according to Rabbi Yehuda, is it not written "hadar"?

hebrew_text: הַהוּא הַדָּר בְּאִילָנוֹ מִשָּׁנָה לְשָׁנָה.
human_translation: That a fruit that dwells [ hadar ] in its tree from year to year.
llm_translation: That one who lived in his tree from year to year.

hebrew_text: שֶׁל אֲשֵׁרָה וְשֶׁל עִיר הַנִּדַּחַת. וְשֶׁל אֲשֵׁרָה — פָּסוּל? וְהָאָמַר רָבָא: לוּלָב שֶׁל עֲבוֹדָה זָרָה — לֹא יִטּוֹל, וְאִם נָטַל — כָּשֵׁר.
human_translation: of a tree worshipped as idolatry [ asheira ] and from a city incited And is of an asheira unfit? But didn’t Rava say a lulav of idolatry: One should not take it however, if he took it, it is fit
llm_translation: Of the Asherah and of the city that is to be destroyed. And of the Asherah — disqualified? And Rava said: If one took a lulav of foreign worship — he should not take it, but if he did take it — it is valid.

hebrew_text: הָכָא בַּאֲשֵׁרָה דְמֹשֶׁה עָסְקִינַן, דְּכַתּוֹתֵי מְיכַתַּת שִׁיעוּרֵיהּ.
human_translation: Here, we are dealing with the asheira of Moses, measure was crushed,
llm_translation: Here we are dealing with the Asherah of Moshe, as it is written: "His measurements were consistent."

hebrew_text: דַּיְקָא נָמֵי, דְּקָתָנֵי: דּוּמְיָא דְּעִיר הַנִּדַּחַת. שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ.
human_translation: is also precise as teaches is similar to a city incited learn from here
llm_translation: Precisely it was stated, as it is taught: Similar to the city of refuge. Learn from it.

hebrew_text: נִקְטַם רֹאשׁוֹ. אָמַר רַב הוּנָא: לֹא שָׁנוּ אֶלָּא נִקְטַם, אֲבָל נִסְדַּק — כָּשֵׁר.
human_translation: the top was severed Rav Huna said: They taught only severed; however, split, is fit.
llm_translation: The text reads: "His head was severed." Rav Huna said: They only said "severed," but if it was crushed - it is valid.

hebrew_text: וְנִסְדַּק כָּשֵׁר? וְהָתַנְיָא: לוּלָב כָּפוּף,
human_translation: And is a split fit? But isn’t it taught A lulav bent
llm_translation: "And it should be straight? And it was taught: 'A bent lulav.'"

hebrew_text: קָווּץ, סָדוּק, עָקוֹם דּוֹמֶה לְמַגָּל — פָּסוּל. חָרוּת — פָּסוּל. דּוֹמֶה לְחָרוּת — כָּשֵׁר. אָמַר רַב פָּפָּא: דַּעֲבִיד כְּהֶימְנֵק.
human_translation: thorny, split, curved like a sickle unfit. hard unfit. like hard fit. Rav Pappa said: it is shaped like a fork [ heimanak ],
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Kavutz, Saduk, Akum domeh leMagal - pasul. Charut - pasul. Domeh leCharut - kasher. Amar Rav Papa: Daavid keHemneq." English translation: "Kavutz, Saduk, Akum resembling a sickle - invalid. Charut - invalid. Resembling Charut - valid. Rav Papa said: He acts like a nursing infant."

hebrew_text: עָקוֹם דּוֹמֶה לְמַגָּל, אָמַר רָבָא: לָא אֲמַרַן אֶלָּא לְפָנָיו, אֲבָל לְאַחֲרָיו — בִּרְיָיתֵיהּ הוּא.
human_translation: curved like a sickle, Rava said: We said only forward however, backward, is its nature,
llm_translation: The Talmudic text translates as follows: "A curved object is similar to a sickle, Rava said: We only said this regarding its front, but regarding its back - it is its creation."

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב נַחְמָן: לִצְדָדִין — כִּלְפָנָיו דָּמֵי. וְאָמְרִי לַהּ: כִּלְאַחֲרָיו דָּמֵי.
human_translation: Rav Naḥman said: to the sides is like forward, And some say: is like backward,
llm_translation: Rav Nachman said: "To the sides - like in front of him blood." And some say: "Like behind him blood."

hebrew_text: וְאָמַר רָבָא: הַאי לוּלַבָּא דְּסָלֵיק בְּחַד הוּצָא — בַּעַל מוּם הוּא, וּפָסוּל.
human_translation: And Rava said: This lulav that grew with one leaf, is blemished and unfit.
llm_translation: And Rava said: This lulav that goes up with one removal - it is blemished, and invalid.

hebrew_text: נִפְרְצוּ עָלָיו כּוּ׳. אָמַר רַב פָּפָּא: נִפְרְצוּ — דְּעָבֵיד כִּי חוּפְיָא. נִפְרְדוּ — דְּאִיפָּרוּד אִפָּרוֹדֵי.
human_translation: If the leaves were severed Rav Pappa said: Severed that is made like a broom. Spread separated
llm_translation: They broke through against him. Rav Papa said: "They broke through" - because he acted like a hypocrite. "They separated" - for they were separated like separated ones.

hebrew_text: בָּעֵי רַב פָּפָּא: נֶחְלְקָה הַתְּיוֹמֶת, מַהוּ? תָּא שְׁמַע, דְּאָמַר (רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן) אָמַר רַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ בֶּן לֵוִי: נִיטְּלָה הַתְּיוֹמֶת — פָּסוּל. מַאי לָאו, הוּא הַדִּין נֶחְלְקָה? לָא, נִיטְּלָה שָׁאנֵי, דְּהָא חֲסַר לֵיהּ.
human_translation: What is the twin-leaf split? Come hear which Rabbi Yoḥanan said Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said: the twin-leaf was removed, is unfit. What, is it not the same is true if split? No, was removed is different, because it is lacking,
llm_translation: The question of Rav Pappa: If the Teyomet was removed, what is the ruling? Come and hear, for Rabbi Yochanan said in the name of Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi: If the Teyomet was removed - it is invalid. What if it was not removed, is the ruling the same? No, if it was not removed, it is different, for it is lacking.

hebrew_text: אִיכָּא דְּאָמְרִי: אָמַר (רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן) אָמַר רַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ בֶּן לֵוִי: נֶחְלְקָה הַתְּיוֹמֶת, נַעֲשָׂה כְּמִי שֶׁנִּיטְּלָה הַתְּיוֹמֶת וּפְסוּל.
human_translation: Some say Rabbi Yoḥanan said Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said: the twin-leaf split, it becomes as twin-leaf was removed, and unfit.
llm_translation: There are those who say: Rabbi Yochanan said, Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said: If the twin fetus became divided, it is as though the twin fetus was removed and it is disqualified.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר. תַּנְיָא, רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר מִשּׁוּם רַבִּי טַרְפוֹן: ״כַּפּוֹת תְּמָרִים״ — כְּפוֹת, אִם הָיָה פָּרוּד יִכְפְּתֶנּוּ.
human_translation: Rabbi Yehuda says: It was taught Rabbi Yehuda says in the name of Rabbi Tarfon “Branches [ kappot ] of a date palm.” bound [ kafut ], if were spread, one should bind it.
llm_translation: Rabbi Yehuda says: It was taught in a Baraita, Rabbi Yehuda says in the name of Rabbi Tarfon: "The 'kafot' of dates" - 'kafot,' if it was separated, one may crush it.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ רָבִינָא לְרַב אָשֵׁי: מִמַּאי דְּהַאי ״כַּפּוֹת תְּמָרִים״ דְּלוּלַבָּא הוּא? אֵימָא חֲרוּתָא! בָּעֵינָא כְּפוֹת וְלֵיכָּא.
human_translation: Ravina said to Rav Ashi: From where that this “branches of a date palm,” is of the lulav ? Say the hardened branch we require to be bound, and there is no
llm_translation: Ravina said to Rav Ashi: From what source is this "palm branches" referring to the lulav? Say, it is derived from the laws of freedom! I require the use of branches, and it is not sufficient.

hebrew_text: וְאֵימָא אוּפְתָּא! ״כְּפוֹת״ — מִכְּלָל דְּאִיכָּא פָּרוּד, וְהַאי כָּפוּת וְעוֹמֵד לְעוֹלָם.
human_translation: say the trunk bound, indicates that there is spread. However, this is perpetually bound,
llm_translation: And why not say "Ufta"! "Kefot" - from the category of a breach, and this kefut stands forever.

hebrew_text: וְאֵימָא כּוּפְרָא? אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: ״דְּרָכֶיהָ דַרְכֵי נוֹעַם וְכׇל נְתִיבוֹתֶיהָ שָׁלוֹם״ כְּתִיב.
human_translation: And say the branch of the date palm [ kufra ] Abaye said it is written “Its way are ways of pleasantness and all its paths are peace”
llm_translation: And why is it called Kufra? Abaye said: "Her ways are ways of pleasantness, and all her paths are peace" is written.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ רָבָא תּוֹסְפָאָה לְרָבִינָא: וְאֵימָא תַּרְתֵּי כַּפֵּי דְתַמְרֵי? ״כַּפַּת״ כְּתִיב. וְאֵימָא חֲדָא? לְהָהוּא — ״כַּף״ קָרֵי לֵיהּ.
human_translation: Rava, the expert in Tosefta , said to Ravina: say two palm branches kappot is written And say one That is called kaf .
llm_translation: He said to him, Rava Tosfa'ah to Ravina: And why not two handfuls of dates? "Handful" is written. And why not one? For that one - "palm" is called.

hebrew_text: צִינֵּי הַר הַבַּרְזֶל — כְּשֵׁרָה. אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: לֹא שָׁנוּ אֶלָּא שֶׁרֹאשׁוֹ שֶׁל זֶה מַגִּיעַ לְצַד עִיקָּרוֹ שֶׁל זֶה, אֲבָל אֵין רֹאשׁוֹ שֶׁל זֶה מַגִּיעַ לְצַד עִיקָּרוֹ שֶׁל זֶה — פָּסוּל.
human_translation: palms of the Iron Mountain is fit. Abaye said: taught that only the top of this reaches the base of that However, the top of this does not reach the base of that it is unfit.
llm_translation: The figs of Mount Barzil - valid. Abaye said: They only taught that if the top of this one reaches the base of that one, it is valid, but if the top of this one does not reach the base of that one, it is invalid.

hebrew_text: תַּנְיָא נָמֵי הָכִי: צִינֵּי הַר הַבַּרְזֶל פְּסוּלָה. וְהָא אֲנַן תְּנַן כְּשֵׁרָה! אֶלָּא שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ כְּאַבָּיֵי: שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ.
human_translation: That was taught as well: palms of the Iron Mountain are unfit. But didn’t we learn fit? Rather, learn from it in accordance with Abaye, learn from it.
llm_translation: It was taught in a baraita: The figs of Mount Barzil are invalid. But we learned that they are valid! Rather, conclude from it like Abbaye: conclude from it.

hebrew_text: וְאִיכָּא דְּרָמֵי לַיהּ מִירְמֵא: תְּנַן צִינֵּי הַר הַבַּרְזֶל — כָּשֵׁר, וְהָתַנְיָא: פְּסוּלָה! אָמַר אַבָּיֵי, לָא קַשְׁיָא: כָּאן — שֶׁרֹאשׁוֹ שֶׁל זֶה מַגִּיעַ לְצַד עִיקָּרוֹ שֶׁל זֶה, כָּאן — שֶׁאֵין רֹאשׁוֹ שֶׁל זֶה מַגִּיעַ לְצַד עִיקָּרוֹ שֶׁל זֶה.
human_translation: And others raise it as a contradiction. We learned in the mishna: palms of the Iron Mountain is fit. But isn’t it taught unfit? Abaye said: not difficult: Here, where the top of this reaches the base of that there, where the top of this does not reach the base of that
llm_translation: There is one who raises an objection against him from a Baraita: We learned in the Mishnah, "The tail of Mount Barzel is valid," yet it was taught in a Baraita, "It is invalid!" Abaye said, "There is no difficulty: here - where the head of this one reaches the side of the core of that one, and here - where the head of this one does not reach the side of the core of that one."

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי מָרִיּוֹן אָמַר רַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ בֶּן לֵוִי, וְאָמְרִי לַהּ תָּנֵי רַבָּה בַּר מָרִי מִשּׁוּם רַבָּן יוֹחָנָן בֶּן זַכַּאי: שְׁתֵּי תְמָרוֹת יֵשׁ בְּגֵיא בֶּן הִנֹּם, וְעוֹלֶה עָשָׁן מִבֵּינֵיהֶם. וְזֶהוּ שֶׁשָּׁנִינוּ: צִינֵּי הַר הַבַּרְזֶל כְּשֵׁרוֹת, וְזוֹ הִיא פִּתְחָהּ שֶׁל גֵּיהִנָּם.
human_translation: Rabbi Maryon said Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said, and some say that Rabba bar Mari taught in the name of Rabban Yoḥanan ben Zakkai: There are two date palms in the valley of ben Hinnom, and smoke arises from between them. And this is which we learned palms of the Iron Mountain is fit. And that is the entrance of Gehenna.
llm_translation: Rabbi Marayon said, Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said, and some say it was taught by Rabba bar Mari in the name of Rabban Yochanan ben Zakkai: There are two palm trees in the valley of Ben Hinom, and smoke ascends between them. And this is what we learned: The figs of Mount Barzil are permissible, and this is the entrance of Gehinnom.

hebrew_text: לוּלָב שֶׁיֵּשׁ בּוֹ שְׁלֹשָׁה טְפָחִים. אָמַר רַב יְהוּדָה אָמַר שְׁמוּאֵל: שִׁיעוּר הֲדַס וַעֲרָבָה — שְׁלֹשָׁה, וְלוּלָב — אַרְבָּעָה, כְּדֵי שֶׁיְּהֵא לוּלָב יוֹצֵא מִן הַהֲדַס טֶפַח.
human_translation: A lulav that has three handbreadths Rav Yehuda said Shmuel said: The measure of a myrtle branch and a willow branch is three And a lulav is four so that the lulav will extend handbreadth from the myrtle branch.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: If a lulav that has three handbreadths. Rav Yehudah said in the name of Shmuel: The measure of myrtle and willow is three, and for the lulav is four, so that the lulav extends a handbreadth beyond the myrtle.

hebrew_text: וְרַבִּי פַּרְנָךְ אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: שִׁדְרוֹ שֶׁל לוּלָב צָרִיךְ שֶׁיֵּצֵא מִן הַהֲדַס טֶפַח.
human_translation: And Rabbi Parnakh Rabbi Yoḥanan said: The spine of the lulav , must extend from the myrtle branch handbreadth.
llm_translation: Rabbi Parnach said Rabbi Yochanan: The binding of the lulav requires that it should extend a handbreadth from the myrtle.

hebrew_text: תְּנַן: לוּלָב שֶׁיֵּשׁ בּוֹ שְׁלֹשָׁה טְפָחִים כְּדֵי לְנַעְנֵעַ בּוֹ כָּשֵׁר. אֵימָא: וּכְדֵי לְנַעְנֵעַ בּוֹ, כָּשֵׁר. מָר כִּדְאִית לֵיהּ, וּמַר כִּדְאִית לֵיהּ.
human_translation: we learn A lulav that has three handbreadths sufficient to wave with it, fit say: and sufficient to wave with it fit. this Sage, as per his and this Sage, as per his
llm_translation: We learned in the Mishnah: A lulav that has three handbreadths in order to shake it is valid. I might say: And in order to shake it, it is valid. Mar said: When it is as you have described it, and Mar said: When it is as you have described it.

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע: שִׁיעוּר הֲדַס וַעֲרָבָה — שְׁלֹשָׁה, וְלוּלָב — אַרְבָּעָה. מַאי לָאו בַּהֲדֵי עָלִין! לָא, לְבַד מֵעָלִין.
human_translation: Come hear: The measure of a myrtle branch and of a willow branch is three and a lulav is four What, is it not with the leaves, No, without the leaves.
llm_translation: "Come and hear: The measurement of myrtle and willow - three, and of the lulav - four. What, is it not with the leaves? No, except for the leaves."

hebrew_text: גּוּפָא: שִׁיעוּר הֲדַס וַעֲרָבָה — שְׁלֹשָׁה, וְלוּלָב — אַרְבָּעָה. רַבִּי טַרְפוֹן אוֹמֵר: בְּאַמָּה בַּת חֲמִשָּׁה טְפָחִים.
human_translation: the matter itself. The measure of a myrtle branch and of a willow branch is three and a lulav is four Rabbi Tarfon says: With a cubit of five handbreadths.
llm_translation: Body: The measurement of myrtle and willow - three, and of the palm branch - four. Rabbi Tarfon says: In a cubit of five handbreadths.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רָבָא: שְׁרָא לֵיהּ מָרֵיהּ לְרַבִּי טַרְפוֹן. הַשְׁתָּא עָבוֹת שְׁלֹשָׁה לָא מַשְׁכְּחִינַן, בַּת חֲמִשָּׁה מִבַּעְיָא!
human_translation: Rava said: May his Master, forgive Rabbi Tarfon Now, we do not find a dense-leaved three necessary five
llm_translation: Rava said: His master permitted it to Rabbi Tarfon. Now, presently, we do not find a thickness of three handbreadths, but a thickness of five handbreadths is required!

hebrew_text: כִּי אֲתָא רַב דִּימִי, אָמַר: אַמָּה בַּת שִׁשָּׁה טְפָחִים עֲשֵׂה אוֹתָהּ בַּת חֲמִשָּׁה, צֵא מֵהֶן שְׁלֹשָׁה לַהֲדַס, וְהַשְּׁאָר לַלּוּלָב. כַּמָּה הָווּ לְהוּ — תְּלָתָא וּתְלָתָא חוּמְשֵׁי.
human_translation: When Rav Dimi came he said a cubit of six handbreadths, render it five Take three of for the myrtle branch, and the extra for the lulav . How many are there three and three-fifths
llm_translation: When Rav Dimi came, he said: A cubit of six handbreadths make it of five, take out from them three for myrtle, and the rest for the lulav. How much were they? Three and three fifths.

hebrew_text: קַשְׁיָא דִּשְׁמוּאֵל אַדִּשְׁמוּאֵל: הָכָא אָמַר רַב יְהוּדָה אָמַר שְׁמוּאֵל: שִׁיעוּר הֲדַס וַעֲרָבָה — שְׁלֹשָׁה, וְהָתָם אָמַר רַב הוּנָא אָמַר שְׁמוּאֵל: הֲלָכָה כְּרַבִּי טַרְפוֹן! לָא דַּק. אֵימַר דְּאָמְרִינַן לָא דַּק לְחוּמְרָא, לְקוּלָּא מִי אָמְרִינַן לָא דַּק?!
human_translation: a difficulty, of Shmuel of Shmuel. Here, Rabbi Yehuda said Shmuel said: measure of myrtle branch and the willow branch is three and there, Rav Huna said Shmuel said: The halakha is in accordance with Rabbi Tarfon, was not precise Say that we say: He was not precise when to stringency, to leniency, do we say: He was not precise?
llm_translation: The difficulty of Shmuel is Shmuel: here Rav Yehudah said in the name of Shmuel: The measurement of myrtle and willow - three, and there Rav Huna said in the name of Shmuel: The halakha is like Rabbi Tarfon! It is not fine. Shall we say that when we say it is not fine, it is for stringency, but for leniency, who said it is not fine?!

hebrew_text: כִּי אֲתָא רָבִין, אָמַר: אַמָּה בַּת חֲמִשָּׁה טְפָחִים עֲשֵׂה אוֹתָהּ שִׁשָּׁה. צֵא מֵהֶן שְׁלֹשָׁה לַהֲדַס, וְהַשְּׁאָר לַלּוּלָב. כַּמָּה הָוֵי לְהוּ — תְּרֵי וּפַלְגָא.
human_translation: When Rabin came he said a cubit of five handbreadths, render it six Take three of for the myrtle branch, and the extra for the lulav . How many are there two and a half
llm_translation: When Ravin came, he said: A cubit of five handbreadths make it six. Go out from them three for myrtle, and the rest for the lulav. How much should there be for them? Two and a half.

hebrew_text: סוֹף סוֹף קַשְׁיָא דִּשְׁמוּאֵל אַדִּשְׁמוּאֵל! לָא דַּק, וְהַיְינוּ לְחוּמְרָא לָא דַּק. דְּאָמַר רַב הוּנָא אָמַר שְׁמוּאֵל: הֲלָכָה כְּרַבִּי טַרְפוֹן.
human_translation: Ultimately, a difficulty, of Shmuel of Shmuel. was not precise And this He was not precise, to a stringency, as Rav Huna said Shmuel said: The halakha is in accordance with Rabbi Tarfon.
llm_translation: End, end, difficult of Shmuel, difficult! Not thin, and that is for a stringency not thin. For Rav Huna said in the name of Shmuel: The halakha is like Rabbi Tarfon.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ הֲדַס הַגָּזוּל וְהַיָּבֵשׁ — פָּסוּל. שֶׁל אֲשֵׁרָה וְשֶׁל עִיר הַנִּדַּחַת — פָּסוּל. נִקְטַם רֹאשׁוֹ, נִפְרְצוּ עָלָיו, אוֹ שֶׁהָיוּ עֲנָבָיו מְרוּבּוֹת מֵעָלָיו — פָּסוּל. וְאִם מִיעֲטָן — כָּשֵׁר, וְאֵין מְמַעֲטִין בְּיוֹם טוֹב.
human_translation: A myrtle branch that was stolen or that is dry is unfit. A myrtle branch of a tree worshipped as idolatry [ asheira ] or from a city incited is unfit. the top was severed, the leaves were severed its berries were more numerous than its leaves, it is unfit. If one diminished their fit. But one may not diminish on the Festival
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: Myrtle that was stolen or dried out - is invalid. Myrtle from an Asherah tree or from a city that has been excommunicated - is invalid. If its head was cut off, or its leaves were split, or if its berries were more numerous than its leaves - it is invalid. But if they were diminished - it is valid, and we do not diminish them on a festival day.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: ״עֲנַף עֵץ עָבוֹת״ — שֶׁעֲנָפָיו חוֹפִין אֶת עֵצוֹ. וְאֵי זֶה הוּא? הֱוֵי אוֹמֵר זֶה הֲדַס. וְאֵימָא זֵיתָא! בָּעֵינַן ״עָבוֹת״, וְלֵיכָּא.
human_translation: The Sages taught: “Boughs of a dense-leaved tree” a tree whose leaves obscure its tree. And which tree is that? You must say it is the myrtle tree. And say the olive We require a “dense-leaved” and is not
llm_translation: Talmudic text: The Rabbis taught: "A branch of a thick tree" - its branches cover its tree. And which is this? One should say this is myrtle. And why not say olive? We require "thick," and it is not applicable.

hebrew_text: וְאֵימָא דּוּלְבָּא! בָּעֵינַן עֲנָפָיו חוֹפִין אֶת עֵצוֹ, וְלֵיכָּא.
human_translation: And say it is the Oriental plane tree, We require leaves obscure its tree, and is not an Oriental plane tree.
llm_translation: And why not say "dulba"! We require its branches to surround its trunk, and there is none.

hebrew_text: וְאֵימָא הִירְדּוּף! אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: ״דְּרָכֶיהָ דַרְכֵי נוֹעַם״, וְלֵיכָּא. רָבָא אָמַר, מֵהָכָא: ״הָאֱמֶת וְהַשָּׁלוֹם אֱהָבוּ״.
human_translation: And say oleander, Abaye said: “Its ways are ways of pleasantness” and is not Rava said: from here: “Love truth and peace”
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And why not consider her ways? Abaye said: "Her ways are ways of pleasantness," but there is no. Rava said, from here: "Truth and peace they loved."

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: קָלוּעַ כְּמִין קְלִיעָה וְדוֹמֶה לְשַׁלְשֶׁלֶת, זֶהוּ הֲדַס. רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר בֶּן יַעֲקֹב אוֹמֵר: ״עֲנַף עֵץ עָבוֹת״ — עֵץ שֶׁטַּעַם עֵצוֹ וּפִרְיוֹ שָׁוֶה, הֱוֵי אוֹמֵר זֶה הֲדַס.
human_translation: The Sages taught: Plaited like a braid and chain-like; that is myrtle branch Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov says “Boughs of a dense-leaved tree,” a tree that the taste of its branches and its fruit are alike. You must say this is the myrtle branch.
llm_translation: The Rabbis taught: A leafy branch resembling a braid and similar to a chain, this is the myrtle. Rabbi Eliezer ben Yaakov says: "A thick tree branch" - a tree whose taste and fruit are similar, one should say this is the myrtle.

hebrew_text: תָּנָא: עֵץ עָבוֹת — כָּשֵׁר, וְשֶׁאֵינוֹ עָבוֹת — פָּסוּל.
human_translation: A Sage taught A dense-leaved branch is fit, and one that is not dense-leaved is unfit,
llm_translation: It was taught: "A thick tree" - valid, and "if it is not thick" - invalid.

hebrew_text: הֵיכִי דָּמֵי עָבוֹת? אָמַר רַב יְהוּדָה: וְהוּא דְּקָיְימִי תְּלָתָא תְּלָתָא טַרְפֵי בְּקִינָּא. רַב כָּהֲנָא אָמַר: אֲפִילּוּ תְּרֵי וְחַד. רַב אַחָא בְּרֵיהּ דְּרָבָא מְהַדַּר אַתְּרֵי וְחַד, הוֹאִיל וּנְפַיק מִפּוּמֵּיהּ דְּרַב כָּהֲנָא. אֲמַר לֵיהּ מָר בַּר אַמֵּימָר לְרַב אָשֵׁי: אַבָּא לְהָהוּא — הֲדַס שׁוֹטֶה קָרֵי לֵיהּ.
human_translation: What are the circumstances “dense-leaved tree”? Rav Yehuda said: And is three leaves each base. Rav Kahana said: Even two and one Rav Aḥa, son of Rava, would seek two and one since emerged from the mouth of Rav Kahana. Mar bar Ameimar said to Rav Ashi: father called a wild myrtle branch.
llm_translation: "How are the laws of thick ropes? Rav Yehudah said: And this is what is established, three by three, bundles of reeds. Rav Kahana said: Even two and one. Rav Acha, son of Rava, would arrange them as two and one, since he would go out from the mouth of Rav Kahana. Mar, son of Amemar, said to Rav Ashi: 'That one is called a myrtle branch.'"

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: נָשְׁרוּ רוֹב עָלָיו וְנִשְׁתַּיְּירוּ בּוֹ מִיעוּט — כָּשֵׁר, וּבִלְבַד שֶׁתְּהֵא עֲבוֹתוֹ קַיֶּימֶת.
human_translation: The Sages taught: most of its leaves fell and only a minority remained, fit, provided that its dense-leaved intact.
llm_translation: The sages taught: If most of it was removed and only a small amount remains - it is valid, provided that its thickness is intact.

hebrew_text: הָא גוּפָא קַשְׁיָא: אָמְרַתְּ נָשְׁרוּ רוֹב עָלָיו כָּשֵׁר, וַהֲדַר תָּנֵי וּבִלְבַד שֶׁתְּהֵא עֲבוֹתוֹ קַיֶּימֶת. כֵּיוָן דְּנָתְרִי לְהוּ תְּרֵי, עָבוֹת הֵיכִי מַשְׁכַּחַתְּ לַהּ?
human_translation: This matter itself is difficult, you said: most of its leaves fell it is fit, and then taught: Provided that its dense-leaved intact. Once two fell, how can you find dense-leaved
llm_translation: The matter is difficult: you said most of it is valid, and then you taught that it is only valid if its thickness is maintained. Once two are removed, how can you remember its thickness?

hebrew_text: אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: מַשְׁכַּחַתְּ לַהּ
human_translation: Abaye said: You can find it
llm_translation: Abbaye said: "She found for herself."

hebrew_text: בְּאַסָּא מִצְרָאָה דְּקָיְימִי שִׁבְעָה שִׁבְעָה בְּחַד קִינָּא, דְּכִי נָתְרִי אַרְבְּעָה, פָּשׁוּ לְהוּ תְּלָתָא. אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ הַאי אַסָּא מִצְרָאָה כָּשַׁר לְהוֹשַׁעְנָא.
human_translation: in an Egyptian myrtle branch, which has seven each and every base, as when four fall, three remain, Abaye said: Learn from it this Egyptian myrtle branch is fit for use as a hoshana
llm_translation: In Asa of Egypt, where they establish seven by seven in one lamentation, when four are released, three remain. Abaye said: Learn from this that this Asa of Egypt is fit for salvation.

hebrew_text: פְּשִׁיטָא! מַהוּ דְּתֵימָא הוֹאִיל וְאִית לֵיהּ שֵׁם לְוַוי, לָא מִתַּכְשַׁר — קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן. וְאֵימָא הָכִי נָמֵי! ״עֵץ עָבוֹת״ אָמַר רַחֲמָנָא, מִכׇּל מָקוֹם.
human_translation: obvious. Lest you say that since its a modifier, it is unfit. teaches us And say it is indeed so, “dense-leaved tree” is stated by the Merciful One. in any case,
llm_translation: It is obvious! What might you say? Since it has a name for itself, it is not valid - this is what he implies to us. And say also this: "a thick tree" the Merciful One said, in any case.

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: יָבְשׁוּ רוֹב עָלָיו וְנִשְׁאֲרוּ בּוֹ שְׁלֹשָׁה בַּדֵּי עָלִין לַחִין כָּשֵׁר. וְאָמַר רַב חִסְדָּא: וּבְרֹאשׁ כׇּל אֶחָד וְאֶחָד.
human_translation: The Sages taught: most of its leaves dried and three branches of moist leaves remained on it, it is fit. Rav Ḥisda said: And at the top of each and every
llm_translation: The rabbis taught: If most of it dried up and three rows of dough remained moist, it is deemed fit. And Rav Hisda said: And at the top of each and every one.

hebrew_text: נִקְטַם רֹאשׁוֹ. תָּנֵי עוּלָּא בַּר חִינָּנָא: נִקְטַם רֹאשׁוֹ וְעָלְתָה בּוֹ תְּמָרָה — כָּשֵׁר.
human_translation: the top was severed, Ulla bar Ḥinnana taught: the top was severed, but berry grew in it is fit,
llm_translation: The head was severed. Ulla son of Hinnana taught: If his head was severed and a date-palm grew from it - it is valid.

hebrew_text: בָּעֵי רַבִּי יִרְמְיָה: נִקְטַם רֹאשׁוֹ מֵעֶרֶב יוֹם טוֹב וְעָלְתָה בּוֹ תְּמָרָה בְּיוֹם טוֹב, מַהוּ? יֵשׁ דִּחוּי אֵצֶל מִצְוֹת, אוֹ לֹא?
human_translation: Rabbi Yirmeya raised a dilemma: the top was severed on the Festival eve, and the berry grew in on the Festival, what is the halakha ? Is there disqualification with regard to mitzvot or not?
llm_translation: Inquiries of Rabbi Yirmiyah: If his head was shaved on Erev Yom Tov and a pimple emerged on Yom Tov, what is the law? Is there a prohibition regarding mitzvot, or not?

hebrew_text: וְתִפְשׁוֹט לֵיהּ מֵהָא דִּתְנַן: כִּסָּהוּ וְנִתְגַּלָּה — פָּטוּר מִלְּכַסּוֹת. כִּסָּהוּ הָרוּחַ — חַיָּיב לְכַסּוֹת. וְאָמַר רַבָּה בַּר בַּר חָנָה אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: לֹא שָׁנוּ אֶלָּא שֶׁחָזַר וְנִתְגַּלָּה, אֲבָל לֹא חָזַר וְנִתְגַּלָּה — פָּטוּר מִלְּכַסּוֹת.
human_translation: And resolve from that which we learned he covered and it then uncovered, he is exempt if the wind covered he is obligated Rabba bar bar Ḥana said Rabbi Yoḥanan said: They taught that only if the blood was then exposed. However, if it was not then exposed, he is exempt from to cover
llm_translation: And he shall remove from it what we learned: if he covered it and it was uncovered - he is exempt from covering. If the wind uncovered it - he is obligated to cover. And Rabba bar bar Ḥana said in the name of Rabbi Yoḥanan: They only taught this case where it returned and was uncovered, but if it did not return and was uncovered - he is exempt from covering.

hebrew_text: וְהָוֵינַן בָּהּ: כִּי חָזַר וְנִתְגַּלָּה אַמַּאי חַיָּיב לְכַסּוֹת? הוֹאִיל וְאִידְּחִי אִידְּחִי!
human_translation: And we discussed this When it was then exposed, why is he obligated to cover Since it was disqualified, it disqualified.
llm_translation: And we ask in it: When he returned and it was revealed, why is he obligated to cover? Since he pushed away, he pushed away!

hebrew_text: וְאָמַר רַב פָּפָּא: זֹאת אוֹמֶרֶת אֵין דִּחוּי אֵצֶל מִצְוֹת.
human_translation: And Rav Pappa said: That is to say that there is no disqualification with regard to mitzvot.
llm_translation: And Rav Papa said: This means, there is no pushing aside with regard to commandments.

hebrew_text: דְּרַב פָּפָּא גּוּפָא מִיבַּעְיָא לֵיהּ: מִיפְשָׁיט פְּשִׁיט לֵיהּ דְּאֵין דִּחוּי אֵצֶל מִצְוֹת — לָא שְׁנָא לְקוּלָּא וְלָא שְׁנָא לְחוּמְרָא, אוֹ דִלְמָא סַפּוֹקֵי מְסַפְּקָא לֵיהּ — לְחוּמְרָא אָמְרִינַן, לְקוּלָּא לָא אָמְרִינַן. תֵּיקוּ.
human_translation: Rav Pappa’s itself raised the dilemma. Is it obvious to that there is no disqualification with regard to mitzvot; no difference whether to leniency, and no difference whether to stringency, Or, perhaps was uncertain, to stringency, we say to leniency, we do not say stands
llm_translation: Rav Papa asked him: If he can fulfill it, let him fulfill it, for there is no pushing aside of mitzvot — it is not different for leniency nor is it different for stringency, or perhaps in cases of doubt we are stringent — for stringency we say, for leniency we do not say. The matter remains unresolved.

hebrew_text: לֵימָא כְּתַנָּאֵי: עָבַר וְלִקְּטָן — פָּסוּל, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר (בֶּן) צָדוֹק, וַחֲכָמִים מַכְשִׁירִין. סַבְרוּהָ דְּכוּלֵּי עָלְמָא, לוּלָב אֵין צָרִיךְ אֶגֶד. וְאִם תִּמְצֵי לוֹמַר צָרִיךְ אֶגֶד, לָא יָלְפִינַן לוּלָב מִסּוּכָּה דִּכְתִיב בָּהּ: ״תַּעֲשֶׂה״ — וְלֹא מִן הֶעָשׂוּי.
human_translation: Let us say a dispute of tanna’im , If one transgressed and picked it unfit; the statement of Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Tzadok. The Sages deem it fit. Everyone, agree that a lulav does not require binding. And even if you say that a lulav requires binding, we do not derive lulav from sukka . With regard to it is written: Prepare it, and not from that which is already prepared.
llm_translation: Let us say like the Tannaim: If one passed by and gathered - it is invalid, the words of Rabbi Eliezer (ben) Zadok, and the sages deem it valid. They hold that in all cases, the lulav does not require a binding. And if you would say that it does require a binding, we do not differentiate the lulav from a covering, as it is written in it: "You shall make" - and not from what is already made.

hebrew_text: מַאי לָאו בְּהָא קָמִיפַּלְגִי, דְּמַאן דְּפָסֵיל סָבַר: אָמְרִינַן יֵשׁ דִּחוּי אֵצֶל מִצְוֹת, וּמַאן דְּמַכְשַׁיר סָבַר: לָא אָמְרִינַן יֵשׁ דִּחוּי אֵצֶל מִצְוֹת?
human_translation: What, is it not that are disagreeing about the following? The one who deems unfit, holds: We say there is disqualification with regard to mitzvot. And the one who deems fit, holds: We do not say there is disqualification with regard to mitzvot.
llm_translation: What is the reason he does not argue with this? Because whoever invalidates, he holds: we say there is a rejection by commandments, and whoever validates, he holds: we do not say there is a rejection by commandments?

hebrew_text: לָא, דְּכוּלֵּי עָלְמָא לָא אָמְרִינַן יֵשׁ דִּחוּי אֵצֶל מִצְוֹת, וְהָכָא בְּמֵילַף לוּלָב מִסּוּכָּה קָא מִיפַּלְגִי. מָר סָבַר: יָלְפִינַן לוּלָב מִסּוּכָּה, וּמַר סָבַר: לָא יָלְפִינַן לוּלָב מִסּוּכָּה.
human_translation: No, everyone agrees that we do not say there is disqualification with regard to mitzvot. And here, with regard to deriving lulav from sukka that they disagree. Sage, holds: We derive lulav from sukka . And Sage, holds: We do not derive lulav from sukka .
llm_translation: Not, of all the world, not do we say there is a priority with regards to commandments, and here in the case of the palm branch of the sukkah they are in disagreement. Master A thinks: We should take a palm branch from the sukkah, and Master B thinks: We should not take a palm branch from the sukkah.

hebrew_text: וְאִיבָּעֵית אֵימָא: אִי סְבִירָא לַן לוּלָב צָרִיךְ אֶגֶד, דְּכוּלֵּי עָלְמָא יָלְפִינַן לוּלָב מִסּוּכָּה, וְהָכָא בְּלוּלָב צָרִיךְ אֶגֶד קָא מִיפַּלְגִי, וּבִפְלוּגְתָּא דְּהָנֵי תַּנָּאֵי, דְּתַנְיָא: לוּלָב, בֵּין אָגוּד, בֵּין שֶׁאֵינוֹ אָגוּד — כָּשֵׁר, רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: אָגוּד — כָּשֵׁר, שֶׁאֵינוֹ אָגוּד — פָּסוּל.
human_translation: And if you wish, say If we hold that lulav requires binding, everyone agrees we derive lulav from sukka . And here, with regard to a lulav requires binding that they disagree, and in the dispute of these tanna’im , as it was taught A lulav , whether bound and whether not bound, is fit. Rabbi Yehuda says: If bound fit; if not bound unfit.
llm_translation: And if you wish, say: If it seems to us that the lulav requires a binding, for everyone else binds the lulav with a palm branch, and here regarding the lulav a binding is necessary, they are in disagreement. And in the dispute of those Tannaim, as it is taught: The lulav, whether bound or unbound — valid. Rabbi Yehuda says: Bound — valid, unbound — invalid.

hebrew_text: מַאי טַעְמָא דְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה? יָלֵיף ״לְקִיחָה״ ״לְקִיחָה״ מֵאֲגוּדַּת אֵזוֹב. כְּתִיב הָכָא: ״וּלְקַחְתֶּם לָכֶם בַּיּוֹם הָרִאשׁוֹן״, וּכְתִיב הָתָם: ״וּלְקַחְתֶּם אֲגוּדַּת אֵזוֹב״. מָה לְהַלָּן — אֲגוּדָּה, אַף כָּאן — אֲגוּדָּה. וְרַבָּנַן לֵית לְהוּ ״לְקִיחָה״ ״לְקִיחָה״.
human_translation: What is the rationale Rabbi Yehuda? He derives taking from taking the bundle of hyssop It is written here, “And you shall take for yourselves on the first day and it is written there, “Take a bundle of hyssop” Just as there, in a bundle, so too here, in a bundle. And the Rabbis We do not derive taking from taking
llm_translation: What is the reason for Rabbi Yehuda's opinion? He derives "taking" "taking" from the bundle of hyssop. It is written here: "And you shall take for yourselves on the first day," and it is written there: "And you shall take a bundle of hyssop." Just as there it is a bundle, so too here it is a bundle. And the Rabbis do not have "taking" "taking."

hebrew_text: מַאן תְּנָא לְהָא דְּתָנוּ רַבָּנַן: לוּלָב מִצְוָה לְאוֹגְדוֹ, וְאִם לֹא אֲגָדוֹ כָּשֵׁר. מַנִּי? אִי רַבִּי יְהוּדָה, כִּי לֹא אֲגָדוֹ אַמַּאי כָּשֵׁר? אִי רַבָּנַן, מַאי מִצְוָה קָא עָבֵיד? לְעוֹלָם רַבָּנַן, וּמִצְוָה מִשּׁוּם ״זֶה אֵלִי וְאַנְוֵהוּ״.
human_translation: Who taught a mitzva to bind the lulav , and if he did not bind it, it is fit? Whose If Rabbi Yehuda, when he did not bind it, why is it fit? If the Rabbis, what mitzva did he perform? Actually, it is the Rabbis. And due to that it is stated: “This is my God and I will glorify Him [ ve’anvehu ]”
llm_translation: Who is the Tanna that taught this that the Rabbis taught: "It is a mitzvah to bind the lulav, and if one did not bind it, it is still valid." Who is it? If it is Rabbi Yehuda, why is it valid if not bound? If it is the Rabbis, what mitzvah is he fulfilling? It is indeed the Rabbis, and the mitzvah is for the sake of "This is my God, and I will glorify Him."

hebrew_text: אוֹ שֶׁהָיוּ עֲנָבָיו מְרוּבִּין. אָמַר רַב חִסְדָּא: דָּבָר זֶה, רַבֵּינוּ הַגָּדוֹל אֲמָרוֹ, וְהַמָּקוֹם יִהְיֶה בְּעֶזְרוֹ: לֹא שָׁנוּ אֶלָּא בְּמָקוֹם אֶחָד, אֲבָל בִּשְׁנַיִם אוֹ שְׁלֹשָׁה מְקוֹמוֹת — כָּשֵׁר.
human_translation: Or its berries were more numerous Rav Ḥisda said: This statement was stated by our great rabbi, and may the Omnipresent to his assistance. taught only in one place. However, in two or three places it is fit.
llm_translation: Or if his grapes were abundant. Rav Hisda said: This matter, our great Rabbi said, and the place shall be in his favor: They only taught this in one place, but in two or three places - it is valid.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ רָבָא:
human_translation: said to
llm_translation: He said to him, Rava:

hebrew_text: שְׁנַיִם וּשְׁלֹשָׁה מְקוֹמוֹת הָוֵי מְנוּמָּר, וּפְסוּל.
human_translation: two or three places, is speckled and is unfit.
llm_translation: Two and three places is considered a mixture, and invalid.

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא, אִי אִתְּמַר הָכִי אִתְּמַר: אוֹ שֶׁהָיוּ עֲנָבָיו מְרוּבִּין מֵעָלָיו — פָּסוּל. אָמַר רַב חִסְדָּא: דָּבָר זֶה רַבֵּינוּ הַגָּדוֹל אֲמָרוֹ, וְהַמָּקוֹם יִהְיֶה בְּעֶזְרוֹ: לֹא שָׁנוּ אֶלָּא עֲנָבָיו שְׁחוֹרוֹת. אֲבָל עֲנָבָיו יְרוּקּוֹת — מִינֵי דַהֲדַס הוּא, וְכָשֵׁר.
human_translation: Rather, If was stated, it was stated as follows: Or, its berries were more numerous unfit. Rav Ḥisda said: This statement was stated by our great rabbi, and may the Omnipresent to his assistance: taught only black berries, However, if its berries are green, are the type as myrtle branch, and it is fit.
llm_translation: Rather, if it was stated thus, it was stated thus: Or if its grapes were more numerous than its leaves — it is invalid. Rav Ḥisdah said: This matter, our great Rabbi stated, and the place shall be in his assistance: They only stated regarding black grapes. But green grapes — they are a type of myrtle, and are valid.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב פָּפָּא: אֲדוּמּוֹת כִּשְׁחוֹרוֹת דָּמְיָין, דְּאָמַר רַבִּי חֲנִינָא: הַאי דָּם שָׁחוֹר — אָדוֹם הוּא, אֶלָּא שֶׁלָּקָה.
human_translation: Rav Pappa said: red is like black as Rabbi Ḥanina said: this black blood is red except that it deteriorated.
llm_translation: Rav Papa said: "Edomites are like Ethiopians, for Rabbi Chanina said: This black blood is red, but it has been diluted."

hebrew_text: אִם מִיעֲטָן — כָּשֵׁר. דְּמַעֲטִינְהוּ אֵימַת? אִילֵּימָא מִקַּמֵּיה דְּלֹאגְדֵיהּ — פְּשִׁיטָא! אֶלָּא לְבָתַר דְּלֹאגְדֵיהּ — דָּחוּי מֵעִיקָּרָא הוּא! תִּפְשׁוֹט מִינַּהּ: דָּחוּי מֵעִיקָּרָא — לָא הָוֵי דָּחוּי!
human_translation: If he diminished their it is fit. where he diminished their when? If you say before he bound obvious Rather, after he bound it is disqualification from the outset, Resolve from here disqualification from the outset is not disqualification.
llm_translation: If they are few - valid. When are they considered few? If you say, before it was tied - it is obvious! Rather, after it was tied - it is invalid from the outset! Understand from it: invalid from the outset - it is not invalid!

hebrew_text: לְעוֹלָם בָּתַר דְּאַגְדֵּיהּ, וְקָסָבַר: אֶגֶד הַזְמָנָה בְּעָלְמָא הוּא, וְהַזְמָנָה בְּעָלְמָא — לָאו כְּלוּם הוּא.
human_translation: Actually, after he bound it. And holds that binding it is mere designation and mere designation is not anything
llm_translation: Always after he completes it, and he holds: a contract of time in the world it is, and a contract in the world - it is not nothing.

hebrew_text: וְאֵין מְמַעֲטִין בְּיוֹם טוֹב. הָא עָבַר וְלִקְּטָן מַאי? כָּשֵׁר. דְּאַשְׁחוּר אֵימַת? אִילֵּימָא דְּאַשְׁחוּר מֵאֶתְמוֹל — דָּחוּי מֵעִיקָּרָא הוּא. תִּפְשׁוֹט מִינַּהּ דָּחוּי מֵעִיקָּרָא דְּלָא הָוֵי דָּחוּי!
human_translation: But one may not diminish on the Festival But if one violated and picked them, what is fit, that turned black when? If you say from yesterday, is disqualified from the outset, resolve from here that disqualification from the outset is not disqualification,
llm_translation: And not diminish on a festival. The one who transgressed and gathered, what is the ruling? Valid. When is the time for clarification? If you say it is clarification from yesterday - it is rejected from the outset. You should rather interpret it as clarification from the outset, for it is not considered clarification!

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא לָאו, דְּאַשְׁחוּר בְּיוֹם טוֹב, נִרְאֶה וְנִדְחֶה הוּא. שָׁמְעַתְּ מִינַּהּ: נִרְאֶה וְנִדְחֶה — חוֹזֵר וְנִרְאֶה!
human_translation: Rather, is it not that they turned black on the Festival is fit and disqualified, Conclude from it fit and disqualified then fit
llm_translation: Rather, no, that it is permitted on a festival, it appears and is rejected. You heard from it: it appears and is rejected - it returns and appears!

hebrew_text: לָא, לְעוֹלָם דְּאַשְׁחוּר מֵעִיקָּרָא, דָּחוּי מֵעִיקָּרָא דְּלָא הָוֵי דָּחוּי תִּפְשׁוֹט מִינַּהּ, אֲבָל נִרְאֶה וְנִדְחֶה חוֹזֵר וְנִרְאֶה, לָא תִּפְשׁוֹט.
human_translation: No, actually, where turned black from the outset, Resolve from it disqualified from the outset However, do not resolve fit and disqualified then fit,
llm_translation: Not, forever, of primary, rejected from primary, not be rejected, spread from it, but seems and rejected, returns and seems, not spread.

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: אֵין מְמַעֲטִין בְּיוֹם טוֹב. מִשּׁוּם רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר בְּרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן אָמְרוּ: מְמַעֲטִין. וְהָא קָא מְתַקֵּן מָנָא בְּיוֹם טוֹב!
human_translation: The Sages taught: One may not diminish on the Festival In the name of Rabbi Eliezer, son of Rabbi Shimon, they said: One may diminish But isn’t he preparing a vessel on a Festival,
llm_translation: The Sages taught: One does not diminish food portions on a festival. In the name of Rabbi Eliezer son of Rabbi Shimon, they said: One does diminish food portions. But Manah was being prepared on a festival!

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב אָשֵׁי: כְּגוֹן שֶׁלִּקְּטָן לַאֲכִילָה. וְרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר בְּרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן סָבַר לַהּ כַּאֲבוּהּ, דְּאָמַר: דָּבָר שֶׁאֵין מִתְכַּוֵּין — מוּתָּר.
human_translation: Rav Ashi said: where he picked them for eating them, And Rabbi Eliezer, son of Rabbi Shimon, holds in accordance with his father, who said: An unintentional act, is permitted
llm_translation: Rav Ashei said: For example, that of a minor for eating. And Rabbi Eliezer, the son of Rabbi Shimon, holds for her like her father, as he said: A matter that is not intended - is permitted.

hebrew_text: וְהָא אַבָּיֵי וְרָבָא דְּאָמְרִי תַּרְוַיְיהוּ: מוֹדֶה רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן בִּ״פְסִיק רֵישֵׁיהּ וְלָא יְמוּת״!
human_translation: But didn’t Abaye and Rava both say Rabbi Shimon concedes in the case of: Cut off its head and will it not die?
llm_translation: And behold, Abbaye and Rava both said: "Rabbi Shimon agrees with 'Pisik Reishei, v'lo yamus'!"

hebrew_text: הָכָא בְּמַאי עָסְקִינַן — דְּאִית לֵיהּ הוֹשַׁעְנָא אַחֲרִיתִי.
human_translation: With what are we dealing here? where he has another myrtle branch.
llm_translation: Here we are dealing with what? - that it has the end of salvation.

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: הוּתַּר אַגְדּוֹ בְּיוֹם טוֹב — אוֹגְדוֹ כַּאֲגוּדָּה שֶׁל יָרָק. וְאַמַּאי? לִיעְנְבֵיהּ מִיעְנָב! הָא מַנִּי רַבִּי יְהוּדָה הִיא, דְּאָמַר: עֲנִיבָה — קְשִׁירָה מְעַלַּיְיתָא הִיא.
human_translation: The Sages taught: If the binding was untied on the Festival, one may bind it like a binding of vegetables, But why Let him tie a bow, Whose is this It is Rabbi Yehuda, who says a bow is a full-fledged knot,
llm_translation: The Rabbis taught: One may tie a bundle on a festival - he should tie it like a bundle of vegetables. And why? To teach him from what he should learn! This is the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda, who said: "Tying is a secondary knot."

hebrew_text: אִי רַבִּי יְהוּדָה, אֶגֶד מְעַלַּיְיתָא בָּעֵי! הַאי תַּנָּא סָבַר לַהּ כְּווֹתֵיהּ בַּחֲדָא, וּפְלִיג עֲלֵיהּ בַּחֲדָא.
human_translation: If is Rabbi Yehuda, he requires a full-fledged binding. This tanna holds in accordance with his in one and disagrees with him in one
llm_translation: If Rabbi Yehuda, the Egged requires! This Tanna holds like his colleagues in one aspect, and disagrees with them in one aspect.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ עֲרָבָה גְּזוּלָה וִיבֵשָׁה — פְּסוּלָה. שֶׁל אֲשֵׁרָה וְשֶׁל עִיר הַנִּדַּחַת — פְּסוּלָה. נִקְטַם רֹאשָׁהּ, נִפְרְצוּ עָלֶיהָ, וְהַצַּפְצָפָה — פְּסוּלָה. כְּמוּשָׁה, וְשֶׁנָּשְׁרוּ מִקְצָת עָלֶיהָ, וְשֶׁל בַּעַל — כְּשֵׁרָה.
human_translation: A willow branch stolen or is dry is unfit. from a tree worshipped as idolatry [ asheira ] or from a city incited is unfit. If the top was severed, or its leaves were severed, or the tzaftzafa , is unfit. slightly dried, and one that a minority of its leaves fell, and that is from a non-irrigated is fit.
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: A stolen 'aravah and a withered one - are disqualified. That of an Asherah tree and that of a city designated for destruction - are disqualified. If its top was cut off, if it was split open, or if it is wilted - it is disqualified. Like a Moshe plant, and if some of its leaves were removed, and that of a ba'al - is valid.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: ״עַרְבֵי נַחַל״ — הַגְּדֵילִין עַל הַנַּחַל. דָּבָר אַחֵר: ״עַרְבֵי נַחַל״, שֶׁעָלֶה שֶׁלָּהּ מָשׁוּךְ כְּנַחַל.
human_translation: The Sages taught: “Willows of the brook” that grow by the brook. Alternatively, “willows of the brook” whose leaf is elongated like a brook.
llm_translation: The sages taught: "The banks of a stream" - they extend over the stream. Another explanation: "The banks of a stream," that its ascent is drawn out like a stream.

hebrew_text: תַּנְיָא אִידַּךְ: ״עַרְבֵי נַחַל״, אֵין לִי אֶלָּא עַרְבֵי נַחַל. שֶׁל בַּעַל וְשֶׁל הָרִים מִנַּיִין — תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״עַרְבֵי נַחַל״ מִכׇּל מָקוֹם.
human_translation: It was taught in another “willows of the brook,” I have only willows of the brook of the brook. of the non-irrigated and of the mountains, from where The verse states: “Willows of the brook,” in any case.
llm_translation: It was taught in another Baraita: "Arvei Nachal," I have only Arvei Nachal. How do I know about those of the valley and those of the mountains? The Talmud teaches: "Arvei Nachal" from any place.

hebrew_text: אַבָּא שָׁאוּל אוֹמֵר: ״עַרְבֵי״ — שְׁתַּיִם. אַחַת לַלּוּלָב, וְאַחַת לַמִּקְדָּשׁ.
human_translation: Abba Shaul says: “Willows” two One for the lulav , and one is for the Temple,
llm_translation: Abba Shaul says: "Arvei" - two. One for the lulav, and one for the Temple.

hebrew_text: וְרַבָּנַן, לַמִּקְדָּשׁ מְנָא לְהוּ? הִלְכְתָא גְּמִירִי לְהוּ. דְּאָמַר רַבִּי אַסִּי אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: עֶשֶׂר נְטִיעוֹת, עֲרָבָה וְנִיסּוּךְ הַמַּיִם — הֲלָכָה לְמֹשֶׁה מִסִּינַי.
human_translation: And the Rabbis, from where they for the Temple? a halakha they learned through tradition as Rabbi Asi said Rabbi Yoḥanan said: ten saplings. willow branch And the water libation halakha to Moses from Sinai.
llm_translation: The sages, to the Temple, what do they hold? The law is established for them. For Rabbi Assi said in the name of Rabbi Yochanan: Ten saplings, willow and water libation — a law given to Moses at Sinai.

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: ״עַרְבֵי נַחַל״ — הַגְּדֵילוֹת עַל הַנַּחַל, פְּרָט לְצַפְצָפָה הַגְּדֵילָה בֵּין הֶהָרִים. אָמַר רַבִּי זֵירָא, מַאי קְרָאָה: ״קָח עַל מַיִם רַבִּים צַפְצָפָה שָׂמוֹ״.
human_translation: The Sages taught “Willows of the brook” that grow by the river, to exclude a tzaftzafa , which grows among the mountains Rabbi Zeira said: What is the verse “He placed it by great waters, and set it as a tzaftzafa ”
llm_translation: The sages taught: "Arvei Nachal" - those that are large on the river, excluding the willow that is large between the mountains. Rabbi Zeira said, what is the verse: "He takes up the waters into the clouds, which pour down in abundance on man."

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ אַבָּיֵי: וְדִילְמָא פָּרוֹשֵׁי קָא מְפָרֵשׁ — ״קָח עַל מַיִם רַבִּים״, וּמַאי נִיהוּ — צַפְצָפָה! אִם כֵּן, מַאי ״שָׂמוֹ״? אָמַר רַבִּי אֲבָהוּ: אָמַר הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא: אֲנִי אָמַרְתִּי שֶׁיְּהוּ יִשְׂרָאֵל לְפָנַי כְּ״קָח עַל מַיִם רַבִּים״, וּמַאי נִיהוּ — עֲרָבָה, וְהֵן שָׂמוּ עַצְמָן כְּצַפְצָפָה שֶׁבֶּהָרִים.
human_translation: Abaye said to And perhaps is explaining He placed it by great waters, and what is it a tzaftzafa . If so, what is “set it”? Rabbi Abbahu said the Holy One, Blessed be He, said: I said that the Jewish people should be before Me as placed by great waters, and what is a willow. And they set themselves as a tzaftzafa of the mountains.
llm_translation: He said to him Abaye: And perhaps he is explaining the verse "Take up on many waters," what is the reason? A sponge! If so, what is "set"? Rabbi Avahu said: The Holy One, blessed be He, said: I said that Israel should be before Me like "take up on many waters," what is the reason? A willow, and they made themselves like a sponge in the mountains.

hebrew_text: אִיכָּא דְּמַתְנֵי לַהּ לְהַאי קְרָא אַמַּתְנִיתָא: ״קָח עַל מַיִם רַבִּים צַפְצָפָה שָׂמוֹ״. מַתְקֵיף לַהּ רַבִּי זֵירָא: וְדִילְמָא פָּרוֹשֵׁי קָא מְפָרֵשׁ ״קָח עַל מַיִם רַבִּים״, מַאי נִיהוּ — צַפְצָפָה! אִם כֵּן — מַאי ״שָׂמוֹ״? אָמַר רַבִּי אֲבָהוּ: אָמַר הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא: אֲנִי אָמַרְתִּי שֶׁיְּהוּ יִשְׂרָאֵל לְפָנַי כְּ״קָח עַל מַיִם רַבִּים״, וּמַאי נִיהוּ — עֲרָבָה, וְהֵן שָׂמוּ עַצְמָן כְּצַפְצָפָה שֶׁבֶּהָרִים.
human_translation: Some taught this verse as the baraita He placed it by great waters, and set it as a tzaftzafa . Rabbi Zeira strongly objects: And perhaps is explaining He placed it by great waters, and what is it a tzaftzafa . If so, what is “set it”? Rabbi Abbahu said the Holy One, Blessed be He, said: I said that the Jewish people should be before Me as placed by great waters, and what is a willow. And they set themselves as a tzaftzafa of the mountains.
llm_translation: There is one who teaches about this verse: "Take up a lamentation for her, for her many waters; a rampart is set up." Rabbi Zeira objects to this: Perhaps he is explaining "Take up a lamentation for her many waters," what is the meaning of "a rampart"? If so, what is "is set up"? Rabbi Avahu said: The Holy One, blessed be He, said: I said that Israel should be before Me like "Take up a lamentation for her many waters," what is the meaning of "a rampart"? - it is the willow, and they set themselves up like the rampart of the mountains.

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: אֵי זֶהוּ עֲרָבָה וְאֵיזֶהוּ צַפְצָפָה? עֲרָבָה, קָנֶה שֶׁלָּהּ אָדוֹם, וְעָלֶה שֶׁלָּהּ מָשׁוּךְ וּפִיהָ חָלָק. צַפְצָפָה, קָנֶה שֶׁלָּהּ לָבָן, וְעָלֶה שֶׁלָּהּ עָגוֹל וּפִיהָ דּוֹמֶה לְמַגָּל. וְהָא תַּנְיָא: דּוֹמֶה לְמַגָּל כָּשֵׁר, דּוֹמֶה לְמַסָּר — פָּסוּל! אֲמַר אַבָּיֵי: כִּי תַּנְיָא הָהִיא, בְּחִילְפָא גִּילָא.
human_translation: the Sages taught: What is a willow and what is a tzaftzafa ? a willow its stem is red, and its leaf is elongated, and edge its is smooth. a tzaftzafa , its stem is white, its leaf is round, and edge its is serrated like a sickle. But isn’t it taught like a sickle it is fit, like a saw, it is unfit? Abaye said: When that was taught, it was to ḥilfa gila ,
llm_translation: The sages taught: What is an aravah (willow) and what is a tzafzafah (myrtle)? An aravah, its stem is red, and its leaves are smooth and its mouth is split. A tzafzafah, its stem is white, and its leaves are round and its mouth resembles a sickle. And it was taught in a baraita: If its mouth resembles a sickle it is valid, if it resembles a saw it is invalid! Abaye said: When that baraita was taught, it was in the region of Gilfa.

hebrew_text: אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ הַאי חִילְפָא גִּילָא — כָּשֵׁר לְהוֹשַׁעְנָא. פְּשִׁיטָא! מַהוּ דְּתֵימָא: הוֹאִיל וְאִית לֵיהּ שֵׁם לְוַוי לָא נִתַּכְשַׁר, קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן.
human_translation: Abaye said: Conclude from it this ḥilfa gila is fit for the hoshana obvious. Lest you say that since its a modifier, it should not be fit. teaches us
llm_translation: Abaye said: Understand from this that the army of Chilfa Gilah is valid for redemption. It is obvious! What might you have thought? Since it has a name for destruction, it is not valid for redemption, it is teaching us.

hebrew_text: וְאֵימָא הָכִי נָמֵי! ״עַרְבֵי נַחַל״ אָמַר רַחֲמָנָא, מִכׇּל מָקוֹם.
human_translation: And say it is indeed so, The Merciful One states: “Willows of the brook,” in any case.
llm_translation: And why not say as follows: "Mixed with a riverbed," as the Merciful One said, from any place.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב חִסְדָּא: הָנֵי תְּלָת מִילֵּי אִשְׁתַּנִּי שְׁמַיְיהוּ מִכִּי חֲרַב בֵּית הַמִּקְדָּשׁ: חֲלַפְתָּא — עֲרַבְתָּא, עֲרַבְתָּא — חֲלַפְתָּא. מַאי נָפְקָא מִינַּהּ? לְלוּלָב.
human_translation: Rav Ḥisda said: These three objects’ names changed since the Temple was destroyed. willow ḥalfata , ḥalfata was willow. What is the difference to lulav ,
llm_translation: Rav Ḥisdah said: Those three matters, their names changed when the Temple was destroyed: Ḥalaphta became Aravta, Aravta became Ḥalaphta. What is derived from this? Regarding the lulav.

hebrew_text: שִׁיפּוּרָא — חֲצוֹצַרְתָּא, חֲצוֹצַרְתָּא — שִׁיפּוּרָא. מַאי נָפְקָא מִינַּהּ? לְשׁוֹפָר שֶׁל רֹאשׁ הַשָּׁנָה.
human_translation: trumpet shofar shofar trumpet What is the difference to shofar of Rosh HaShana.
llm_translation: "Shipura - chatzotzarta, chatzotzarta - shipura. Maai nafka minah? Leshofar shel Rosh Hashanah." "Beauty - trumpet, trumpet - beauty. What is derived from it? For the shofar of Rosh Hashanah."

hebrew_text: פָּתוּרְתָּא — פָּתוּרָא, פָּתוּרָא — פָּתוּרְתָּא. לְמַאי נָפְקָא מִינַּהּ? לְמִקָּח וּמִמְכָּר.
human_translation: petorata petora , petora , originally meaning a large table, was called petorata What is the difference to buying and selling.
llm_translation: Interpretation - interpretation, interpretation - interpretation. For what purpose does it emerge? For buying and selling.

hebrew_text: אָמַר אַבָּיֵי, אַף אֲנִי אוֹמֵר: בֵּי כָסֵי — הוּבְלִילָא, הוּבְלִילָא — בֵּי כָסֵי.
human_translation: Abaye said: I too speak huvlila , bei kasei , bei kasei huvlila
llm_translation: Abbaye said, I also say: "Bei Kasei - Hublila, Hublila - Bei Kasei."

hebrew_text: לְמַאי נָפְקָא מִינַּהּ? לְמַחַט הַנִּמְצָא בְּעוֹבִי בֵּית הַכּוֹסוֹת.
human_translation: What is the difference with regard to a needle that is found in the thick of the second compartment of the stomach.
llm_translation: For what does it come out? For the needle found in the thickness of the walls of the privy.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רָבָא בַּר יוֹסֵף, אַף אֲנִי אוֹמֵר: בָּבֶל — בּוֹרְסִיף, בּוֹרְסִיף — בָּבֶל. לְמַאי
human_translation: Rava bar Yosef said: I too speak Babylon Bursif Bursif Babylon What is
llm_translation: Rava bar Yosef said, "I also say: Babylonia is Borsif, and Borsif is Babylonia." For what reason?

hebrew_text: נָפְקָא מִינַּהּ? לְגִיטֵּי נָשִׁים.
human_translation: the practical difference of women’s bills of divorce.
llm_translation: It came out from her? For the divorces of women.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל אוֹמֵר: שְׁלֹשָׁה הֲדַסִּים וּשְׁתֵּי עֲרָבוֹת, לוּלָב אֶחָד, וְאֶתְרוֹג אֶחָד. אֲפִילּוּ שְׁנַיִם קְטוּמִים, וְאֶחָד אֵינוֹ קָטוּם. רַבִּי טַרְפוֹן אוֹמֵר: אֲפִילּוּ שְׁלָשְׁתָּן קְטוּמִים. רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא אוֹמֵר: כְּשֵׁם שֶׁלּוּלָב אֶחָד וְאֶתְרוֹג אֶחָד — כָּךְ הֲדַס אֶחָד וַעֲרָבָה אַחַת.
human_translation: Rabbi Yishmael says: three myrtle branches, and two willow branches, one lulav , and one etrog . even if two are severed and one is not severed, Rabbi Tarfon says: Even if all three are severed, Rabbi Akiva says Just as one lulav and one etrog , so too one myrtle branch and one willow branch.
llm_translation: The Mishnah: Rabbi Yishmael says: Three myrtles and two willows, one palm branch, and one citron. Even if two are dried out, and one is not dried out. Rabbi Tarfon says: Even if all three are dried out. Rabbi Akiva says: Just as there is one palm branch and one citron - so too one myrtle and one willow.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ תַּנְיָא, רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל אוֹמֵר: ״פְּרִי עֵץ הָדָר״ — אֶחָד. ״כַּפֹּת תְּמָרִים״ — אֶחָד. ״עֲנַף עֵץ עָבוֹת״ — שְׁלֹשָׁה. ״עַרְבֵי נַחַל״ — שְׁתַּיִם. וַאֲפִילּוּ שְׁנַיִם קְטוּמִים, וְאֶחָד שֶׁאֵינוֹ קָטוּם. רַבִּי טַרְפוֹן אוֹמֵר: שְׁלֹשָׁה, וַאֲפִילּוּ שְׁלָשְׁתָּן קְטוּמִים. רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא אוֹמֵר: כְּשֵׁם שֶׁלּוּלָב אֶחָד וְאֶתְרוֹג אֶחָד, כָּךְ הֲדַס אֶחָד וַעֲרָבָה אַחַת.
human_translation: It was taught Rabbi Yishmael says: “The fruit of a beautiful tree” one “Branches of a date palm”; one “Boughs of a dense-leaved tree”; three, “Willows of the brook”; two, Even if two are severed and one is not severed, Rabbi Tarfon says: Even if all three are severed, Rabbi Akiva says: Just as one lulav and one etrog , so too, one myrtle branch and one willow branch.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Gemara: It was taught in a baraita: Rabbi Yishmael says: 'The fruit of a beautiful tree' — one. 'Palm branches' — one. 'Thick tree branches' — three. 'Willow branches of the brook' — two. And even if they are two cut and one not cut. Rabbi Tarfon says: three, and even if all three are cut. Rabbi Akiva says: Just as there is one lulav and one etrog, so too one myrtle branch and one willow branch."

hebrew_text: אָמַר לוֹ רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר: יָכוֹל יְהֵא אֶתְרוֹג עִמָּהֶן בַּאֲגוּדָּה אַחַת? אָמַרְתָּ, וְכִי נֶאֱמַר ״פְּרִי עֵץ הָדָר וְכַפֹּת תְּמָרִים״? וַהֲלֹא לֹא נֶאֱמַר אֶלָּא ״כַּפֹּת״! וּמִנַּיִן שֶׁמְּעַכְּבִין זֶה אֶת זֶה? תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״וּלְקַחְתֶּם״ — שֶׁתְּהֵא לְקִיחָה תַּמָּה.
human_translation: Rabbi Eliezer said to him might the etrog should be with in one bundle. you say Does it say: The fruit of a beautiful tree and branches of a date palm, Doesn’t it say only “branches And from where that prevents with the others? The verse states: “And you shall take [ ulkaḥtem ],” it shall be a complete taking [ lekiḥa tamma ]
llm_translation: He said to him Rabbi Eliezer: Can the etrog be with them in one bundle? You said, is it not said "the fruit of a beautiful tree and palm branches"? But was it not said only "palm branches"! And from where do we know that one delays the other? The Scripture teaches: "And you shall take" - that the taking should be simultaneous.

hebrew_text: וְרַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל, מָה נַפְשָׁךְ? אִי שְׁלֵימִין בָּעֵי — לִיבְעֵי נָמֵי כּוּלְּהוּ, אִי לָא בָּעֵי שְׁלֵימִין — אֲפִילּוּ חַד נָמֵי לָא! אָמַר בִּירָאָה אָמַר רַבִּי אַמֵּי: חָזַר בּוֹ רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל.
human_translation: And Rabbi Yishmael, whichever way you If he requires whole let him require all of them And if he does not require whole even one branch not either, Bira’a said Rabbi Ami said: Rabbi Yishmael retracted his
llm_translation: Rabbi Yishmael, what is your desire? If you seek completeness - seek it for all, if you do not seek completeness - not even for one! He said in awe, Rabbi Amei said: Rabbi Yishmael reconsidered.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב יְהוּדָה אָמַר שְׁמוּאֵל: הֲלָכָה כְּרַבִּי טַרְפוֹן. וְאַזְדָּא שְׁמוּאֵל לְטַעְמֵיהּ, דַּאֲמַר לְהוּ שְׁמוּאֵל לְהָנְהוּ דִּמְזַבְּנֵי אַסָּא: אַשְׁווֹ וְזַבִּינוּ, וְאִי לָא — דָּרֵישְׁנָא לְכוּ כְּרַבִּי טַרְפוֹן.
human_translation: Rav Yehuda said Shmuel said: The halakha is in accordance with Rabbi Tarfon. And Shmuel conforms to his reasoning, as Shmuel said to those who were selling myrtle branches: Equate and sell And if not I will teach for you in accordance with Rabbi Tarfon,
llm_translation: Rav Yehudah said in the name of Shmuel: The halakha is like Rabbi Tarfon. And Shmuel was consistent in his reasoning, for Shmuel said to those who were selling the produce of King Asa: "Price it and sell it, and if not, we shall interpret it according to the view of Rabbi Tarfon."
