hebrew_text: מַאי טַעְמָא? אִילֵּימָא מִשּׁוּם דְּמֵיקֵל — וְלִידְרוֹשׁ לְהוּ כְּרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא דְּמֵיקֵל טְפֵי! תְּלָתָא קְטִימִי שְׁכִיחִי, חַד וְלָא קְטִים לָא שְׁכִיחַ.
human_translation: What is the reason If you say it is because is lenient let him teach for them in accordance with Rabbi Akiva, who is even more lenient three severed are common, one is not severed not common.
llm_translation: What is the reason? Perhaps because it is lenient — and to interpret it according to the opinion of Rabbi Akiva who is lenient in minor matters! Three occurrences are common, but one occurrence is not common.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ אֶתְרוֹג הַגָּזוּל וְהַיָּבֵשׁ — פָּסוּל. שֶׁל אֲשֵׁרָה וְשֶׁל עִיר הַנִּדַּחַת — פָּסוּל. שֶׁל עׇרְלָה — פָּסוּל. שֶׁל תְּרוּמָה טְמֵאָה — פָּסוּל. שֶׁל תְּרוּמָה טְהוֹרָה לֹא יִטּוֹל, וְאִם נָטַל — כָּשֵׁר. שֶׁל דְּמַאי — בֵּית שַׁמַּאי פּוֹסְלִין, וּבֵית הִלֵּל מַכְשִׁירִין. שֶׁל מַעֲשֵׂר שֵׁנִי בִּירוּשָׁלַיִם — לֹא יִטּוֹל, וְאִם נָטַל — כָּשֵׁר.
human_translation: An etrog stolen or is dry is unfit. from a tree worshipped as idolatry [ asheira ] or from a city incited is unfit. fruit that grew on a tree during the three years after it was planted [ orla ] is unfit, of impure teruma is unfit. of pure teruma , one may not take it and if one took it, it is fit, demai , Beit Shammai deem it unfit, and Beit Hillel deem it fit. of second tithe in Jerusalem, one may not take it and if he took it, it is fit.
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: A stolen or dried-out etrog is invalid. One from an Asherah tree or from a city that has been designated for destruction is invalid. One from uncircumcised produce is invalid. One from impure terumah is invalid. One from pure terumah should not be taken, but if one did take it, it is valid. One from demai produce: Beit Shammai disqualifies it, and Beit Hillel permits it. One from second tithe produce in Jerusalem should not be taken, but if one did take it, it is valid.

hebrew_text: עָלְתָה חֲזָזִית עַל רוּבּוֹ, נִטְּלָה פִּטְמָתוֹ, נִקְלַף, נִסְדַּק, נִיקַּב וְחָסַר כׇּל שֶׁהוּא — פָּסוּל. עָלְתָה חֲזָזִית עַל מִיעוּטוֹ, נִטַּל עוּקְצוֹ, נִיקַּב וְלֹא חָסַר כׇּל שֶׁהוּא — כָּשֵׁר. אֶתְרוֹג הַכּוּשִׁי — פָּסוּל, וְהַיָּרוֹק כְּכַרָּתֵי — רַבִּי מֵאִיר מַכְשִׁיר וְרַבִּי יְהוּדָה פּוֹסֵל. שִׁיעוּר אֶתְרוֹג הַקָּטָן, רַבִּי מֵאִיר אוֹמֵר: כֶּאֱגוֹז, רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר כְּבֵיצָה. וּבַגָּדוֹל — כְּדֵי שֶׁיֹּאחַז שְׁנַיִם בְּיָדוֹ. דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי יְהוּדָה, וְרַבִּי יוֹסֵי אוֹמֵר: אֲפִילּוּ אֶחָד בִּשְׁתֵּי יָדָיו.
human_translation: boil-like blemishes arose on majority its pestle was removed; was peeled, split, or pierced and is missing any amount, it is unfit. boil-like blemishes arose on its minority; if its stem, was removed; or it was pierced is missing any amount, it is fit. A Cushite etrog , is unfit. that is leek green, Rabbi Meir deems it fit and Rabbi Yehuda deems it unfit. the measure of a small etrog ? Rabbi Meir says: a walnut-bulk. Rabbi Yehuda says: an egg-bulk. And in a large so that one could hold two in his one hand; the statement of Rabbi Yehuda. Rabbi Yosei says: even one in his two hands.
llm_translation: The hazazit ascended upon its majority, its pitmah was removed, it peeled, cracked, was pierced, and lacked anything - it is invalid. The hazazit ascended upon its minority, its uktz was removed, it was pierced and did not lack anything - it is valid. The Ethiopian etrog is invalid, and the green like leeks - Rabbi Meir deems it valid, and Rabbi Yehuda deems it invalid. The measure of a small etrog, Rabbi Meir says: like a nut, Rabbi Yehuda says like an egg. And for a large one - enough to hold two in his hand. These are the words of Rabbi Yehuda, and Rabbi Yosei says: even one in both his hands.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: ״פְּרִי עֵץ הָדָר״, עֵץ שֶׁטַּעַם עֵצוֹ וּפִרְיוֹ שָׁוֶה — הֱוֵי אוֹמֵר זֶה אֶתְרוֹג.
human_translation: The Sages taught “Fruit of a beautiful tree,” a tree that the taste of its tree and fruit are alike. You must say it is etrog
llm_translation: The Sages taught: "The fruit of a beautiful tree," a tree whose taste and appearance are similar - one should say this is an etrog.

hebrew_text: וְאֵימָא פִּלְפְּלִין; כִּדְתַנְיָא, הָיָה רַבִּי מֵאִיר אוֹמֵר: מִמַּשְׁמַע שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר ״וּנְטַעְתֶּם כׇּל עֵץ״, אֵינִי יוֹדֵעַ שֶׁהוּא עֵץ מַאֲכָל? מָה תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר ״עֵץ מַאֲכָל״, עֵץ שֶׁטַּעַם עֵצוֹ וּפִרְיוֹ שָׁוֶה — הֱוֵי אוֹמֵר זֶה פִּלְפְּלִין. לְלַמֶּדְךָ שֶׁהַפִּלְפְּלִין חַיָּיבִין בְּעׇרְלָה. וְאֵין אֶרֶץ יִשְׂרָאֵל חֲסֵרָה כְּלוּם, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״לֹא תֶחְסַר כֹּל בָּהּ״.
human_translation: And say pepper as it was taught Rabbi Meir would say by inference from that which is stated don’t I know that it is a tree food? Rather, what does the verse state: “Any tree for food”? to include a tree that the taste of its tree and fruit are alike. And which is this? You must say this is the pepper to teach you that the peppers, obligated orla . And Eretz Yisrael lacks nothing, as it is stated: “A land where you shall eat bread without scarceness, you shall lack nothing”
llm_translation: And why not peppers? As it was taught: Rabbi Meir would say: From the language of what is heard, as it is stated, "And you shall plant every tree," do I not know that it is a fruit tree? What is the teaching when it says "fruit tree"? A tree whose taste and fruit are similar — you would say this is peppers. To teach you that peppers are subject to the laws of uncircumcised fruit. And there is no land of Israel lacking anything, as it is stated: "Nothing is lacking in it."

hebrew_text: הָתָם מִשּׁוּם דְּלָא אֶפְשָׁר, הֵיכִי נַעֲבֵיד? נִנְקוֹט חֲדָא — לָא מִינַּכְרָא לְקִיחָתַהּ. נִנְקוֹט תְּרֵי אוֹ תְּלָתָא — (אֶחָד) אָמַר רַחֲמָנָא, וְלֹא שְׁנַיִם וּשְׁלֹשָׁה פֵּירוֹת, הִלְכָּךְ לָא אֶפְשָׁר.
human_translation: There, due to that it is not possible How shall we proceed? we take one its taking is not noticeable we take two or three the Torah said one and not two or three fruits. Therefore, it is impossible.
llm_translation: There, because it is not possible, how shall we proceed? If one is taken - it is not recognizable for its acquisition. If two or three are taken - (one) says "Merciful One," and not two or three fruits, therefore it is not possible.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי אוֹמֵר: אַל תִּקְרֵי ״הָדָר״, אֶלָּא ״הַדִּיר״. מָה דִּיר זֶה יֵשׁ בּוֹ גְּדוֹלִים וּקְטַנִּים, תְּמִימִים וּבַעֲלֵי מוּמִין — הָכִי נָמֵי יֵשׁ בּוֹ גְּדוֹלִים וּקְטַנִּים, תְּמִימִים וּבַעֲלֵי מוּמִין. אַטּוּ שְׁאָר פֵּירוֹת לֵית בְּהוּ גְּדוֹלִים וּקְטַנִּים, תְּמִימִין וּבַעֲלֵי מוּמִין?! אֶלָּא הָכִי קָאָמַר: עַד שֶׁבָּאִין קְטַנִּים, עֲדַיִין גְּדוֹלִים קַיָּימִים.
human_translation: Rabbi says: Do not read hadar , but rather hadir , just as this pen there are large and small unblemished and blemished so too, has large and small flawless and blemished Is that to say among other fruits there are not large and small flawless and blemished Rather, this is is saying: when small ones come large ones still exist
llm_translation: Rabbi says: Do not read "hadar" (splendor), rather "hadir" (dwelling). Just as a dwelling contains both great and small, innocent and blemished, so too a dwelling contains both great and small, innocent and blemished. If so, are there not other fruits that do not contain both great and small, innocent and blemished? Rather, this is what he is saying: Until the small ones come, the great ones are still present.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי אֲבָהוּ אָמַר: אַל תִּקְרֵי ״הָדָר״, אֶלָּא ״הַדָּר״ — דָּבָר שֶׁדָּר בְּאִילָנוֹ מִשָּׁנָה לְשָׁנָה. בֶּן עַזַּאי אוֹמֵר: אַל תִּקְרֵי ״הָדָר״, אֶלָּא ״אִידוֹר״, שֶׁכֵּן בְּלָשׁוֹן יְווֹנִי קוֹרִין לְמַיִם אִידוֹר, וְאֵיזוֹ הִיא שֶׁגָּדֵל עַל כׇּל מַיִם — הֱוֵי אוֹמֵר זֶה אֶתְרוֹג.
human_translation: Rabbi Abbahu said: Do not read hadar , but rather haddar , that dwells, an item that dwells on its tree from year to year. Ben Azzai says: Do not read hadar , but rather idur , as in the Greek language one calls water idur . And which is that grows on all water You must say it is an etrog .
llm_translation: Rabbi Avahu said: Do not read "hadar," rather "haddar" - something that dwells in its tree from year to year. Ben Azzai says: Do not read "hadar," rather "idor," for in the Greek language they call water "idor," and which is the one that grows above all waters? - Say this is the etrog.

hebrew_text: שֶׁל אֲשֵׁרָה וְשֶׁל עִיר הַנִּדַּחַת — פָּסוּל. מַאי טַעְמָא? כֵּיוָן דְּלִשְׂרֵפָה קָאֵי — כַּתּוֹתֵי מְיכַתַּת שִׁיעוּרֵיהּ.
human_translation: from a tree worshipped as idolatry or from a city incited What is the reason? Since is fated for burning, its measure was crushed.
llm_translation: Of an Asherah and of a city devoted to destruction — disqualified. What is the reason? Since it stands for burning, its measures are like the measures of its estimation.

hebrew_text: וְשֶׁל עׇרְלָה פָּסוּל. מַאי טַעְמָא? פְּלִיגִי בַּהּ רַבִּי חִיָּיא בַּר אָבִין וְרַבִּי אַסִּי. חַד אָמַר: לְפִי שֶׁאֵין בָּהּ הֶיתֵּר אֲכִילָה, וְחַד אָמַר: לְפִי שֶׁאֵין בָּהּ דִּין מָמוֹן.
human_translation: of orla is unfit. What is the reason? Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Avin and Rabbi Asi disagree this One said: because there is no permission to eat And one said: because it has no monetary
llm_translation: And of uncircumcision is disqualified. What is the reason? They dispute it: Rabbi Chiya bar Avin and Rabbi Assi. One says: Because it does not have the allowance of eating, and one says: Because it does not have the law of monetary compensation.

hebrew_text: קָא סָלְקָא דַּעְתֵּיהּ מַאן דְּבָעֵי הֶיתֵּר אֲכִילָה לָא בָּעֵי דִּין מָמוֹן, וּמַאן דְּבָעֵי דִּין מָמוֹן לָא בָּעֵי הֶיתֵּר אֲכִילָה. תְּנַן: שֶׁל תְּרוּמָה טְמֵאָה — פְּסוּלָה, בִּשְׁלָמָא לְמַאן דְּאָמַר לְפִי שֶׁאֵין בָּהּ הֶיתֵּר אֲכִילָה — שַׁפִּיר. אֶלָּא לְמַאן דְּאָמַר לְפִי שֶׁאֵין בָּהּ דִּין מָמוֹן — אַמַּאי? הֲרֵי מַסִּיקָהּ תַּחַת תַּבְשִׁילוֹ!
human_translation: that it may enter one’s mind one who requires permission to eat does not require monetary and one who requires monetary does not require permission to eat it. we learned in the mishna: of impure teruma is unfit. Granted, according to the one who says because there is no permission to eat it, well However, according to the one who says because it has no monetary value, why burns it under his cooked food.
llm_translation: He ascended with his opinion: One who desires permission for eating does not desire judgment for money, and one who desires judgment for money does not desire permission for eating. We learned in a Mishnah: If the terumah is impure, it is invalid. It is well according to the one who said that since it does not have permission for eating, it is fine. But according to the one who said that since it does not have judgment for money, why? Behold, he has designated it in place of his dish!

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא: בְּהֶיתֵּר אֲכִילָה כּוּלֵּי עָלְמָא לָא פְּלִיגִי דְּבָעֵינַן, כִּי פְּלִיגִי בְּדִין מָמוֹן. מָר סָבַר: הֶיתֵּר אֲכִילָה בָּעֵינַן, דִּין מָמוֹן לָא בָּעֵינַן, וּמָר סָבַר: דִּין מָמוֹן נָמֵי בָּעֵינַן. מַאי בֵּינַיְיהוּ?
human_translation: Rather, with regard to permission to eat everyone agrees that we require When they disagree is with regard to monetary Sage holds: We require permission to eat it, we do not require monetary And Sage holds: We also require monetary what is the between them?
llm_translation: Rather: in the case of excess eating, everyone agrees that we do not differentiate, for they differentiate in monetary law. One Sage holds: we require excess eating, we do not require monetary law, and the other Sage holds: we require monetary law as well. What is the practical difference between them?

hebrew_text: אִיכָּא בֵּינַיְיהוּ מַעֲשֵׂר שֵׁנִי שֶׁבִּירוּשָׁלַיִם. אַלִּיבָּא דְּרַבִּי מֵאִיר, לְמַאן דְּאָמַר לְפִי שֶׁאֵין בָּהּ הֶיתֵּר אֲכִילָה — הֲרֵי יֵשׁ בָּהּ הֶיתֵּר אֲכִילָה, לְמַאן דְּאָמַר לְפִי שֶׁאֵין בָּהּ דִּין מָמוֹן — מַעֲשֵׂר שֵׁנִי מָמוֹן גָּבוֹהַּ הוּא.
human_translation: There is between them second tithe in Jerusalem, and according to the opinion of Rabbi Meir, to the one who said: because there is no permission to eat there is permission to eat And to the one who said: because it has no monetary second tithe is property of God
llm_translation: There is a difference between them regarding the second tithe in Jerusalem. According to the opinion of Rabbi Meir, one who says that it does not have the permissibility of eating - behold, it has the permissibility of eating. And one who says that it does not have the status of monetary value - the second tithe is indeed of monetary value.

hebrew_text: תִּסְתַּיַּים דְּרַבִּי אַסִּי דְּאָמַר לְפִי שֶׁאֵין בָּהּ דִּין מָמוֹן. דְּאָמַר רַבִּי אַסִּי: אֶתְרוֹג שֶׁל מַעֲשֵׂר שֵׁנִי, לְדִבְרֵי רַבִּי מֵאִיר — אֵין אָדָם יוֹצֵא בּוֹ יְדֵי חוֹבָתוֹ בְּיוֹם טוֹב, לְדִבְרֵי חֲכָמִים — אָדָם יוֹצֵא בּוֹ יְדֵי חוֹבָתוֹ בְּיוֹם טוֹב. תִּסְתַּיַּים.
human_translation: Conclude that Rabbi Asi who said because there is no monetary as Rabbi Asi said: an etrog of second tithe, according to the statement of Rabbi Meir, a person does not fulfill his obligation with it on Festival. According to the Rabbis, a person fulfills his obligation with it on Festival. conclude
llm_translation: The completion of Rabbi Assi who said because it does not have monetary judgment. Rabbi Assi said: A second tithe etrog, according to the words of Rabbi Meir - a person does not fulfill his obligation with it on the festival day, according to the words of the Sages - a person fulfills his obligation with it on the festival day. The completion.

hebrew_text: גּוּפָא. אָמַר רַבִּי אַסִּי: אֶתְרוֹג שֶׁל מַעֲשֵׂר שֵׁנִי, לְדִבְרֵי רַבִּי מֵאִיר — אֵין אָדָם יוֹצֵא בּוֹ יְדֵי חוֹבָתוֹ בְּיוֹם טוֹב. לְדִבְרֵי חֲכָמִים — אָדָם יוֹצֵא בּוֹ יְדֵי חוֹבָתוֹ בְּיוֹם טוֹב. מַצָּה שֶׁל מַעֲשֵׂר שֵׁנִי, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי מֵאִיר — אֵין אָדָם יוֹצֵא בָּהּ יְדֵי חוֹבָתוֹ בַּפֶּסַח, לְדִבְרֵי חֲכָמִים — אָדָם יוֹצֵא בָּהּ יְדֵי חוֹבָתוֹ בַּפֶּסַח. עִיסָּה שֶׁל מַעֲשֵׂר שֵׁנִי, לְדִבְרֵי רַבִּי מֵאִיר — פְּטוּרָה מִן הַחַלָּה, לְדִבְרֵי חֲכָמִים — חַיֶּיבֶת בַּחַלָּה.
human_translation: the matter itself, Rabbi Asi said: an etrog of second tithe, according to the statement of Rabbi Meir, a person does not fulfill his obligation with it on Festival. According to the Rabbis, a person fulfills his obligation with it on Festival. matza of second tithe, according to Rabbi Meir, a person does not fulfill his obligation with it on Passover According to the Rabbis, a person fulfills his obligation with it on Passover. according to Rabbi Meir, dough of second tithe is exempt from the obligation of ḥalla . According to the Rabbis, it is subject to the obligation of ḥalla .
llm_translation: Body. Rabbi Assi said: A citron of second tithe, according to the words of Rabbi Meir - a person does not fulfill his obligation with it on a festival day. According to the Sages - a person fulfills his obligation with it on a festival day. Matzah of second tithe, according to the words of Rabbi Meir - a person does not fulfill his obligation with it on Passover, according to the Sages - a person fulfills his obligation with it on Passover. Dough of second tithe, according to the words of Rabbi Meir - exempt from challah, according to the Sages - obligated in challah.

hebrew_text: מַתְקֵיף לַהּ רַב פָּפָּא: בִּשְׁלָמָא עִיסָּה, כְּתִיב: ״רֵאשִׁית עֲרִיסוֹתֵיכֶם״. אֶתְרוֹג נָמֵי — כְּתִיב: ״לָכֶם״, מִשֶּׁלָּכֶם. אֶלָּא מַצָּה, מִי כְּתִיב ״מַצַּתְכֶם״? אָמַר רַבָּה בַּר שְׁמוּאֵל, וְאִיתֵּימָא רַב יֵימַר בַּר שֶׁלֶמְיָא: אָתְיָא ״לֶחֶם״ ״לֶחֶם״. כְּתִיב הָכָא ״לֶחֶם עוֹנִי״, וּכְתִיב הָתָם
human_translation: Rav Pappa strongly objects to this: Granted, dough, it is written: “The first of your dough, etrog too it is written: “ for yourselves,” from your own However, matza , Is it written: Your matza ? Rabba bar Shmuel said, and some say Rav Yeimar bar Shelamya derived bread bread It is written here, “Bread of affliction” and it is written there,
llm_translation: Rav Papa objects to this: With regard to dough, it is written: "The first of your dough." Concerning the etrog, it is written: "For you," meaning from yours. But with regard to matzah, where is it written "your matzot"? Rabbah bar Shmuel said, and some say Rav Yeimar bar Shelemya said: It comes from "bread," "bread." It is written here "bread of affliction," and it is written there...

hebrew_text: ״וְהָיָה בַּאֲכׇלְכֶם מִלֶּחֶם הָאָרֶץ״. מָה לְהַלָּן — מִשֶּׁלָּכֶם וְלֹא מִשֶּׁל מַעֲשֵׂר, אַף כָּאן — מִשֶּׁלָּכֶם וְלֹא מִשֶּׁל מַעֲשֵׂר.
human_translation: “And it shall be when you eat of the bread of the land Just as there, from yours and not from tithe, here too, from yours and not from tithe.
llm_translation: "And it shall be when you eat of the bread of the land." Just as there - from yours and not from the tithe, so too here - from yours and not from the tithe.

hebrew_text: לֵימָא מְסַיַּיע לֵיהּ: עִיסָּה שֶׁל מַעֲשֵׂר שֵׁנִי פְּטוּרָה מִן הַחַלָּה, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי מֵאִיר. וַחֲכָמִים אוֹמְרִים: חַיֶּיבֶת בַּחַלָּה. לֵימָא מְסַיַּיע לֵיהּ? הִיא הִיא!
human_translation: Let us say that supports Dough of second tithe is exempt from ḥalla ; the statement of Rabbi Meir. And the Rabbis say: It is subject to ḥalla . Let us say it supports his it is itself.
llm_translation: Let us say it supports him: Dough of second tithe is exempt from hallah, the words of Rabbi Meir. And the sages say: It is obligated in hallah. Let us say it supports him? It is the same!

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא: מִדִּבְהָא פְּלִיגִי — בְּהָא נָמֵי פְּלִיגִי, אוֹ דִלְמָא: שָׁאנֵי עִיסָּה, דְּאָמַר קְרָא ״עֲרִיסוֹתֵיכֶם״ ״עֲרִיסוֹתֵיכֶם״ תְּרֵי זִימְנֵי.
human_translation: Rather, from the fact that they disagree this they disagree that as well? Or perhaps, dough is different because the verse states: “Your dough…your dough” twice.
llm_translation: Rather: they argue in this matter - they argue in this matter, or perhaps: it is different with dough, as the verse says "your dough" twice.

hebrew_text: שֶׁל תְּרוּמָה טְמֵאָה פְּסוּלָה. דְּלֵית בָּהּ הֶיתֵּר אֲכִילָה.
human_translation: of impure teruma is unfit. that there is no permission to eat it.
llm_translation: Of terumah impure disqualified. For there is not in it permission eating.

hebrew_text: וְשֶׁל תְּרוּמָה טְהוֹרָה לֹא יִטּוֹל. פְּלִיגִי בַּהּ רַבִּי אַמֵּי וְרַבִּי אַסִּי, חַד אָמַר: מִפְּנֵי שֶׁמַּכְשִׁירָהּ, וְחַד אָמַר: מִפְּנֵי שֶׁמַּפְסִידָהּ.
human_translation: And of pure teruma , one should not take it Rabbi Ami and Rabbi Asi disagreed about this. One said: because one renders it susceptible And one said: because he damages it.
llm_translation: And of pure terumah he shall not take. They dispute it: Rabbi Ammi and Rabbi Assi. One said: Because it makes it fit, and one said: Because it causes it to lose.

hebrew_text: מַאי בֵּינַיְיהוּ? כְּגוֹן שֶׁקָּרָא עָלֶיהָ שֵׁם חוּץ מִקְּלִיפָּתָהּ חִיצוֹנָה. לְמַאן דְּאָמַר מִפְּנֵי שֶׁמַּכְשִׁירָהּ — אִיכָּא. לְמַאן דְּאָמַר מִפְּנֵי שֶׁמַּפְסִידָהּ — לֵיכָּא.
human_translation: What is between them? where one accorded the status exclusion of the peel, According to the one who said: Because one renders it susceptible there is according to the one who said: Because he damages there is no
llm_translation: What is the difference between them? For example, if one recites upon it a name, except for its outer peel. According to the one who says that this validates it - there is. According to the one who says that this invalidates it - there is not.

hebrew_text: וְאִם נָטַל כְּשֵׁרָה. לְמַאן דְּאָמַר מִפְּנֵי שֶׁאֵין בָּהּ הֶיתֵּר אֲכִילָה — הֲרֵי יֵשׁ בָּהּ הֶיתֵּר אֲכִילָה, לְמַאן דְּאָמַר לְפִי שֶׁאֵין בָּהּ דִּין מָמוֹן — הֲרֵי יֵשׁ בָּהּ דִּין מָמוֹן.
human_translation: And if he took it is fit, According to the one who said because there is no permission to eat there is permission to eat it. According to the one who said because it has no monetary it has monetary
llm_translation: And if he took it properly. According to the one who says because it does not have the permission of eating - behold, it has the permission of eating, according to the one who says because it does not have the law of money - behold, it has the law of money.

hebrew_text: וְשֶׁל דְּמַאי. מַאי טַעְמַיְיהוּ דְּבֵית הִלֵּל — כֵּיוָן דְּאִי בָּעֵי מַפְקַר לְהוּ לְנִכְסֵיהּ וְהָוֵי עָנִי וַחֲזֵי לֵיהּ, הַשְׁתָּא נָמֵי ״לָכֶם״ קָרֵינָא בֵּיהּ. דִּתְנַן: מַאֲכִילִין אֶת הָעֲנִיִּים דְּמַאי וְאֶת אַכְסַנְיָא דְּמַאי.
human_translation: of demai . What is the rationale Beit Hillel, Because, if one wants, he could declare all of his property ownerless, and he would be a pauper, fit for his Now too, it is considered for yourselves.” As we learned One may feed the impoverished demai , and soldiers [ akhsanya ] demai .
llm_translation: And regarding Demai. What is the reason of Beit Hillel? - Since if he wants to declare his property ownerless and become poor, and they see him, now "to you" is read in it. For we learned: One may feed the poor with Demai and the guests of Demai.

hebrew_text: וּבֵית שַׁמַּאי, עָנִי לָא אָכֵיל דְּמַאי, דִּתְנַן: (אֵין) מַאֲכִילִין הָעֲנִיִּים דְּמַאי וְאֶת הָאַכְסְנָאִים דְּמַאי, וְאָמַר רַב הוּנָא: תָּנָא, בֵּית שַׁמַּאי אוֹמְרִים: אֵין מַאֲכִילִין אֶת הָעֲנִיִּים וְאֶת הָאַכְסְנָאִים דְּמַאי, וּבֵית הִלֵּל אוֹמְרִים: מַאֲכִילִין אֶת הָעֲנִיִּים דְּמַאי וְאֶת הָאַכְסְנָאִים דְּמַאי.
human_translation: And Beit Shammai A pauper may not eat demai , as we learned in One may not feed the impoverished demai and soldiers demai . And Rav Huna said: It was taught Beit Shammai say: One may not feed the impoverished demai and soldiers demai . And Beit Hillel say: One may feed the impoverished demai and soldiers demai .
llm_translation: House of Shammai, a poor person does not eat Demai, as we learned: They do not feed the poor with Demai and the guests with Demai. And Rav Huna said: It was taught, House of Shammai says: They do not feed the poor and the guests with Demai, and House of Hillel says: They feed the poor and the guests with Demai.

hebrew_text: שֶׁל מַעֲשֵׂר שֵׁנִי שֶׁבִּירוּשָׁלַיִם. לְמַאן דְּאָמַר מִפְּנֵי שֶׁמַּכְשִׁירָהּ — הֲרֵי מַכְשִׁירָהּ, לְמַאן דְּאָמַר מִפְּנֵי שֶׁמַּפְסִידָהּ — הֲרֵי מַפְסִידָה.
human_translation: of second tithe in Jerusalem, one may not take it, According to the one who says because one renders it susceptible here too, he renders it susceptible. According to the one who says because one damages here too, he damages
llm_translation: Tithe of the second tithe in Jerusalem. According to the one who says because it makes it valid - behold, it makes it valid. According to the one who says because it causes it to be lost - behold, it causes it to be lost.

hebrew_text: וְאִם נָטַל — כְּשֵׁרָה. לְמַאן דְּאָמַר מִפְּנֵי שֶׁאֵין בָּהּ הֶיתֵּר אֲכִילָה — דִּבְרֵי הַכֹּל. לְמַאן דְּאָמַר לְפִי שֶׁאֵין בָּהּ דִּין מָמוֹן — הָא מַנִּי רַבָּנַן הִיא.
human_translation: And if one took it is fit. According to the one who said because there is no permission to eat everyone, agrees according to the one who said because it has no monetary value, whose is this the Rabbis,
llm_translation: "And if he took - it is valid. According to the one who says because it does not have the permit of eating - the words of everyone. According to the one who says because it does not have monetary value - behold, it is the opinion of the Rabbis."

hebrew_text: עָלְתָה חֲזָזִית. אָמַר רַב חִסְדָּא: דָּבָר זֶה רַבֵּינוּ הַגָּדוֹל אֲמָרוֹ, הַמָּקוֹם יִהְיֶה בְּעֶזְרוֹ: לֹא שָׁנוּ אֶלָּא בְּמָקוֹם אֶחָד, אֲבָל בִּשְׁנַיִם וּשְׁלֹשָׁה מְקוֹמוֹת — כָּשֵׁר. אֲמַר לֵיהּ רָבָא: אַדְּרַבָּה, בִּשְׁנַיִם וּשְׁלֹשָׁה מְקוֹמוֹת הָוֵה לֵיהּ כִּמְנוּמָּר, וּפָסוּל.
human_translation: If boil-like blemishes arose Rav Ḥisda said: This statement was stated by our great rabbi, and may the Omnipresent to his assistance. taught only in one place; however, in two or three places it is fit. said to two or three places, it is as if speckled and is unfit.
llm_translation: The text reads: "An issue of doubt arose. Rav Ḥisdah said: Our great teacher said this matter: The place shall be in his favor. They only stated this in one place, but in two or three places - it is valid. Rava said to him: Adrabah, in two or three places it is like a spotted garment, and it is invalid."

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא: אִי אִתְּמַר אַסֵּיפָא אִתְּמַר. עַל מִיעוּטוֹ — כָּשֵׁר. אָמַר רַב חִסְדָּא: דָּבָר זֶה רַבֵּינוּ הַגָּדוֹל אֲמָרוֹ, וְהַמָּקוֹם יִהְיֶה בְּעֶזְרוֹ: לֹא שָׁנוּ אֶלָּא בְּמָקוֹם אֶחָד, אֲבָל בִּשְׁנַיִם וּשְׁלֹשָׁה מְקוֹמוֹת — הָוֵה לֵיהּ כִּמְנוּמָּר, וּפָסוּל. אָמַר רָבָא: וְעַל חוֹטְמוֹ — וַאֲפִילּוּ בְּמַשֶּׁהוּ נָמֵי פָּסוּל.
human_translation: Rather, If was stated, it was stated concerning the latter clause If boil-like blemishes arose on its minority, it is fit. Rav Ḥisda said: This statement was stated by our great rabbi, and may the Omnipresent to his assistance. taught only in one place. However, in two or three places it is as if speckled, and unfit. Rava said: on its upper, end, even if is any size, unfit.
llm_translation: Rather: if it was stated in the latter clause, it was stated. Due to its scarcity - it is valid. Rav Ḥisdah said: This matter, our great Rabbi stated, and the place shall be in his assistance: They only stated this in one place, but in two or three places - it is like a leopard to him, and invalid. Rava said: And on his nostril - even with its support, it is also invalid.

hebrew_text: נִטְּלָה פִּטְמָתוֹ. תָּנָא רַבִּי יִצְחָק בֶּן אֶלְעָזָר: נִטְּלָה בּוּכְנָתוֹ.
human_translation: If its pitam was removed, Rabbi Yitzḥak ben Elazar taught if its pestle was removed.
llm_translation: He took his staff. It was taught: Rabbi Yitzhak ben Elazar said: He took his flask.

hebrew_text: נִקְלַף. אָמַר רָבָא: הַאי אֶתְרוֹגָא דְּאַגְלֵיד כַּאֲהִינָא סוּמָּקָא — כְּשֵׁרָה. וְהָא אֲנַן תְּנַן: נִקְלַף — פָּסוּל! לָא קַשְׁיָא,
human_translation: was peeled Rava said: This etrog that was peeled like a red date is fit. But didn’t we learn was peeled not difficult;
llm_translation: "Niklaf. Amar Rava: Hai etroga deaglaid ka'ahina sumaka - k'shira. Veha anan tenan: Niklaf - pasul! La kashya," "Niklaf. Rava said: This etrog that has its peel removed like the eye of a needle - it is valid. But we learned: Niklaf - it is invalid! There is no difficulty."

hebrew_text: הָא בְּכוּלַּהּ, הָא בְּמִקְצָתַהּ.
human_translation: this in all of it That in part of it
llm_translation: This one in its entirety, this one in part.

hebrew_text: נִסְדַּק, נִיקַּב. תָּנֵי עוּלָּא בַּר חֲנִינָא: נִיקַּב נֶקֶב מְפוּלָּשׁ — בְּמַשֶּׁהוּ, וְשֶׁאֵינוֹ מְפוּלָּשׁ — בִּכְאִיסָּר.
human_translation: split pierced. Ulla bar Ḥanina taught: pierced with a hole that goes through with any the hole does not go through with the size of an issar
llm_translation: נִסְדַּק, נִיקַּב. תָּנֵי עוּלָּא בַּר חֲנִינָא: נִיקַּב נֶקֶב מְפוּלָּשׁ — בְּמַשֶּׁהוּ, וְשֶׁאֵינוֹ מְפוּלָּשׁ — בִּכְאִיסָּר. It was pierced, it was perforated. Ulla, son of Chanina, taught: If it was perforated with a protrusion - with its full width, and if it was not perforated with a protrusion - with a needle.

hebrew_text: בָּעֵי רָבָא: נוֹלְדוּ בָּאֶתְרוֹג סִימָנֵי טְרֵפָה, מַהוּ? מַאי קָמִיבַּעְיָא לֵיהּ? אִי נִקְלַף — תְּנֵינָא! אִי נִסְדַּק — תְּנֵינָא! אִי נִיקַּב — תְּנֵינָא!
human_translation: Rava raised a dilemma: signs of a tereifa developed in the etrog , what is What is the dilemma he is raising? If peeled, we learned If split, we learned if pierced, we learned
llm_translation: Ba'ei Rava: Noldu ba'etrog simanei t'reifah, mah? Mai kamibai leih? Iy niklaf - tenina! Iy nisdaq - tenina! Iy nikav - tenina!

hebrew_text: כִּי קָא מִיבַּעְיָא לֵיהּ כִּדְעוּלָּא אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: רֵיאָה שֶׁנִּשְׁפְּכָה כְּקִיתוֹן — כְּשֵׁרָה. וְאָמַר רָבָא: וְהוּא דְּקָיְימִי סִימְפּוֹנַהָא. הָא לָא קָיְימִי סִימְפּוֹנַהָא — טְרֵפָה. הָכָא מַאי? דִּלְמָא הָתָם הוּא דְּלָא שָׁלֵיט בַּהּ אַוֵּירָא, הֲדַר בָּרְיָא, אֲבָל הָכָא דְּשָׁלֵיט בַּהּ אַוֵּירָא — סָרוֹחֵי מַסְרְחָא, אוֹ דִלְמָא לָא שְׁנָא?
human_translation: When he raises the dilemma, like which Ulla Rabbi Yoḥanan said: A lung whose can be poured like a pitcher, kosher. And Rava said: And that is where the bronchia are intact. if the bronchia are not intact, it is tereifa . here What Perhaps it is there, where the air does not affect it can recover, However, here, where the air affects it, it decays Or, perhaps no different.
llm_translation: When he asked him as usual, Rabbi Yohanan said: "If the lung was punctured like a sieve - it is kosher." And Rava said: "And this is when its membrane is intact. If its membrane is not intact - it is treif." What is the difference here? Perhaps there, where it does not have control over it, the air, it will heal, but here, where it has control over the air - it will deteriorate, or perhaps not?

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע: אֶתְרוֹג תָּפוּחַ סָרוּחַ, כָּבוּשׁ, שָׁלוּק, כּוּשִׁי, לָבָן, וּמְנוּמָּר — פָּסוּל. אֶתְרוֹג כְּכַדּוּר — פָּסוּל, וְיֵשׁ אוֹמְרִים: אַף הַתְּיוֹם. אֶתְרוֹג הַבּוֹסֶר — רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא פּוֹסֵל, וַחֲכָמִים מַכְשִׁירִין. גִּדְּלוֹ בִּדְפוּס וַעֲשָׂאוֹ כְּמִין בְּרִיָּה אַחֶרֶת — פָּסוּל.
human_translation: Come hear An etrog that is tafuaḥ , saruaḥ , pickled, boiled, Cushite a white or a speckled is unfit. An etrog like a ball is unfit, and some say even a twin, an etrog that is unripe, Rabbi Akiva deems it unfit, and the Rabbis deem it fit. If he grew in a mold and shaped it like a different entity, unfit.
llm_translation: Come and hear: an etrog that is swollen, sunken, peeled, black, white, or streaked — it is invalid. An etrog shaped like a ball — it is invalid, and some say: even today. An etrog that is budding — Rabbi Akiva disqualifies it, and the sages deem it fit. If it grew in a mold and was made like a different creature — it is invalid.

hebrew_text: קָתָנֵי מִיהַת תָּפוּחַ סָרוּחַ, מַאי לָאו: תָּפוּחַ מִבַּחוּץ, וְסָרוּחַ מִבִּפְנִים! לָא, אִידִי וְאִידִי מִבַּחוּץ, וְלָא קַשְׁיָא: הָא דִּתְפַח אַף עַל גַּב דְּלָא סְרַח, הָא דִּסְרַח אַף עַל גַּב דְּלָא תְּפַח.
human_translation: In any event, it teaches tafuaḥ saruaḥ What, is it not tafuaḥ on the outside and saruaḥ on the inside? No, this and that are on the outside. And this not difficult, this is where it swelled even though it did not decay, and that is where it decayed even though it did not swell.
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: If a swollen apple, what is the law? The apple is swollen on the outside, and the swelling is on the inside! No, both the apple and the swelling are on the outside, and there is no difficulty: Just as this one swells even though it is not rotten, so too, that one rots even though it is not swollen.

hebrew_text: אָמַר מָר: אֶתְרוֹג כּוּשִׁי — פָּסוּל. וְהָתַנְיָא: כּוּשִׁי כָּשֵׁר, דּוֹמֶה לְכוּשִׁי — פָּסוּל! אֲמַר אַבָּיֵי: כִּי תְּנַן נָמֵי מַתְנִיתִין, דּוֹמֶה לְכוּשִׁי תְּנַן. רָבָא אָמַר: לָא קַשְׁיָא הָא לַן, וְהָא לְהוּ.
human_translation: The Master said A Cushite etrog is unfit. But isn’t it taught A Cushite etrog is fit, similar to a Cushite is unfit. Abaye said: When we learned in the mishna too, we learned similar to a Cushite Rava said: not difficult; this, is for us And that, is for them
llm_translation: Master said: Ethiopian etrog — invalid. And it was taught: Ethiopian is valid, resembling Ethiopian — invalid! Abaye said: For we learned in a Mishnah, resembling Ethiopian we learned. Rava said: There is no difficulty here for us, and there for them.

hebrew_text: אֶתְרוֹג הַבּוֹסֶר — רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא פּוֹסֵל וַחֲכָמִים מַכְשִׁירִין. אָמַר רַבָּה: רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא וְרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן אָמְרוּ דָּבָר אֶחָד. רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא — הָא דַּאֲמַרַן. רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן מַאי הִיא — (דְּתַנְיָא:) רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן פּוֹטֵר אֶת הָאֶתְרוֹגִים בְּקוֹטְנָן.
human_translation: an unripe etrog , Rabbi Akiva deems it unfit, and the Rabbis deem it fit. Rabba said: Rabbi Akiva and Rabbi Shimon said one statement. Rabbi Akiva that which we said; Rabbi Shimon, what is as it is taught Rabbi Shimon exempts etrogim in their small
llm_translation: The citron of Bozrah - Rabbi Akiva disqualifies it, and the sages deem it fit. Rabbah said: Rabbi Akiva and Rabbi Shimon agreed on one matter. Rabbi Akiva - this is what we said. What is Rabbi Shimon's opinion? (As it was taught:) Rabbi Shimon exempts small citrons.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ אַבָּיֵי: דִּלְמָא לָא הִיא, עַד כָּאן לָא קָאָמַר רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא הָכָא, דְּבָעֵינַן ״הָדָר״ וְלֵיכָּא, אֲבָל הָתָם — כְּרַבָּנַן סְבִירָא לֵיהּ.
human_translation: Abaye said to Perhaps that is not Rabbi Akiva stated his opinion only here, as we require beauty [ hadar ] and there is none however, there, he holds in accordance with the Rabbis
llm_translation: He said to him Abaye: perhaps it is not so, until here Rabbi Akiva did not say here, that we need "hadar" and it is not necessary, but there - like the Rabbis hold.

hebrew_text: אִי נָמֵי, עַד כָּאן לָא קָאָמַר רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן הָתָם, אֶלָּא דִּכְתִיב: ״עַשֵּׂר תְּעַשֵּׂר אֵת כׇּל תְּבוּאַת זַרְעֶךָ״, כְּדֶרֶךְ שֶׁבְּנֵי אָדָם מוֹצִיאִין לִזְרִיעָה. אֲבָל הָכָא, כְּרַבָּנַן סְבִירָא לֵיהּ.
human_translation: Alternatively, Rabbi Shimon stated his opinion only there as it is written: “You shall surely tithe all the produce of your planting, typical for people to take it out for sowing; However, here he holds in accordance with the Rabbis,
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Ii namei, ad kan lo ka'amar Rabbi Shimon hataam, ela dikhtiv: 'aser te'aser et kol tevu'at zarekha', kederekh shebnei adam motzi'in lizri'ah. Aval haka, kerabanan sevira lei." English translation: "Here too, Rabbi Shimon did not say that, but it is written: 'You shall surely tithe all the yield of your seed,' in the manner that people give for sowing. But here, the Rabbis hold a different opinion."

hebrew_text: וְתוּ לָא מִידֵּי.
human_translation: And nothing more
llm_translation: And come to not from the hand of.

hebrew_text: גִּדְּלוֹ בִּדְפוּס וַעֲשָׂאוֹ כְּמִין בְּרִיָּה אַחֶרֶת — פָּסוּל. אָמַר רָבָא: לֹא שָׁנוּ אֶלָּא כְּמִין בְּרִיָּה אַחֶרֶת, אֲבָל כִּבְרִיָּיתוֹ — כָּשֵׁר. פְּשִׁיטָא! כְּמִין בְּרִיָּה אַחֶרֶת (תְּנַן)! לָא צְרִיכָא, דַּעֲבִידָא דַּפֵּי דַּפֵּי.
human_translation: If he grew in a mold and shaped it like a different species, unfit. Rava said: taught only like a different species; however, like its own species, it is fit. obvious; Like a different species, is taught No, is necessary that is shaped many planks,
llm_translation: They enlarged it in a mold and made it like a different creature - it is invalid. Rava said: They only taught that it must be like a different creature, but if it is like its original creation - it is valid. It is obvious! Like a different creature (we learned)! It is not necessary, for it is the work of a craftsman.

hebrew_text: אִיתְּמַר אֶתְרוֹג שֶׁנְּקָבוּהוּ עַכְבָּרִים, אָמַר רַב: אֵין זֶה הָדָר. אִינִי? וְהָא רַבִּי חֲנִינָא מְטַבֵּיל בֵּהּ וְנָפֵיק בֵּהּ! וּלְרַבִּי חֲנִינָא קַשְׁיָא מַתְנִיתִין!
human_translation: It was stated an etrog that mice pierced. Rav said: That is not beautiful. Is that so? But wouldn’t Rabbi Ḥanina dip and fulfill his obligation with it? And for Rabbi Ḥanina, the mishna is difficult,
llm_translation: It was said: A citron that mice punctured, Rav said: This is not beautiful. Is it not so? But Rabbi Chanina immersed it and took it out! And for Rabbi Chanina there is a contradiction from the Mishnah!

hebrew_text: בִּשְׁלָמָא מַתְנִיתִין לְרַבִּי חֲנִינָא לָא קַשְׁיָא: כָּאן בְּיוֹם טוֹב רִאשׁוֹן, כָּאן בְּיוֹם טוֹב שֵׁנִי. אֶלָּא לְרַב קַשְׁיָא! אָמַר לְךָ רַב: שָׁאנֵי עַכְבָּרִים דִּמְאִיסִי.
human_translation: Granted, for Rabbi Ḥanina, the mishna is not difficult, here, on the first day of the festival there, the second day of the Festival However, to Rav, difficult, Rav said to you: Mice are different, as they are repulsive.
llm_translation: In truth, the Mishnah to Rabbi Chanina is not difficult: here on the first day of Yom Tov, here on the second day of Yom Tov. Rather, it is difficult for Rav! Rav said to you: The difference is regarding mice that are repulsive.

hebrew_text: אִיכָּא דְּאָמְרִי, אָמַר רַב: זֶה הָדָר, דְּהָא רַבִּי חֲנִינָא מְטַבֵּיל בֵּהּ וְנָפֵיק בֵּהּ. וּלְרַבִּי חֲנִינָא קַשְׁיָא מַתְנִיתִין! לָא קַשְׁיָא: כָּאן בְּיוֹם טוֹב רִאשׁוֹן, כָּאן בְּיוֹם טוֹב שֵׁנִי.
human_translation: Some say Rav said That is beautiful, as Rabbi Ḥanina would dip and fulfill his obligation with it, And for Rabbi Ḥanina, the mishna is difficult, The mishna is not difficult; here, on the first day of the festival there, the second day of the Festival
llm_translation: There is one who says, Rav said: This is the Hadar, for Rabbi Chanina immerses in it and emerges from it. And for Rabbi Chanina, there is a contradiction from the Mishnah! It is not a contradiction: here on the first day of the festival, here on the second day of the festival.

hebrew_text: אֶתְרוֹג קָטָן וְכוּ׳. אָמַר רַפְרָם בַּר פָּפָּא: כְּמַחְלוֹקֶת כָּאן, כָּךְ מַחְלוֹקֶת בַּאֲבָנִים מְקוּרְזָלוֹת. דְּתַנְיָא: בְּשַׁבָּת שָׁלֹשׁ אֲבָנִים מְקוּרְזָלוֹת מוּתָּר לְהַכְנִיס לְבֵית הַכִּסֵּא, וְכַמָּה שִׁיעוּרָן? רַבִּי מֵאִיר אוֹמֵר: כֶּאֱגוֹז, רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: כְּבֵיצָה.
human_translation: of a small etrog . Rafram bar Pappa said: Like the dispute here, so is the dispute with regard to rounded stones, as it was taught On Shabbat three rounded stones may be taken into the bathroom And what is their measure? Rabbi Meir says: A walnut-bulk; Rabbi Yehuda says: An egg-bulk.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: A small etrog, etc. Raphram bar Papa said: Just as there is a dispute here, so too there is a dispute regarding iron stones. As it was taught: On Shabbat, three iron stones are permitted to be brought into the bathroom, and what is their measure? Rabbi Meir says: Like a nut, Rabbi Yehuda says: Like an egg.

hebrew_text: וּבַגָּדוֹל כְּדֵי שֶׁיֹּאחַז כּוּ׳. תַּנְיָא, אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹסֵי: מַעֲשֶׂה בְּרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא שֶׁבָּא לְבֵית הַכְּנֶסֶת וְאֶתְרוֹגוֹ עַל כְּתֵפוֹ! אָמַר לוֹ רַבִּי יְהוּדָה: מִשָּׁם רְאָיָה? אַף הֵם אָמְרוּ לוֹ: אֵין זֶה הָדָר.
human_translation: And in a large so that one could hold It is taught Rabbi Yosei said: an incident involving Rabbi Akiva, who came to the synagogue, and his etrog on his shoulder. Rabbi Yehuda said to him: proof from there? too, said to him: That is not beauty.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "And with a large citron the size that one can grasp." It was taught: Rabbi Yosei said: There was an incident with Rabbi Akiva that he came to the synagogue and his etrog was on his shoulder! Rabbi Yehuda said to him: Is this a proper sight there? They also said to him: This is not proper.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ אֵין אוֹגְדִין אֶת הַלּוּלָב אֶלָּא בְּמִינוֹ, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי יְהוּדָה. רַבִּי מֵאִיר אוֹמֵר: אֲפִילּוּ (בְּחוּט) בִּמְשִׁיחָה. אָמַר רַבִּי מֵאִיר: מַעֲשֶׂה בְּאַנְשֵׁי יְרוּשָׁלַיִם שֶׁהָיוּ אוֹגְדִין אֶת לוּלְבֵיהֶן בְּגִימוֹנִיּוֹת שֶׁל זָהָב. אָמְרוּ לוֹ: בְּמִינוֹ הָיוּ אוֹגְדִין אוֹתוֹ מִלְּמַטָּה.
human_translation: One may bind the lulav only with its own species; the statement of Rabbi Yehuda. Rabbi Meir says: even with a string with a cord. Rabbi Meir said: an incident involving the men of Jerusalem who would bind their lulavim with gold rings. said to him: They would bind it with its own species beneath
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: One may only bind the lulav with its own kind, the words of Rabbi Yehuda. Rabbi Meir says: Even with a thread of linen. Rabbi Meir said: There was an incident with the people of Jerusalem who would bind their lulavs with golden threads. They said to him: They would bind it from below.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ אָמַר רָבָא: אֲפִילּוּ בְּסִיב, אֲפִילּוּ בְּעִיקָּרָא דְּדִיקְלָא. וְאָמַר רָבָא: מַאי טַעְמֵיהּ דְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה, קָסָבַר: לוּלָב צָרִיךְ אֶגֶד, וְאִי מַיְיתֵי מִינָא אַחֲרִינָא — הָוֵה חַמְשָׁה מִינֵי.
human_translation: Rava said: even with fibers and even with the trunk of the date palm. And Rava said: What is the rationale of Rabbi Yehuda? He holds that a lulav requires binding, and if one brings another species there will be five species
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Gemara said Rava: Even in the round part, even in the main part of the palm tree. And Rava said: What is the reason of Rabbi Yehuda, he holds: the lulav needs a binding, and if one brings another species - there are five species.

hebrew_text: וְאָמַר רָבָא: מְנָא אָמֵינָא לַהּ דְּסִיב וְעִיקָּרָא דְּדִיקְלָא מִינָא דְלוּלַבָּא הוּא — דְּתַנְיָא: ״בַּסּוּכּוֹת תֵּשְׁבוּ״, סוּכָּה שֶׁל כׇּל דָּבָר, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי מֵאִיר. רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: אֵין סוּכָּה נוֹהֶגֶת אֶלָּא בְּאַרְבָּעָה מִינִים שֶׁבַּלּוּלָב. וְהַדִּין נוֹתֵן: וּמָה לוּלָב שֶׁאֵין נוֹהֵג בַּלֵּילוֹת כְּבַיָּמִים, אֵינוֹ נוֹהֵג אֶלָּא בְּאַרְבַּעַת מִינִין, סוּכָּה שֶׁנּוֹהֶגֶת בַּלֵּילוֹת כְּבַיָּמִים — אֵינוֹ דִּין שֶׁלֹּא תְּהֵא אֶלָּא בְּאַרְבַּעַת מִינִין!
human_translation: And Rava said: From where do I say that fibers and the trunk of the date palm are the species of the lulav ? as it is taught “You shall reside in sukkot a sukka of any material, the statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yehuda says: sukka is practiced only with the four species of the lulav And, logic dictates Just as lulav , which is not practiced at night as it is during the day, is practiced only with the four species, sukka , which is practiced at night as it is during the day, is it not right that its should be only from the four species?
llm_translation: And Rava said: From where do I say that the sitting and the essence of the palm branch is the lulav itself? - As it was taught: "You shall dwell in booths," a booth that is fit for anything, the words of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yehuda says: A booth is only valid with the four species of the lulav. And similarly, he gives the ruling: Just as the lulav, which is not used at night like during the day, is only used with the four species, a booth that is used at night like during the day - it is not proper unless with the four species!

hebrew_text: אָמְרוּ לוֹ: כׇּל דִּין שֶׁאַתָּה דָּן תְּחִלָּתוֹ לְהַחְמִיר וְסוֹפוֹ לְהָקֵל — אֵינוֹ דִּין.
human_translation: said to him: any inference that you infer initially to be stringent, but ultimately to be lenient, is not a inference.
llm_translation: They said to him: "Every judgment that you judge, begin with being stringent and end with being lenient - is not a judgment."

hebrew_text: לֹא מָצָא אַרְבַּעַת מִינִין יְהֵא יוֹשֵׁב וּבָטֵל, וְהַתּוֹרָה אָמְרָה: ״בַּסּוּכּוֹת תֵּשְׁבוּ שִׁבְעַת יָמִים״ — סוּכָּה שֶׁל כׇּל דָּבָר. וְכֵן בְּעֶזְרָא אוֹמֵר: ״צְאוּ הָהָר וְהָבִיאוּ עֲלֵי זַיִת וַעֲלֵי עֵץ שֶׁמֶן וַעֲלֵי הֲדַס וַעֲלֵי תְמָרִים וַעֲלֵי עֵץ עָבוֹת (וַעֲשׂוּ) סוּכּוֹת כַּכָּתוּב״!
human_translation: one did not find four species he will sit idly and the Torah states: “You shall reside in sukkot a sukka of any material. Likewise, in Ezra, it says: “Go forth unto the mount, and fetch olive branches, and pine branches, and myrtle branches, and palm branches, and branches of a dense-leaved tree, to make sukkot , as it is written”
llm_translation: He did not find four species, he should sit and be idle, and the Torah said: "You shall dwell in booths for seven days" - a booth made of anything. And similarly, in Ezra it says: "Go out to the mountain and bring olive branches, oil tree branches, myrtle branches, palm branches, and thick tree branches (and make) booths as it is written!"

hebrew_text: וְרַבִּי יְהוּדָה סָבַר: הָנֵי — לִדְפָנוֹת, עֲלֵי הֲדַס וַעֲלֵי תְמָרִים וַעֲלֵי עֵץ עָבוֹת — לִסְכָךְ. וּתְנַן: מְסַכְּכִין בִּנְסָרִין, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי יְהוּדָה. אַלְמָא סִיב וְעִיקָּרָא דְּדִיקְלָא מִינָא דְלוּלַבָּא הוּא, שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ.
human_translation: And Rabbi Yehuda holds: These for the walls Myrtle branches, palm branches, and branches of a dense-leaved tree, for the roofing. And we learned One roof with boards; the statement of Rabbi Yehuda. apparently, fibers and the trunk of the date palm are the species of the lulav . conclude from it
llm_translation: Rabbi Yehuda holds: those — for walls, branches of myrtle and branches of palm trees and branches of thick trees — for covering. And we learned: they cover with twigs, the words of Rabbi Yehuda. Therefore, the reason and essence of the palm tree species is that it is heard from it.

hebrew_text: וּמִי אָמַר רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אַרְבַּעַת מִינִין — אִין, מִידֵּי אַחֲרִינָא — לָא? וְהָתַנְיָא: סִיכְּכָהּ בִּנְסָרִים שֶׁל אֶרֶז שֶׁיֵּשׁ בָּהֶן אַרְבָּעָה טְפָחִים — דִּבְרֵי הַכֹּל פְּסוּלָה. אֵין בָּהֶן אַרְבָּעָה טְפָחִים — רַבִּי מֵאִיר פּוֹסֵל, וְרַבִּי יְהוּדָה מַכְשִׁיר. וּמוֹדֶה רַבִּי מֵאִיר שֶׁאִם יֵשׁ בֵּין נֶסֶר לְנֶסֶר כִּמְלֹא נֶסֶר — שֶׁמַּנִּיחַ פְּסָל בֵּינֵיהֶן, וּכְשֵׁירָה!
human_translation: And did Rabbi Yehuda say the four species, yes, other materials, no, But isn’t it taught one roofed with cedar [ erez ] boards that have four in their everyone agrees unfit. they do not have four in their Rabbi Meir deems it unfit and Rabbi Yehuda deems it fit. And Rabbi Meir concedes that if there is between board board complete of a board, one places waste between and is fit.
llm_translation: And who said, Rabbi Yehuda, four species — no, from another source — yes? And it was taught: If one interwove it with cedar branches that have four handbreadths — the words of everyone, it is invalid. If they do not have four handbreadths — Rabbi Meir disqualifies it, and Rabbi Yehuda permits it. And Rabbi Meir concedes that if there is space between one cedar branch and another like the size of a cedar branch — he places invalidation between them, and it is valid!

hebrew_text: מַאי ״אֶרֶז״ — הֲדַס, כִּדְרַבָּה בַּר רַב הוּנָא. דְּאָמַר רַבָּה בַּר רַב הוּנָא, אָמְרִי בֵּי רַב: עֲשָׂרָה מִינֵי אֲרָזִים הֵן, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״אֶתֵּן בַּמִּדְבָּר אֶרֶז שִׁיטָּה וַהֲדַס וְגוֹ׳״.
human_translation: What is erez myrtle in accordance with which Rabba bar Rav Huna as Rabba bar Rav Huna said they say in the school of Rav: There are ten types of erez , as it is stated: “I will place in the wilderness the cedar [ erez ], the acacia-tree, the myrtle,
llm_translation: What is "אֶרֶז" — myrtle, as Rabba bar Rav Huna said. For Rabba bar Rav Huna said, the students of Rav said: There are ten types of cedars, as it is stated: "I will plant in the wilderness the cedar, the acacia tree, and the myrtle, and so forth."

hebrew_text: רַבִּי מֵאִיר אוֹמֵר אֲפִילּוּ בִּמְשִׁיחָה כּוּ׳. תַּנְיָא אָמַר רַבִּי מֵאִיר: מַעֲשֶׂה בְּיַקִּירֵי יְרוּשָׁלַיִם שֶׁהָיוּ אוֹגְדִין אֶת לוּלְבֵיהֶן בְּגִימוֹנִיּוֹת שֶׁל זָהָב. אָמְרוּ לוֹ: מִשָּׁם רְאָיָה?! בְּמִינוֹ הָיוּ אוֹגְדִין אוֹתוֹ מִלְּמַטָּה.
human_translation: Rabbi Meir says: even with a cord. It is taught Rabbi Meir said: an incident involving the prominent of Jerusalem who would bind their lulavim with gold rings. said to him: proof from there? They would bind it with its own species beneath
llm_translation: Rabbi Meir says: Even in the Messianic era. It was taught: Rabbi Meir said: There was an incident with the aristocrats of Jerusalem who would bind their lulavs with golden threads. They said to him: Is there a demonstration from there?! They would bind it from below.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לְהוּ רַבָּה לְהָנְהוּ מְגַדְּלֵי הוֹשַׁעְנָא דְּבֵי רֵישׁ גָּלוּתָא: כִּי גָּדְלִיתוּ הוֹשַׁעְנָא דְּבֵי רֵישׁ גָּלוּתָא, שַׁיִּירוּ בֵּיהּ בֵּית יָד — כִּי הֵיכִי דְּלָא תֶּיהְוֵי חֲצִיצָה.
human_translation: Rabba said to those who bind the four species [ hoshana ] of the house of the Exilarch: When you bind the four species of the house of the Exilarch, leave a handgrip on it so that there will not be an interposition
llm_translation: He said to them, Rabba said to those tower builders of the house of exile: When you build the tower of the house of exile, leave a handbreadth in it, so that it will not be a breach.

hebrew_text: רָבָא אָמַר: כׇּל לְנָאוֹתוֹ — אֵינוֹ חוֹצֵץ. וְאָמַר רַבָּה: לָא לִינְקוֹט אִינִישׁ הוֹשַׁעְנָא בְּסוּדָרָא, דְּבָעֵינָא לְקִיחָה תַּמָּה וְלֵיכָּא. וְרָבָא אָמַר: לְקִיחָה עַל יְדֵי דָּבָר אַחֵר — שְׁמָהּ לְקִיחָה.
human_translation: Rava said: any to beautify does not interpose. And Rabba said: Let a person not take the four species with a cloth [ sudara ] since I require a complete taking, and there is none And Rava said: taking by means of another object is considered taking.
llm_translation: Rava said: "Any for his pleasure - not a barrier." And Rabba said: "A person should not be negligent in his arrangement, for I desire a clear purchase and there is none." And Rava said: "A purchase through another object - its name is a purchase."

hebrew_text: אָמַר רָבָא: מְנָא אָמֵינָא לַהּ דִּלְקִיחָה עַל יְדֵי דָּבָר אַחֵר שְׁמָהּ לְקִיחָה, דִּתְנַן: אֵזוֹב קָצָר — מְסַפְּקוֹ בְּחוּט וּבְכוּשׁ, וְטוֹבֵל וּמַעֲלֶה וְאוֹחֵז בָּאֵזוֹב וּמַזֶּה. אַמַּאי — ״וְלָקַח״ ״וְטָבַל״ אָמַר רַחֲמָנָא! אֶלָּא לָאו, שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ: לְקִיחָה עַל יְדֵי דָּבָר אַחֵר — שְׁמָהּ לְקִיחָה.
human_translation: Rava said: From where do I say that taking by means of another object is considered taking? as we learned hyssop short one renders it sufficiently by a string or a spindle, and dips removes grasps the hyssop, and sprinkles why the Merciful One say “And take and dip Rather, not conclude from taking by means of another object is considered taking?
llm_translation: Rava said: From where do I say to her that if she picked it up through another object, its name is considered a picking up, as we learned: "If one cuts hyssop - he wraps it with a thread and with a reed, and he dips it and brings it up and holds the hyssop and sprinkles." Why? "And he shall take" "and he shall dip" - the Merciful One said! Rather, no, learn from it: if it was picked up through another object - its name is considered a picking up.

hebrew_text: מִמַּאי? דִּלְמָא שָׁאנֵי הָתָם, כֵּיוָן דְּחַבְּרֵיהּ — כְּגוּפֵיהּ דָּמֵי. אֶלָּא מֵהָכָא: נָפַל מִשְּׁפוֹפֶרֶת לַשּׁוֹקֶת — פָּסוּל.
human_translation: From where Perhaps it is different there; since he attached is like itself. Rather, from here: fell from the tube into the trough unfit,
llm_translation: From where? Perhaps it is different there, since once it is connected - it is considered like its own body. Rather, from here: if it fell from the window to the marketplace - it is disqualified.

hebrew_text: הָא הִפִּילוֹ הוּא — כָּשֵׁר. אַמַּאי? ״וְלָקְחוּ״ ״וְנָתַן״ אָמַר רַחֲמָנָא! אֶלָּא לָאו, שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ: לְקִיחָה עַל יְדֵי דָּבָר אַחֵר — שְׁמָהּ לְקִיחָה.
human_translation: he spilled it is fit. Why? the Merciful One say “And they shall take and he places Rather, not conclude from it taking by means of another object is considered taking?
llm_translation: The one who dropped it - it is valid. Why? "And they shall take" "and give" the Merciful One said! Rather, no, learn from it: taking through another object - its name is taking.

hebrew_text: וְאָמַר רַבָּה: לָא לִדוּץ אִינִישׁ לוּלַבָּא בְּהוֹשַׁעְנָא, דְּדִלְמָא נָתְרִי טַרְפֵי וְהָוֵי חֲצִיצָה. וְרָבָא אָמַר: מִין בְּמִינוֹ אֵינוֹ חוֹצֵץ.
human_translation: And Rabba said let a person not insert the lulav into the four species, as perhaps the leaves fall and will an interposition And Rava said: species does not interpose before species.
llm_translation: And Rabba said: A person should not shake the lulav on Hoshana, lest the leaves fall off and it becomes a barrier. And Rava said: A species within its own kind does not create a barrier.

hebrew_text: וְאָמַר רַבָּה: לָא לִיגּוֹז אִינִישׁ לוּלַבָּא בְּהוֹשַׁעְנָא, דְּמִשְׁתַּיְּירִי הוּצֵא וְהָוֵי חֲצִיצָה. וְרָבָא אָמַר: מִין בְּמִינוֹ אֵינוֹ חוֹצֵץ.
human_translation: And Rabba said: Let a person not cut the lulav in the four species, as leaves will become detached and will an interposition And Rava said: species does not interpose before species.
llm_translation: And Rabba said: One should not steal a lulav on Hoshana, for when it dries up, it becomes a barrier. And Rava said: A species within its own kind does not create a barrier.

hebrew_text: וְאָמַר רַבָּה: הֲדַס שֶׁל מִצְוָה — אָסוּר לְהָרִיחַ בּוֹ, אֶתְרוֹג שֶׁל מִצְוָה — מוּתָּר לְהָרִיחַ בּוֹ. מַאי טַעְמָא? הֲדַס דִּלְרֵיחָא קָאֵי, כִּי אַקְצְיֵיה — מֵרֵיחָא אַקְצְיֵיה. אֶתְרוֹג דְּלַאֲכִילָה קָאֵי כִּי אַקְצְיֵיה — מֵאֲכִילָה אַקְצְיֵיה.
human_translation: And Rabba said: It is prohibited to smell the myrtle branch of the mitzva. it is permitted to smell the etrog of the mitzva. What is the reason a myrtle branch, which exists for fragrance, when he sets it aside he sets it aside from fragrance. an etrog , which exists for eating, when he sets it aside he sets it aside from eating.
llm_translation: And Rabba said: A myrtle branch of a mitzvah - it is forbidden to smell it, an etrog of a mitzvah - it is permitted to smell it. What is the reason? The myrtle is standing for its fragrance, when you cut it - it is for its fragrance. The etrog is standing for eating, when you cut it - it is for eating.

hebrew_text: וְאָמַר רַבָּה: הֲדַס בִּמְחוּבָּר — מוּתָּר לְהָרִיחַ בּוֹ, אֶתְרוֹג בִּמְחוּבָּר — אָסוּר לְהָרִיחַ בּוֹ. מַאי טַעְמָא? הֲדַס דִּלְהָרִיחַ קָאֵי, אִי שָׁרֵית לֵיהּ — לָא אָתֵי לְמִגְזְיֵיהּ. אֶתְרוֹג, דְּלַאֲכִילָה קָאֵי, אִי שָׁרֵית לֵיהּ — אָתֵי לְמִגְזְיֵיהּ.
human_translation: And Rabba said: a myrtle branch, while it is attached permitted to smell it an etrog , while it is attached it is prohibited to smell it. What is the reason a myrtle branch, which exists to smell if you permit him he will not come to cut it. an etrog , which exists for eating, if you permit him he will come to cut it
llm_translation: And Rabba said: Myrtle that is bound together - it is permitted to smell it, an Etrog that is bound together - it is forbidden to smell it. What is the reason? Myrtle, since it stands for smelling, if you permit it to him - he will not come to pluck it. Etrog, since it stands for eating, if you permit it to him - he will come to pluck it.

hebrew_text: וְאָמַר רַבָּה: לוּלָב — בְּיָמִין, וְאֶתְרוֹג — בִּשְׂמֹאל. מַאי טַעְמָא? הָנֵי תְּלָתָא מִצְוֹת, וְהַאי חֲדָא מִצְוָה. אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַבִּי יִרְמְיָה לְרַבִּי זְרִיקָא: מַאי טַעַם לָא מְבָרְכִינַן אֶלָּא ״עַל נְטִילַת לוּלָב״ — הוֹאִיל וְגָבוֹהַּ מִכּוּלָּן. וְלַגְבְּהֵיהּ לְאֶתְרוֹג וּלְבָרֵיךְ! אֲמַר לֵיהּ: הוֹאִיל וּבְמִינוֹ גָּבוֹהַּ מִכּוּלָּן.
human_translation: And Rabba said: lulav in the right and the etrog in the left. What is the reason These three mitzvot, and this is one mitzva. Rabbi Yirmeya said to Rabbi Zerika: What is the reason we recite the blessing only About taking the lulav , Since it highest of them all And let him lift the etrog and recite the blessing said to him Since of its species is the tallest of them all,
llm_translation: Rabba said: The lulav - in the right hand, and the etrog - in the left. What is the reason? Those three are commandments, and this is one commandment. Rabbi Yirmeya said to Rabbi Zerika: What is the reason we only recite the blessing of "al netilat lulav" - since it is taller than all of them. So let him raise it and recite! He said to him: Since it is taller than all of them in its kind.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ וְהֵיכָן הָיוּ מְנַעַנְעִין? בְּ״הוֹדוּ לַה׳״ תְּחִילָּה וָסוֹף, וּבְ״אָנָּא ה׳ הוֹשִׁיעָה נָּא״ — דִּבְרֵי בֵּית הִלֵּל. וּבֵית שַׁמַּאי אוֹמְרִין: אַף בְּ״אָנָּא ה׳ הַצְלִיחָה נָּא״. אָמַר רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא: צוֹפֶה הָיִיתִי בְּרַבָּן גַּמְלִיאֵל וְרַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ, שֶׁכׇּל הָעָם הָיוּ מְנַעְנְעִין אֶת לוּלְבֵיהֶן, וְהֵם לֹא נַעְנָעוֹ אֶלָּא בְּ״אָנָּא ה׳ הוֹשִׁיעָה נָּא״.
human_translation: And where would they wave at “Thank the Lord, at the beginning and the end and at “Lord, please save us” the statement of Beit Hillel. And Beit Shammai say: even at “Lord, please grant us success” Rabbi Akiva said: I was observing Rabban Gamliel and Rabbi Yehoshua that all the people were waving their lulavim , and them waved only at: “Lord, please save us,”
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: And where would they wave the lulav? "Hodu Lashem" at the beginning and end, and "Ana Hashem Hoshia Na" - these are the words of Beit Hillel. And Beit Shammai say: Also "Ana Hashem Hatzlicha Na." Rabbi Akiva said: I observed Rabban Gamliel and Rabbi Yehoshua, that all the people would wave their lulavs, but they would only wave it with "Ana Hashem Hoshia Na."

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ נִעְנוּעַ מַאן דְּכַר שְׁמֵיהּ? הָתָם קָאֵי: כׇּל לוּלָב שֶׁיֵּשׁ בּוֹ שְׁלֹשָׁה טְפָחִים כְּדֵי לְנַעְנֵעַ בּוֹ — כָּשֵׁר, וְקָאָמַר: הֵיכָן מְנַעְנְעִין.
human_translation: waving, who mentioned it? is basing there Any lulav that has three handbreadths sufficient to wave with it, is fit is saying: Where would they wave
llm_translation: Gemara: Who mentioned his name? There it stands: "Every lulav that has three handbreadths in order to shake with it — is valid," and it says: "Where do we shake?"

hebrew_text: תְּנַן הָתָם: שְׁתֵּי הַלֶּחֶם וּשְׁנֵי כִּבְשֵׂי עֲצֶרֶת כֵּיצַד הוּא עוֹשֶׂה? מַנִּיחַ שְׁתֵּי הַלֶּחֶם עַל גַּבֵּי שְׁנֵי הַכְּבָשִׂין, וּמַנִּיחַ יָדוֹ תַּחְתֵּיהֶן, וּמֵנִיף וּמוֹלִיךְ וּמֵבִיא, מַעֲלֶה וּמוֹרִיד. שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״אֲשֶׁר הוּנַף וַאֲשֶׁר הוּרָם״.
human_translation: We learned there the two loaves and the two lambs Shavuot , how does he perform He places the two loaves atop the two lambs, and places his hand beneath them, and waves to and fro and he raises and lowers as it is stated: “Which is waved and which is lifted”
llm_translation: We learned there: Two loaves and two lambs of Shavuot, how does one do it? He places the two loaves on top of the two lambs, and he places his hand underneath them, and he waves and brings, raises and lowers. As it is stated: "Which were waved and which were raised."

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: מוֹלִיךְ וּמֵבִיא לְמִי שֶׁהָאַרְבַּע רוּחוֹת שֶׁלּוֹ, מַעֲלֶה וּמוֹרִיד לְמִי שֶׁהַשָּׁמַיִם וְהָאָרֶץ שֶׁלּוֹ. בְּמַעְרְבָא מַתְנוּ הָכִי: אָמַר רַבִּי חָמָא בַּר עוּקְבָא אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹסֵי בְּרַבִּי חֲנִינָא: מוֹלִיךְ וּמֵבִיא כְּדֵי לַעֲצוֹר רוּחוֹת רָעוֹת, מַעֲלֶה וּמוֹרִיד כְּדֵי לַעֲצוֹר טְלָלִים רָעִים. אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹסֵי בַּר אָבִין וְאִיתֵּימָא רַבִּי יוֹסֵי בַּר זְבִידָא: זֹאת אוֹמֶרֶת
human_translation: Rabbi Yoḥanan said: He moves to and fro to He Whom the four directions are His. He raises and lowers to He Whom the heavens and earth are His. In the West, they taught as follows. Rabbi Ḥama bar Ukva said Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, said: He moves to and fro in order to a halt harmful winds, he raises and lowers in order to halt harmful dews Rabbi Yosei bar Avin said, and some say Rabbi Yosei bar Zevila That is to say,
llm_translation: Rabbi Yochanan said: One who circumcises and brings the child to whom his four winds belong, raises and lowers him to whom the heavens and the earth belong. In the West, they taught thus: Rabbi Chama bar Ukva said in the name of Rabbi Yosei bar Chanina: One who circumcises and brings the child in order to stop evil winds, raises and lowers him in order to stop harmful dews. Rabbi Yosei bar Avin said, and some say it was Rabbi Yosei bar Zavida: This is what it means.

hebrew_text: שְׁיָרֵי מִצְוָה מְעַכְּבִין אֶת הַפּוּרְעָנוּת. שֶׁהֲרֵי תְּנוּפָה שְׁיָרֵי מִצְוָה הִיא — וְעוֹצֶרֶת רוּחוֹת וּטְלָלִים רָעִים. וְאָמַר רָבָא: וְכֵן בְּלוּלָב. רַב אַחָא בַּר יַעֲקֹב מַמְטֵי לֵיהּ וּמַיְיתֵי לֵיהּ, אֲמַר: דֵּין גִּירָא בְּעֵינֵיהּ דְּסִטְנָא. וְלָאו מִלְּתָא הִיא, מִשּׁוּם דְּאָתֵי לְאִיגָּרוֹיֵי בֵּיהּ.
human_translation: non-essential aspects of a mitzva avert calamity, as waving is a non-essential aspect of the mitzva, and it halts harmful winds and dews. And Rava said: And likewise with a lulav , Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov move to and fro, he would say: This is an arrow in the eye of Satan, That is not manner as come to incite him
llm_translation: The remnants of a mitzvah delay punishment. For the waving of the remnants of a mitzvah is effective, withholding evil spirits and harmful dew. And Rava said: The same applies to the lulav. Rav Acha bar Yaakov would wrap it and unwrap it, saying: The spine of the lulav is visible like a thorn. And this is not the main point, because it comes to strengthen it.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ מִי שֶׁבָּא בַּדֶּרֶךְ וְלֹא הָיָה בְּיָדוֹ לוּלָב לִיטּוֹל — לִכְשֶׁיִּכָּנֵס לְבֵיתוֹ, יִטּוֹל עַל שֻׁלְחָנוֹ. לֹא נָטַל שַׁחֲרִית — יִטּוֹל בֵּין הָעַרְבַּיִם, שֶׁכׇּל הַיּוֹם כָּשֵׁר לְלוּלָב.
human_translation: one who was coming the way and did not have a lulav in his hand to take when he enters his house he take at his table. If he did not take morning, he take it in the afternoon, as the entire day is suited for lulav .
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: One who is on the road and does not have a lulav to take - when he enters his house, he should take it on his table. If he did not take it in the morning - he should take it between the evenings, for the entire day is fit for the lulav.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ אָמְרַתְּ, נוֹטְלוֹ עַל שֻׁלְחָנוֹ; לְמֵימְרָא דְּמַפְסֵיק? וּרְמִינְהִי: אִם הִתְחִילוּ — אֵין מַפְסִיקִין! אָמַר רַב סָפְרָא: לָא קַשְׁיָא, הָא — דְּאִיכָּא שְׁהוּת בַּיּוֹם, הָא — דְּלֵיכָּא שְׁהוּת בַּיּוֹם.
human_translation: you said he takes it at his table. That is to say that he interrupts And raises a contradiction if they started they need not interrupt Rav Safra said: not difficult, that where there is opportunity in the day; this where there is no opportunity in the day.
llm_translation: The Gemara said: He takes it on his table; to say that it interrupts? And ask: If they began - they do not interrupt! Rav Safra said: It is not difficult, here - where there is a break during the day, here - where there is no break during the day.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רָבָא: מַאי קוּשְׁיָא? דִּילְמָא הָא דְּאוֹרָיְיתָא, הָא דְּרַבָּנַן. אֶלָּא אָמַר רָבָא: אִי קַשְׁיָא — הָא קַשְׁיָא: לִכְשֶׁיִּכָּנֵס לְבֵיתוֹ — נוֹטְלוֹ עַל שֻׁלְחָנוֹ, אַלְמָא דְּמַפְסֵיק, וַהֲדַר תָּנֵי: לֹא נָטַל שַׁחֲרִית — יִטּוֹל בֵּין הָעַרְבַּיִם. אַלְמָא לָא מַפְסֵיק!
human_translation: Rava said: What is the difficulty? Perhaps this is by Torah law, that is by rabbinic law, Rather, Rava said: If a difficulty, difficulty: when he enters his house he take at his table. Apparently, one interrupt And then is taught: If he did not take morning, he take it in the afternoon. Apparently, he not interrupt
llm_translation: Rava said: What is the difficulty? Perhaps this law is from the Torah, and this law is from the Rabbis. Rather, Rava said: If it is difficult, this is the difficulty: when he enters his house, he should take it the meal on his table, implying that he interrupts the meal, and then he teaches: If he did not take the morning meal, he should take it between the evenings. Implying that he does not interrupt!

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב סָפְרָא: לָא קַשְׁיָא, הָא — דְּאִיכָּא שְׁהוּת בַּיּוֹם, הָא — דְּלֵיכָּא שְׁהוּת בַּיּוֹם.
human_translation: Rav Safra said: not difficult. This where there is opportunity in the day; that where there is no opportunity in the day.
llm_translation: Rav Safra said: It is not difficult, this - that there is dwelling during the day, this - that there is no dwelling during the day.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי זֵירָא: מַאי קוּשְׁיָא? דִּלְמָא: מִצְוָה לְאַפְסוֹקֵי, וְאִי לָא פְּסַיק — יִטּוֹל בֵּין הָעַרְבַּיִם, שֶׁכׇּל הַיּוֹם כָּשֵׁר לְלוּלָב. אֶלָּא אָמַר רַבִּי זֵירָא: לְעוֹלָם כִּדְאָמְרִינַן מֵעִיקָּרָא, וּדְקַשְׁיָא לָךְ הָא דְּאוֹרָיְיתָא הָא דְּרַבָּנַן — הָכָא בְּיוֹם טוֹב שֵׁנִי דְּרַבָּנַן עָסְקִינַן.
human_translation: Rabbi Zeira said: What is the difficulty? perhaps a mitzva to interrupt but if he did not interrupt he take it in the afternoon, as the entire day is suited for lulav . Rather, Rabbi Zeira said: Actually, as we said initially, And that which you found difficult, this is by Torah law that is by rabbinic law, here, we are dealing with the second day of the Festival by rabbinic law.
llm_translation: Rabbi Zeira said: What is the difficulty? Perhaps it is a mitzvah to cut the palm branches, and if not cut, one should place them between the beams, for the entire day is valid for the lulav. Rather, Rabbi Zeira said: Always follow the principle we say from the outset, and the difficulty for you is this - that which is from the Torah, that which is from the Rabbis - here we are dealing with the second day of a festival, which is a Rabbinic enactment.

hebrew_text: דַּיְקָא נָמֵי, מִדְּקָתָנֵי: מִי שֶׁבָּא בַּדֶּרֶךְ וְאֵין בְּיָדוֹ לוּלָב. דְּאִי סָלְקָא דַעְתָּךְ בְּיוֹם טוֹב רִאשׁוֹן — מִי שְׁרֵי?!
human_translation: is also precise from that it teaches: One who was coming along the way and does not have a lulav in his hand. As, if it enters your mind the first day of the Festival, is it permitted
llm_translation: Precisely it is stated, as it is taught: One who is on the way and does not have a lulav. For if it enters your mind on the first day of the festival - is he exempt?!

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ מִי שֶׁהָיָה עֶבֶד אוֹ אִשָּׁה אוֹ קָטָן מַקְרִין אוֹתוֹ — עוֹנֶה אַחֲרֵיהֶן מַה שֶּׁהֵן אוֹמְרִין, וְתָבֹא לוֹ מְאֵירָה. אִם הָיָה גָּדוֹל מַקְרֶא אוֹתוֹ, עוֹנֶה אַחֲרָיו ״הַלְלוּיָהּ״. מָקוֹם שֶׁנָּהֲגוּ לִכְפּוֹל — יִכְפּוֹל, לִפְשׁוֹט — יִפְשׁוֹט, לְבָרֵךְ — יְבָרֵךְ, הַכֹּל כְּמִנְהַג הַמְּדִינָה.
human_translation: one for whom a Canaanite slave, a woman, or a minor was reciting he repeats after them what they are saying And may a curse come to him If an adult male was reciting on his he answers: Halleluya , a place where they were accustomed to repeat he, repeat to plainly, he plainly. In a place where the custom is to recite a blessing he should recite a blessing. Everything is in accordance with the local custom
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: One who was a slave, a woman, or a minor may read the Torah portion, and others respond after them what they say, and the one who reads should come to the light. If one who is an adult reads, others respond after him "Hallelujah." In a place where they are accustomed to repeat the reading, they should repeat; where they are accustomed to translate, they should translate; where they are accustomed to bless, they should bless. Everything follows the custom of the locality.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: בֶּאֱמֶת אָמְרוּ בֵּן מְבָרֵךְ לְאָבִיו. וְעֶבֶד מְבָרֵךְ לְרַבּוֹ, וְאִשָּׁה מְבָרֶכֶת לְבַעְלָהּ, אֲבָל אָמְרוּ חֲכָמִים: תָּבֹא מְאֵירָה לְאָדָם שֶׁאִשְׁתּוֹ וּבָנָיו מְבָרְכִין לוֹ.
human_translation: The Sages taught: Actually, they said a son may recite a blessing his father, and a slave may recite a blessing his master, and a woman may recite a blessing her husband, but the Sages said: May a curse come to a man his wife and children to recite a blessing on his behalf.
llm_translation: The Sages taught: In truth they said, a son blesses his father. And a slave blesses his master, and a woman blesses her husband. But the Sages said: A bright light shall come to a person, for his wife and children bless him.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רָבָא:
human_translation: Rava said:
llm_translation: Rava said:

hebrew_text: הִלְכְתָא גִּיבָּרָתָא אִיכָּא לְמִשְׁמַע מִמִּנְהֲגָא דְהַלֵּילָא. הוּא אוֹמֵר: ״הַלְלוּיָהּ״, וְהֵן אוֹמְרִים: ״הַלְלוּיָהּ״ — מִכָּאן שֶׁמִּצְוָה לַעֲנוֹת ״הַלְלוּיָהּ״.
human_translation: Many significant halakhot can be learned from the custom of hallel recites: “ Halleluya ” and recites: Halleluya , From here that a mitzva to respond: Halleluya .
llm_translation: The halakha is like the opinion that there is room to learn from the custom of Hillel. He says, "Hallelujah," and they say, "Hallelujah" - from here it is a commandment to respond "Hallelujah."

hebrew_text: הוּא אוֹמֵר: ״הַלָּלוּ עַבְדֵי ה׳״, וְהֵן אוֹמְרִין: ״הַלְלוּיָהּ״ — מִכָּאן שֶׁאִם הָיָה גָּדוֹל מַקְרֶא אוֹתוֹ, עוֹנֶה אַחֲרָיו ״הַלְלוּיָהּ״. הוּא אוֹמֵר: ״הוֹדוּ לַה׳״, וְהֵן אוֹמְרִים: ״הוֹדוּ לַה׳״ — מִכָּאן שֶׁמִּצְוָה לַעֲנוֹת רָאשֵׁי פְרָקִים. אִתְּמַר נָמֵי, אָמַר רַב חָנָן בַּר רָבָא: מִצְוָה לַעֲנוֹת רָאשֵׁי פְרָקִים.
human_translation: recites: “Give praise, servants of the Lord” and recites: Halleluya , From here that if an adult male was reciting on his he answers: Halleluya . He recites: “Thank the Lord, and they respond: “Thank the Lord, From here that a mitzva to respond the beginnings of chapters. It was also stated Rav Ḥanan bar Rava said: a mitzva to respond the beginnings of chapters.
llm_translation: He says: "These are the servants of Hashem," and they say: "Hallelujah" - from here that if one reads the verse, he responds after it "Hallelujah." He says: "Give thanks to Hashem," and they say: "Give thanks to Hashem" - from here it is a commandment to respond at the heads of chapters. It was stated similarly, Rav Hanan son of Rava said: It is a commandment to respond at the heads of chapters.

hebrew_text: הוּא אוֹמֵר: ״אָנָא ה׳ הוֹשִׁיעָה נָּא״, וְהֵן אוֹמְרִים: ״אָנָּא ה׳ הוֹשִׁיעָה נָּא״, — מִכָּאן שֶׁאִם הָיָה קָטָן מַקְרֶא אוֹתוֹ, עוֹנִין אַחֲרָיו מַה שֶׁהוּא אוֹמֵר.
human_translation: recites: “Lord, please save us” and recites: “Lord, please save us,” From here that if a minor was reciting on one’s he recites after him what he says.
llm_translation: He says: "Ana Hashem Hoshia Na," and they say: "Ana Hashem Hoshia Na," - from here that if a minor reads it, others respond after him what he says.

hebrew_text: הוּא אוֹמֵר: ״אָנָא ה׳ הַצְלִיחָה נָּא״ וְהֵן אוֹמְרִים: ״אָנָּא ה׳ הַצְלִיחָה נָּא״, מִכָּאן שֶׁאִם בָּא לִכְפּוֹל — כּוֹפֵל. הוּא אוֹמֵר: ״בָּרוּךְ הַבָּא״, וְהֵן אוֹמְרִים: ״בְּשֵׁם ה׳״ — מִכָּאן לְשׁוֹמֵעַ כְּעוֹנֶה.
human_translation: recites: “Lord, please grant us success,” and recites Lord, please grant us success” From here that if comes to repeat he repeat recites: “Blessed is one who comes” and recites “In the name of the Lord” From here one who hears is equivalent to one who recites
llm_translation: He says: "Ana Hashem hatzlicha na" and they say: "Ana Hashem hatzlicha na," from here that if one comes to bend down - he should bend down. He says: "Baruch haba," and they say: "B'shem Hashem" - from here to the listener is like the responder.

hebrew_text: בְּעוֹ מִינֵּיהּ מֵרַבִּי חִיָּיא בַּר אַבָּא: שָׁמַע וְלֹא עָנָה, מַהוּ? אֲמַר לְהוּ: חַכִּימַיָּא וְסָפְרַיָּא וְרֵישֵׁי עַמָּא וְדָרָשַׁיָּא אָמְרוּ: שָׁמַע וְלֹא עָנָה — יָצָא.
human_translation: raised a dilemma before Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba: one heard and did not recite what is He said to them the Sages, and the schoolteachers, and the heads of the nation, and the interpreters said: One who heard and did not recite fulfilled
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Be'u minei meRabbi Chiya bar Abba: shama ve'lo ana, mah? Amar lehu: chakimaya ve'sofriya ve'reishei amma ve'darshaya amru: shama ve'lo ana - yatza." English translation: "They asked Rabbi Chiya bar Abba: 'He heard but did not answer, what is the ruling?' He said to them: The wise ones, the scribes, the heads of the people, and the scholars said: 'He heard but did not answer - he is exempt.'"

hebrew_text: אִתְּמַר נָמֵי, אָמַר רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן פַּזִּי אָמַר רַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ בֶּן לֵוִי מִשּׁוּם בַּר קַפָּרָא: מִנַּיִן לְשׁוֹמֵעַ כְּעוֹנֶה — דִּכְתִיב: ״אֶת (הַדְּבָרִים) אֲשֶׁר קָרָא (יֹאשִׁיָּהוּ)״. וְכִי יֹאשִׁיָּהוּ קְרָאָן? וַהֲלֹא שָׁפָן קְרָאָן, דִּכְתִיב: ״וַיִּקְרָאֵהוּ שָׁפָן (אֵת כׇּל הַדְּבָרִים הָאֵלֶּה) לִפְנֵי הַמֶּלֶךְ״. אֶלָּא, מִכָּאן לְשׁוֹמֵעַ כְּעוֹנֶה.
human_translation: It was also stated Rabbi Shimon ben Pazi said Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said in the name of Bar Kappara: From where one who hears is equivalent to one who recites as it is written: “All the words of the book which has read” And did Josiah read them? Didn’t Shaphan read them, as it is written: “And Shaphan read it before the king” Rather, from here that one who hears is equivalent to one who recites
llm_translation: It was stated: Naḥmei said, Rabbi Shimon ben Pazi said in the name of Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi from the school of Bar Kappara: From where do we derive that one who hears is like one who responds? As it is written: "The words that Yoshiyahu read." But did Yoshiyahu read them? Wasn't Shafan the one who read them, as it is written: "Shafan read it (all these words) before the king"? Rather, from here we derive that one who hears is like one who responds.

hebrew_text: וְדִילְמָא בָּתַר דִּקְרָאנְהוּ שָׁפָן קְרָא יֹאשִׁיָּהוּ? אָמַר רַב אַחָא בַּר יַעֲקֹב: לָא סָלְקָא דַּעְתָּךְ, דִּכְתִיב: ״יַעַן רַךְ לְבָבְךָ וַתִּכָּנַע לִפְנֵי ה׳ בְּשׇׁמְעֲךָ (אֶת הַדְּבָרִים הָאֵלֶּה)״ — ״בְּשׇׁמְעֲךָ״ וְלָא ״בְּקׇרְאֲךָ״.
human_translation: And perhaps after Shaphan read them Josiah read Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov said: not enter your mind as it is written: “Because your heart was tender and you humbled yourself before the Lord when you heard “When you heard” and not: When you read.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Perhaps after they read the verse, "Shaphan the scribe read it before the king," Josiah changed his mind? Rav Acha bar Yaakov said: Your opinion is not correct, as it is written: "Because your heart was tender and you humbled yourself before the Lord when you heard these words" — "when you heard" and not "when you read." English translation:

hebrew_text: אָמַר רָבָא: לָא לֵימָא אִינִישׁ ״בָּרוּךְ הַבָּא״ וַהֲדַר ״בְּשֵׁם ה׳״, אֶלָּא ״בָּרוּךְ הַבָּא בְּשֵׁם ה׳״, בַּהֲדָדֵי. (אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַב סָפְרָא:
human_translation: Rava said: Let a person not recite: “Blessed is one who comes,” and then, “In the name of the Lord.” Rather, “Blessed is one who comes in the name of the Lord.” Rav Safra said to
llm_translation: Rava said: One should not say "Baruch haba" and then "B'shem Hashem," rather "Baruch haba b'shem Hashem" together. This is the correct way. (Rav Safra said to him: ...)

hebrew_text: מֹשֶׁה, שַׁפִּיר קָאָמְרַתְּ?! אֶלָּא הָתָם וְהָכָא אַסּוֹקֵי מִילְּתָא הִיא, וְלֵית לַן בַּהּ). אָמַר רָבָא: לָא לֵימָא אִינִישׁ ״יְהֵא שְׁמֵיהּ רַבָּא״ וַהֲדַר ״מְבָרַךְ״, אֶלָּא ״יְהֵא שְׁמֵיהּ רַבָּא מְבָרַךְ״ בַּהֲדָדֵי. אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַב סָפְרָא: מֹשֶׁה, שַׁפִּיר קָאָמְרַתְּ?! אֶלָּא, הָתָם וְהָכָא אַסּוֹקֵי מִילְּתָא הוּא, וְלֵית לַן בַּהּ.
human_translation: Moses, did you speak well? rather, there and here, is the conclusion of the matter, and we have no with it, Rava said: Let a person not recite May His great name, and then, Be blessed. Rather, May His great name be blessed. Rav Safra said to Moses, did you speak well? rather, there and here, is the conclusion of the matter, and we have no with it.
llm_translation: Moses, you are speaking beautifully?! Rather, there and here we are dealing with a matter, and we have no concern with it. Rava said: A person should not say, "May the name of Rava be blessed," and then say, "Blessed," but rather, "May the name of Rava be blessed forever." Rav Safra said to him: Moses, you are speaking beautifully?! Rather, there and here we are dealing with a matter, and we have no concern with it.

hebrew_text: מָקוֹם שֶׁנָּהֲגוּ לִכְפּוֹל. תָּנָא: רַבִּי כּוֹפֵל בָּהּ דְּבָרִים. רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר בֶּן פַּרְטָא מוֹסִיף בָּהּ דְּבָרִים. מַאי מוֹסִיף? אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: מוֹסִיף לִכְפּוֹל מֵ״אוֹדְךָ״ וּלְמַטָּה.
human_translation: In a place where they were accustomed to repeat taught Rabbi repeats matters in Rabbi Elazar ben Perata adds matters in What he add? Abaye said: He continues repeating from: I will thank You, and onward
llm_translation: Place where they were accustomed to fold. It was taught: Rabbi folds in it words. Rabbi Elazar ben Parta adds in it words. What does he add? Abaye said: He adds to fold from "from your witness" and downwards.

hebrew_text: לְבָרֵךְ — יְבָרֵךְ. אֲמַר אַבָּיֵי: לֹא שָׁנוּ אֶלָּא לְאַחֲרָיו, אֲבָל לְפָנָיו — מִצְוָה לְבָרֵךְ. דְּאָמַר רַב יְהוּדָה אָמַר שְׁמוּאֵל: כׇּל הַמִּצְוֹת כּוּלָּן, מְבָרֵךְ עֲלֵיהֶן עוֹבֵר לַעֲשִׂיָּיתָן. וּמַאי מַשְׁמַע דְּהַאי ״עוֹבֵר״, לִישָּׁנָא דְּאַקְדּוֹמֵי הוּא? דְּאָמַר רַב נַחְמָן בַּר יִצְחָק דִּכְתִיב: ״וַיָּרׇץ אֲחִימַעַץ דֶּרֶךְ הַכִּכָּר וַיַּעֲבוֹר אֶת הַכּוּשִׁי״. אַבָּיֵי אָמַר, מֵהָכָא: ״וְהוּא עָבַר לִפְנֵיהֶם״. וְאִיבָּעֵית אֵימָא מֵהָכָא: ״וַיַּעֲבוֹר מַלְכָּם לִפְנֵיהֶם וַה׳ בְּרֹאשָׁם״.
human_translation: to recite a blessing he should recite a blessing. Abaye said: taught only after However, before a mitzva to recite a blessing, as Rav Yehuda said Shmuel said: all one recites a blessing over them prior to [ over ] their performance. From where may it be inferred that over is the language of priority? as Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said that it is written: “And Ahimaaz ran by the way of the plain and overtook [ vaya’avor ] the Cushite” Abaye said: from here: “And he passed [ avar ] before them” ( And if you wish, say from here: “And their king passed [ vaya’avor ] before them and the Lord at their head”
llm_translation: To bless - he shall bless. Abaye said: They only taught this regarding after, but before - it is a mitzvah to bless. For Rav Yehudah said in the name of Shmuel: For all the mitzvot, one who blesses upon them before performing them is considered as if he has passed before them. And what is implied by this "he has passed"? To the matter of being ahead of them? For Rav Nachman bar Yitzchak said as it is written: "And Achima'atz ran by way of the plain and passed the Kushite." Abaye said, from here: "And he passed before them." And if you wish, say from here: "And their king passed before them and Hashem at their head."

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ הַלּוֹקֵחַ לוּלָב מֵחֲבֵירוֹ בַּשְּׁבִיעִית — נוֹתֵן לוֹ אֶתְרוֹג בְּמַתָּנָה, לְפִי שֶׁאֵין רַשַּׁאי לְלוֹקְחוֹ בַּשְּׁבִיעִית.
human_translation: one who purchases a lulav from another during the Sabbatical Year, gives him an etrog as a gift, as he is not permitted to purchase during the Sabbatical Year
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: One who buys a lulav from his fellow on the seventh year of the Shemitah cycle—he gives him the etrog as a gift, because he is not permitted to buy it on the seventh year.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ לֹא רָצָה לִיתֵּן לוֹ בְּמַתָּנָה, מַהוּ? אָמַר רַב הוּנָא: מַבְלַיע לֵיהּ דְּמֵי אֶתְרוֹג בְּלוּלָב. וְלִיתֵּיב לֵיהּ בְּהֶדְיָא?
human_translation: did not want to give him as a gift, what is Rav Huna said: He incorporates the cost of the etrog into lulav . And let give directly;
llm_translation: Gemar did not want to give it to him as a gift, what is the law? Rav Huna said: He should swallow the value of an etrog in a lulav. And should he sit with him in Hadaya?

hebrew_text: לְפִי שֶׁאֵין מוֹסְרִין דְּמֵי פֵּירוֹת שְׁבִיעִית לְעַם הָאָרֶץ. דְּתַנְיָא: אֵין מוֹסְרִין דְּמֵי פֵּירוֹת שְׁבִיעִית לְעַם הָאָרֶץ יוֹתֵר מִמְּזוֹן שָׁלֹשׁ סְעוּדוֹת. וְאִם מָסַר, יֹאמַר: הֲרֵי מָעוֹת הַלָּלוּ יְהוּ מְחוּלָּלִין עַל פֵּירוֹת שֶׁיֵּשׁ לִי בְּתוֹךְ בֵּיתִי,
human_translation: because one may not transfer money Sabbatical-Year produce to an am ha’aretz , As it is taught One not transfer to an am ha’aretz money Sabbatical-Year produce more than food three meals. And if transferred he say: This money is deconsecrated produce that I have in my house.
llm_translation: According to the fact that we do not tithe the produce of the seventh year to the common people. As it was taught: We do not tithe the produce of the seventh year to the common people more than the sustenance of three meals. And if one did tithe, he should say: "Behold, these coins should be redeemed for the produce that I have in my house."

hebrew_text: וּבָא וְאוֹכְלָן בִּקְדוּשַּׁת שְׁבִיעִית.
human_translation: And he comes and eats in the sanctity of Sabbatical-Year
llm_translation: And he shall come and eat them in the holiness of the seventh.

hebrew_text: בַּמֶּה דְּבָרִים אֲמוּרִים — בְּלוֹקֵחַ מִן הַמּוּפְקָר. אֲבָל בְּלוֹקֵחַ מִן הַמְשׁוּמָּר, אֲפִילּוּ בְּכַחֲצִי אִיסָּר — אָסוּר.
human_translation: In what is this statement said where one purchases from ownerless However, he buys from that was safeguarded even worth half an issar , it is prohibited
llm_translation: In what case are these words spoken? When one takes from ownerless property. But when one takes from guarded property, even with half a perutah's worth, it is prohibited.
